12739  using type_error = detail::type_error;
12740  /// @copydoc detail::out_of_range
12741  using out_of_range = detail::out_of_range;
12742  /// @copydoc detail::other_error
12743  using other_error = detail::other_error;
12744 
12745  /// @}
12746 
12747 
12748  /////////////////////
12749  // container types //
12750  /////////////////////
12751 
12752  /// @name container types
12753  /// The canonic container types to use @ref basic_json like any other STL
12754  /// container.
12755  /// @{
12756 
12757  /// the type of elements in a basic_json container
12758  using value_type = basic_json;
12759 
12760  /// the type of an element reference
12761  using reference = value_type&;
12762  /// the type of an element const reference
12763  using const_reference = const value_type&;
12764 
12765  /// a type to represent differences between iterators
12766  using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
12767  /// a type to represent container sizes
12768  using size_type = std::size_t;
12769 
12770  /// the allocator type
12771  using allocator_type = AllocatorType<basic_json>;
12772 
12773  /// the type of an element pointer
12774  using pointer = typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::pointer;
12775  /// the type of an element const pointer
12776  using const_pointer = typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::const_pointer;
12777 
12778  /// an iterator for a basic_json container
12779  using iterator = iter_impl<basic_json>;
12780  /// a const iterator for a basic_json container
12781  using const_iterator = iter_impl<const basic_json>;
12782  /// a reverse iterator for a basic_json container
12783  using reverse_iterator = json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::iterator>;
12784  /// a const reverse iterator for a basic_json container
12785  using const_reverse_iterator = json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::const_iterator>;
12786 
12787  /// @}
12788 
12789 
12790  /*!
12791  @brief returns the allocator associated with the container
12792  */
12793  static allocator_type get_allocator()
12794  {
12795  return allocator_type();
12796  }
12797 
12798  /*!
12799  @brief returns version information on the library
12800 
12801  This function returns a JSON object with information about the library,
12802  including the version number and information on the platform and compiler.
12803 
12804  @return JSON object holding version information
12805  key | description
12806  ----------- | ---------------
12807  `compiler` | Information on the used compiler. It is an object with the following keys: `c++` (the used C++ standard), `family` (the compiler family; possible values are `clang`, `icc`, `gcc`, `ilecpp`, `msvc`, `pgcpp`, `sunpro`, and `unknown`), and `version` (the compiler version).
12808  `copyright` | The copyright line for the library as string.
12809  `name` | The name of the library as string.
12810  `platform` | The used platform as string. Possible values are `win32`, `linux`, `apple`, `unix`, and `unknown`.
12811  `url` | The URL of the project as string.
12812  `version` | The version of the library. It is an object with the following keys: `major`, `minor`, and `patch` as defined by [Semantic Versioning](http://semver.org), and `string` (the version string).
12813 
12814  @liveexample{The following code shows an example output of the `meta()`
12815  function.,meta}
12816 
12817  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
12818  changes to any JSON value.
12819 
12820  @complexity Constant.
12821 
12822  @since 2.1.0
12823  */
12824  JSON_NODISCARD
12825  static basic_json meta()
12826  {
12827  basic_json result;
12828 
12829  result["copyright"] = "(C) 2013-2017 Niels Lohmann";
12830  result["name"] = "JSON for Modern C++";
12831  result["url"] = "https://github.com/nlohmann/json";
12832  result["version"]["string"] =
12833  std::to_string(NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MAJOR) + "." +
12834  std::to_string(NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MINOR) + "." +
12835  std::to_string(NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_PATCH);
12836  result["version"]["major"] = NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MAJOR;
12837  result["version"]["minor"] = NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_MINOR;
12838  result["version"]["patch"] = NLOHMANN_JSON_VERSION_PATCH;
12839 
12840 #ifdef _WIN32
12841  result["platform"] = "win32";
12842 #elif defined __linux__
12843  result["platform"] = "linux";
12844 #elif defined __APPLE__
12845  result["platform"] = "apple";
12846 #elif defined __unix__
12847  result["platform"] = "unix";
12848 #else
12849  result["platform"] = "unknown";
12850 #endif
12851 
12852 #if defined(__ICC) || defined(__INTEL_COMPILER)
12853  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "icc"}, {"version", __INTEL_COMPILER}};
12854 #elif defined(__clang__)
12855  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "clang"}, {"version", __clang_version__}};
12856 #elif defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
12857  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "gcc"}, {"version", std::to_string(__GNUC__) + "." + std::to_string(__GNUC_MINOR__) + "." + std::to_string(__GNUC_PATCHLEVEL__)}};
12858 #elif defined(__HP_cc) || defined(__HP_aCC)
12859  result["compiler"] = "hp"
12860 #elif defined(__IBMCPP__)
12861  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "ilecpp"}, {"version", __IBMCPP__}};
12862 #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
12863  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "msvc"}, {"version", _MSC_VER}};
12864 #elif defined(__PGI)
12865  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "pgcpp"}, {"version", __PGI}};
12866 #elif defined(__SUNPRO_CC)
12867  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "sunpro"}, {"version", __SUNPRO_CC}};
12868 #else
12869  result["compiler"] = {{"family", "unknown"}, {"version", "unknown"}};
12870 #endif
12871 
12872 #ifdef __cplusplus
12873  result["compiler"]["c++"] = std::to_string(__cplusplus);
12874 #else
12875  result["compiler"]["c++"] = "unknown";
12876 #endif
12877  return result;
12878  }
12879 
12880 
12881  ///////////////////////////
12882  // JSON value data types //
12883  ///////////////////////////
12884 
12885  /// @name JSON value data types
12886  /// The data types to store a JSON value. These types are derived from
12887  /// the template arguments passed to class @ref basic_json.
12888  /// @{
12889 
12890 #if defined(JSON_HAS_CPP_14)
12891  // Use transparent comparator if possible, combined with perfect forwarding
12892  // on find() and count() calls prevents unnecessary string construction.
12893  using object_comparator_t = std::less<>;
12894 #else
12895  using object_comparator_t = std::less<StringType>;
12896 #endif
12897 
12898  /*!
12899  @brief a type for an object
12900 
12901  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON objects as follows:
12902  > An object is an unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs,
12903  > where a name is a string and a value is a string, number, boolean, null,
12904  > object, or array.
12905 
12906  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters
12907  described below.
12908 
12909  @tparam ObjectType the container to store objects (e.g., `std::map` or
12910  `std::unordered_map`)
12911  @tparam StringType the type of the keys or names (e.g., `std::string`).
12912  The comparison function `std::less<StringType>` is used to order elements
12913  inside the container.
12914  @tparam AllocatorType the allocator to use for objects (e.g.,
12915  `std::allocator`)
12916 
12917  #### Default type
12918 
12919  With the default values for @a ObjectType (`std::map`), @a StringType
12920  (`std::string`), and @a AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default
12921  value for @a object_t is:
12922 
12923  @code {.cpp}
12924  std::map<
12925  std::string, // key_type
12926  basic_json, // value_type
12927  std::less<std::string>, // key_compare
12928  std::allocator<std::pair<const std::string, basic_json>> // allocator_type
12929  >
12930  @endcode
12931 
12932  #### Behavior
12933 
12934  The choice of @a object_t influences the behavior of the JSON class. With
12935  the default type, objects have the following behavior:
12936 
12937  - When all names are unique, objects will be interoperable in the sense
12938  that all software implementations receiving that object will agree on
12939  the name-value mappings.
12940  - When the names within an object are not unique, it is unspecified which
12941  one of the values for a given key will be chosen. For instance,
12942  `{"key": 2, "key": 1}` could be equal to either `{"key": 1}` or
12943  `{"key": 2}`.
12944  - Internally, name/value pairs are stored in lexicographical order of the
12945  names. Objects will also be serialized (see @ref dump) in this order.
12946  For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be stored
12947  and serialized as `{"a": 2, "b": 1}`.
12948  - When comparing objects, the order of the name/value pairs is irrelevant.
12949  This makes objects interoperable in the sense that they will not be
12950  affected by these differences. For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and
12951  `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be treated as equal.
12952 
12953  #### Limits
12954 
12955  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
12956  > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
12957 
12958  In this class, the object's limit of nesting is not explicitly constrained.
12959  However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
12960  runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the
12961  @ref max_size function of a JSON object.
12962 
12963  #### Storage
12964 
12965  Objects are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is, for any
12966  access to object values, a pointer of type `object_t*` must be
12967  dereferenced.
12968 
12969  @sa @ref array_t -- type for an array value
12970 
12971  @since version 1.0.0
12972 
12973  @note The order name/value pairs are added to the object is *not*
12974  preserved by the library. Therefore, iterating an object may return
12975  name/value pairs in a different order than they were originally stored. In
12976  fact, keys will be traversed in alphabetical order as `std::map` with
12977  `std::less` is used by default. Please note this behavior conforms to [RFC
12978  7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159), because any order implements the
12979  specified "unordered" nature of JSON objects.
12980  */
12981  using object_t = ObjectType<StringType,
12982  basic_json,
12983  object_comparator_t,
12984  AllocatorType<std::pair<const StringType,
12985  basic_json>>>;
12986 
12987  /*!
12988  @brief a type for an array
12989 
12990  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON arrays as follows:
12991  > An array is an ordered sequence of zero or more values.
12992 
12993  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters
12994  explained below.
12995 
12996  @tparam ArrayType container type to store arrays (e.g., `std::vector` or
12997  `std::list`)
12998  @tparam AllocatorType allocator to use for arrays (e.g., `std::allocator`)
12999 
13000  #### Default type
13001 
13002  With the default values for @a ArrayType (`std::vector`) and @a
13003  AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default value for @a array_t is:
13004 
13005  @code {.cpp}
13006  std::vector<
13007  basic_json, // value_type
13008  std::allocator<basic_json> // allocator_type
13009  >
13010  @endcode
13011 
13012  #### Limits
13013 
13014  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
13015  > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
13016 
13017  In this class, the array's limit of nesting is not explicitly constrained.
13018  However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
13019  runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the
13020  @ref max_size function of a JSON array.
13021 
13022  #### Storage
13023 
13024  Arrays are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is, for any
13025  access to array values, a pointer of type `array_t*` must be dereferenced.
13026 
13027  @sa @ref object_t -- type for an object value
13028 
13029  @since version 1.0.0
13030  */
13031  using array_t = ArrayType<basic_json, AllocatorType<basic_json>>;
13032 
13033  /*!
13034  @brief a type for a string
13035 
13036  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON strings as follows:
13037  > A string is a sequence of zero or more Unicode characters.
13038 
13039  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter
13040  described below. Unicode values are split by the JSON class into
13041  byte-sized characters during deserialization.
13042 
13043  @tparam StringType the container to store strings (e.g., `std::string`).
13044  Note this container is used for keys/names in objects, see @ref object_t.
13045 
13046  #### Default type
13047 
13048  With the default values for @a StringType (`std::string`), the default
13049  value for @a string_t is:
13050 
13051  @code {.cpp}
13052  std::string
13053  @endcode
13054 
13055  #### Encoding
13056 
13057  Strings are stored in UTF-8 encoding. Therefore, functions like
13058  `std::string::size()` or `std::string::length()` return the number of
13059  bytes in the string rather than the number of characters or glyphs.
13060 
13061  #### String comparison
13062 
13063  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
13064  > Software implementations are typically required to test names of object
13065  > members for equality. Implementations that transform the textual
13066  > representation into sequences of Unicode code units and then perform the
13067  > comparison numerically, code unit by code unit, are interoperable in the
13068  > sense that implementations will agree in all cases on equality or
13069  > inequality of two strings. For example, implementations that compare
13070  > strings with escaped characters unconverted may incorrectly find that
13071  > `"a\\b"` and `"a\u005Cb"` are not equal.
13072 
13073  This implementation is interoperable as it does compare strings code unit
13074  by code unit.
13075 
13076  #### Storage
13077 
13078  String values are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is,
13079  for any access to string values, a pointer of type `string_t*` must be
13080  dereferenced.
13081 
13082  @since version 1.0.0
13083  */
13084  using string_t = StringType;
13085 
13086  /*!
13087  @brief a type for a boolean
13088 
13089  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) implicitly describes a boolean as a
13090  type which differentiates the two literals `true` and `false`.
13091 
13092  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter @a
13093  BooleanType which chooses the type to use.
13094 
13095  #### Default type
13096 
13097  With the default values for @a BooleanType (`bool`), the default value for
13098  @a boolean_t is:
13099 
13100  @code {.cpp}
13101  bool
13102  @endcode
13103 
13104  #### Storage
13105 
13106  Boolean values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
13107 
13108  @since version 1.0.0
13109  */
13110  using boolean_t = BooleanType;
13111 
13112  /*!
13113  @brief a type for a number (integer)
13114 
13115  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
13116  > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
13117  > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
13118  > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
13119  > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
13120  > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
13121  > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
13122  > are not permitted.
13123 
13124  This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
13125  However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
13126  is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
13127  Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
13128  number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
13129 
13130  To store integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
13131  parameter @a NumberIntegerType which chooses the type to use.
13132 
13133  #### Default type
13134 
13135  With the default values for @a NumberIntegerType (`int64_t`), the default
13136  value for @a number_integer_t is:
13137 
13138  @code {.cpp}
13139  int64_t
13140  @endcode
13141 
13142  #### Default behavior
13143 
13144  - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
13145  leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
13146  number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
13147  instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`.
13148  During deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
13149  - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
13150 
13151  #### Limits
13152 
13153  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
13154  > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
13155 
13156  When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
13157  stored is `9223372036854775807` (INT64_MAX) and the minimal integer number
13158  that can be stored is `-9223372036854775808` (INT64_MIN). Integer numbers
13159  that are out of range will yield over/underflow when used in a
13160  constructor. During deserialization, too large or small integer numbers
13161  will be automatically be stored as @ref number_unsigned_t or @ref
13162  number_float_t.
13163 
13164  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
13165  > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
13166  > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
13167  > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
13168 
13169  As this range is a subrange of the exactly supported range [INT64_MIN,
13170  INT64_MAX], this class's integer type is interoperable.
13171 
13172  #### Storage
13173 
13174  Integer number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
13175 
13176  @sa @ref number_float_t -- type for number values (floating-point)
13177 
13178  @sa @ref number_unsigned_t -- type for number values (unsigned integer)
13179 
13180  @since version 1.0.0
13181  */
13182  using number_integer_t = NumberIntegerType;
13183 
13184  /*!
13185  @brief a type for a number (unsigned)
13186 
13187  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
13188  > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
13189  > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
13190  > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
13191  > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
13192  > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
13193  > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
13194  > are not permitted.
13195 
13196  This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
13197  However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
13198  is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
13199  Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
13200  number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
13201 
13202  To store unsigned integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the
13203  template parameter @a NumberUnsignedType which chooses the type to use.
13204 
13205  #### Default type
13206 
13207  With the default values for @a NumberUnsignedType (`uint64_t`), the
13208  default value for @a number_unsigned_t is:
13209 
13210  @code {.cpp}
13211  uint64_t
13212  @endcode
13213 
13214  #### Default behavior
13215 
13216  - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
13217  leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
13218  number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
13219  instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`.
13220  During deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
13221  - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
13222 
13223  #### Limits
13224 
13225  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
13226  > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
13227 
13228  When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
13229  stored is `18446744073709551615` (UINT64_MAX) and the minimal integer
13230  number that can be stored is `0`. Integer numbers that are out of range
13231  will yield over/underflow when used in a constructor. During
13232  deserialization, too large or small integer numbers will be automatically
13233  be stored as @ref number_integer_t or @ref number_float_t.
13234 
13235  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
13236  > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
13237  > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
13238  > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
13239 
13240  As this range is a subrange (when considered in conjunction with the
13241  number_integer_t type) of the exactly supported range [0, UINT64_MAX],
13242  this class's integer type is interoperable.
13243 
13244  #### Storage
13245 
13246  Integer number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
13247 
13248  @sa @ref number_float_t -- type for number values (floating-point)
13249  @sa @ref number_integer_t -- type for number values (integer)
13250 
13251  @since version 2.0.0
13252  */
13253  using number_unsigned_t = NumberUnsignedType;
13254 
13255  /*!
13256  @brief a type for a number (floating-point)
13257 
13258  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
13259  > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
13260  > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
13261  > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
13262  > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
13263  > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
13264  > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
13265  > are not permitted.
13266 
13267  This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
13268  However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
13269  is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
13270  Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
13271  number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
13272 
13273  To store floating-point numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
13274  parameter @a NumberFloatType which chooses the type to use.
13275 
13276  #### Default type
13277 
13278  With the default values for @a NumberFloatType (`double`), the default
13279  value for @a number_float_t is:
13280 
13281  @code {.cpp}
13282  double
13283  @endcode
13284 
13285  #### Default behavior
13286 
13287  - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
13288  leading zeros in floating-point literals will be ignored. Internally,
13289  the value will be stored as decimal number. For instance, the C++
13290  floating-point literal `01.2` will be serialized to `1.2`. During
13291  deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
13292  - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
13293 
13294  #### Limits
13295 
13296  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
13297  > This specification allows implementations to set limits on the range and
13298  > precision of numbers accepted. Since software that implements IEEE
13299  > 754-2008 binary64 (double precision) numbers is generally available and
13300  > widely used, good interoperability can be achieved by implementations
13301  > that expect no more precision or range than these provide, in the sense
13302  > that implementations will approximate JSON numbers within the expected
13303  > precision.
13304 
13305  This implementation does exactly follow this approach, as it uses double
13306  precision floating-point numbers. Note values smaller than
13307  `-1.79769313486232e+308` and values greater than `1.79769313486232e+308`
13308  will be stored as NaN internally and be serialized to `null`.
13309 
13310  #### Storage
13311 
13312  Floating-point number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json
13313  type.
13314 
13315  @sa @ref number_integer_t -- type for number values (integer)
13316 
13317  @sa @ref number_unsigned_t -- type for number values (unsigned integer)
13318 
13319  @since version 1.0.0
13320  */
13321  using number_float_t = NumberFloatType;
13322 
13323  /// @}
13324 
13325  private:
13326 
13327  /// helper for exception-safe object creation
13328  template<typename T, typename... Args>
13329  static T* create(Args&& ... args)
13330  {
13331  AllocatorType<T> alloc;
13332  using AllocatorTraits = std::allocator_traits<AllocatorType<T>>;
13333 
13334  auto deleter = [&](T * object)
13335  {
13336  AllocatorTraits::deallocate(alloc, object, 1);
13337  };
13338  std::unique_ptr<T, decltype(deleter)> object(AllocatorTraits::allocate(alloc, 1), deleter);
13339  AllocatorTraits::construct(alloc, object.get(), std::forward<Args>(args)...);
13340  assert(object != nullptr);
13341  return object.release();
13342  }
13343 
13344  ////////////////////////
13345  // JSON value storage //
13346  ////////////////////////
13347 
13348  /*!
13349  @brief a JSON value
13350 
13351  The actual storage for a JSON value of the @ref basic_json class. This
13352  union combines the different storage types for the JSON value types
13353  defined in @ref value_t.
13354 
13355  JSON type | value_t type | used type
13356  --------- | --------------- | ------------------------
13357  object | object | pointer to @ref object_t
13358  array | array | pointer to @ref array_t
13359  string | string | pointer to @ref string_t
13360  boolean | boolean | @ref boolean_t
13361  number | number_integer | @ref number_integer_t
13362  number | number_unsigned | @ref number_unsigned_t
13363  number | number_float | @ref number_float_t
13364  null | null | *no value is stored*
13365 
13366  @note Variable-length types (objects, arrays, and strings) are stored as
13367  pointers. The size of the union should not exceed 64 bits if the default
13368  value types are used.
13369 
13370  @since version 1.0.0
13371  */
13372  union json_value
13373  {
13374  /// object (stored with pointer to save storage)
13375  object_t* object;
13376  /// array (stored with pointer to save storage)
13377  array_t* array;
13378  /// string (stored with pointer to save storage)
13379  string_t* string;
13380  /// boolean
13381  boolean_t boolean;
13382  /// number (integer)
13383  number_integer_t number_integer;
13384  /// number (unsigned integer)
13385  number_unsigned_t number_unsigned;
13386  /// number (floating-point)
13387  number_float_t number_float;
13388 
13389  /// default constructor (for null values)
13390  json_value() = default;
13391  /// constructor for booleans
13392  json_value(boolean_t v) noexcept : boolean(v) {}
13393  /// constructor for numbers (integer)
13394  json_value(number_integer_t v) noexcept : number_integer(v) {}
13395  /// constructor for numbers (unsigned)
13396  json_value(number_unsigned_t v) noexcept : number_unsigned(v) {}
13397  /// constructor for numbers (floating-point)
13398  json_value(number_float_t v) noexcept : number_float(v) {}
13399  /// constructor for empty values of a given type
13400  json_value(value_t t)
13401  {
13402  switch (t)
13403  {
13404  case value_t::object:
13405  {
13406  object = create<object_t>();
13407  break;
13408  }
13409 
13410  case value_t::array:
13411  {
13412  array = create<array_t>();
13413  break;
13414  }
13415 
13416  case value_t::string:
13417  {
13418  string = create<string_t>("");
13419  break;
13420  }
13421 
13422  case value_t::boolean:
13423  {
13424  boolean = boolean_t(false);
13425  break;
13426  }
13427 
13428  case value_t::number_integer:
13429  {
13430  number_integer = number_integer_t(0);
13431  break;
13432  }
13433 
13434  case value_t::number_unsigned:
13435  {
13436  number_unsigned = number_unsigned_t(0);
13437  break;
13438  }
13439 
13440  case value_t::number_float:
13441  {
13442  number_float = number_float_t(0.0);
13443  break;
13444  }
13445 
13446  case value_t::null:
13447  {
13448  object = nullptr; // silence warning, see #821
13449  break;
13450  }
13451 
13452  default:
13453  {
13454  object = nullptr; // silence warning, see #821
13455  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(t == value_t::null))
13456  {
13457  JSON_THROW(other_error::create(500, "961c151d2e87f2686a955a9be24d316f1362bf21 3.5.0")); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
13458  }
13459  break;
13460  }
13461  }
13462  }
13463 
13464  /// constructor for strings
13465  json_value(const string_t& value)
13466  {
13467  string = create<string_t>(value);
13468  }
13469 
13470  /// constructor for rvalue strings
13471  json_value(string_t&& value)
13472  {
13473  string = create<string_t>(std::move(value));
13474  }
13475 
13476  /// constructor for objects
13477  json_value(const object_t& value)
13478  {
13479  object = create<object_t>(value);
13480  }
13481 
13482  /// constructor for rvalue objects
13483  json_value(object_t&& value)
13484  {
13485  object = create<object_t>(std::move(value));
13486  }
13487 
13488  /// constructor for arrays
13489  json_value(const array_t& value)
13490  {
13491  array = create<array_t>(value);
13492  }
13493 
13494  /// constructor for rvalue arrays
13495  json_value(array_t&& value)
13496  {
13497  array = create<array_t>(std::move(value));
13498  }
13499 
13500  void destroy(value_t t) noexcept
13501  {
13502  switch (t)
13503  {
13504  case value_t::object:
13505  {
13506  AllocatorType<object_t> alloc;
13507  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, object);
13508  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, object, 1);
13509  break;
13510  }
13511 
13512  case value_t::array:
13513  {
13514  AllocatorType<array_t> alloc;
13515  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, array);
13516  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, array, 1);
13517  break;
13518  }
13519 
13520  case value_t::string:
13521  {
13522  AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
13523  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, string);
13524  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, string, 1);
13525  break;
13526  }
13527 
13528  default:
13529  {
13530  break;
13531  }
13532  }
13533  }
13534  };
13535 
13536  /*!
13537  @brief checks the class invariants
13538 
13539  This function asserts the class invariants. It needs to be called at the
13540  end of every constructor to make sure that created objects respect the
13541  invariant. Furthermore, it has to be called each time the type of a JSON
13542  value is changed, because the invariant expresses a relationship between
13543  @a m_type and @a m_value.
13544  */
13545  void assert_invariant() const noexcept
13546  {
13547  assert(m_type != value_t::object or m_value.object != nullptr);
13548  assert(m_type != value_t::array or m_value.array != nullptr);
13549  assert(m_type != value_t::string or m_value.string != nullptr);
13550  }
13551 
13552  public:
13553  //////////////////////////
13554  // JSON parser callback //
13555  //////////////////////////
13556 
13557  /*!
13558  @brief parser event types
13559 
13560  The parser callback distinguishes the following events:
13561  - `object_start`: the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object
13562  - `key`: the parser read a key of a value in an object
13563  - `object_end`: the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object
13564  - `array_start`: the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array
13565  - `array_end`: the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array
13566  - `value`: the parser finished reading a JSON value
13567 
13568  @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are triggered"
13569 
13570  @sa @ref parser_callback_t for more information and examples
13571  */
13572  using parse_event_t = typename parser::parse_event_t;
13573 
13574  /*!
13575  @brief per-element parser callback type
13576 
13577  With a parser callback function, the result of parsing a JSON text can be
13578  influenced. When passed to @ref parse, it is called on certain events
13579  (passed as @ref parse_event_t via parameter @a event) with a set recursion
13580  depth @a depth and context JSON value @a parsed. The return value of the
13581  callback function is a boolean indicating whether the element that emitted
13582  the callback shall be kept or not.
13583 
13584  We distinguish six scenarios (determined by the event type) in which the
13585  callback function can be called. The following table describes the values
13586  of the parameters @a depth, @a event, and @a parsed.
13587 
13588  parameter @a event | description | parameter @a depth | parameter @a parsed
13589  ------------------ | ----------- | ------------------ | -------------------
13590  parse_event_t::object_start | the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | a JSON value with type discarded
13591  parse_event_t::key | the parser read a key of a value in an object | depth of the currently parsed JSON object | a JSON string containing the key
13592  parse_event_t::object_end | the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | the parsed JSON object
13593  parse_event_t::array_start | the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | a JSON value with type discarded
13594  parse_event_t::array_end | the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | the parsed JSON array
13595  parse_event_t::value | the parser finished reading a JSON value | depth of the value | the parsed JSON value
13596 
13597  @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are triggered"
13598 
13599  Discarding a value (i.e., returning `false`) has different effects
13600  depending on the context in which function was called:
13601 
13602  - Discarded values in structured types are skipped. That is, the parser
13603  will behave as if the discarded value was never read.
13604  - In case a value outside a structured type is skipped, it is replaced
13605  with `null`. This case happens if the top-level element is skipped.
13606 
13607  @param[in] depth the depth of the recursion during parsing
13608 
13609  @param[in] event an event of type parse_event_t indicating the context in
13610  the callback function has been called
13611 
13612  @param[in,out] parsed the current intermediate parse result; note that
13613  writing to this value has no effect for parse_event_t::key events
13614 
13615  @return Whether the JSON value which called the function during parsing
13616  should be kept (`true`) or not (`false`). In the latter case, it is either
13617  skipped completely or replaced by an empty discarded object.
13618 
13619  @sa @ref parse for examples
13620 
13621  @since version 1.0.0
13622  */
13623  using parser_callback_t = typename parser::parser_callback_t;
13624 
13625  //////////////////
13626  // constructors //
13627  //////////////////
13628 
13629  /// @name constructors and destructors
13630  /// Constructors of class @ref basic_json, copy/move constructor, copy
13631  /// assignment, static functions creating objects, and the destructor.
13632  /// @{
13633 
13634  /*!
13635  @brief create an empty value with a given type
13636 
13637  Create an empty JSON value with a given type. The value will be default
13638  initialized with an empty value which depends on the type:
13639 
13640  Value type | initial value
13641  ----------- | -------------
13642  null | `null`
13643  boolean | `false`
13644  string | `""`
13645  number | `0`
13646  object | `{}`
13647  array | `[]`
13648 
13649  @param[in] v the type of the value to create
13650 
13651  @complexity Constant.
13652 
13653  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
13654  changes to any JSON value.
13655 
13656  @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor for different @ref
13657  value_t values,basic_json__value_t}
13658 
13659  @sa @ref clear() -- restores the postcondition of this constructor
13660 
13661  @since version 1.0.0
13662  */
13663  basic_json(const value_t v)
13664  : m_type(v), m_value(v)
13665  {
13666  assert_invariant();
13667  }
13668 
13669  /*!
13670  @brief create a null object
13671 
13672  Create a `null` JSON value. It either takes a null pointer as parameter
13673  (explicitly creating `null`) or no parameter (implicitly creating `null`).
13674  The passed null pointer itself is not read -- it is only used to choose
13675  the right constructor.
13676 
13677  @complexity Constant.
13678 
13679  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
13680  exceptions.
13681 
13682  @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with and without a
13683  null pointer parameter.,basic_json__nullptr_t}
13684 
13685  @since version 1.0.0
13686  */
13687  basic_json(std::nullptr_t = nullptr) noexcept
13688  : basic_json(value_t::null)
13689  {
13690  assert_invariant();
13691  }
13692 
13693  /*!
13694  @brief create a JSON value
13695 
13696  This is a "catch all" constructor for all compatible JSON types; that is,
13697  types for which a `to_json()` method exists. The constructor forwards the
13698  parameter @a val to that method (to `json_serializer<U>::to_json` method
13699  with `U = uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`, to be exact).
13700 
13701  Template type @a CompatibleType includes, but is not limited to, the
13702  following types:
13703  - **arrays**: @ref array_t and all kinds of compatible containers such as
13704  `std::vector`, `std::deque`, `std::list`, `std::forward_list`,
13705  `std::array`, `std::valarray`, `std::set`, `std::unordered_set`,
13706  `std::multiset`, and `std::unordered_multiset` with a `value_type` from
13707  which a @ref basic_json value can be constructed.
13708  - **objects**: @ref object_t and all kinds of compatible associative
13709  containers such as `std::map`, `std::unordered_map`, `std::multimap`,
13710  and `std::unordered_multimap` with a `key_type` compatible to
13711  @ref string_t and a `value_type` from which a @ref basic_json value can
13712  be constructed.
13713  - **strings**: @ref string_t, string literals, and all compatible string
13714  containers can be used.
13715  - **numbers**: @ref number_integer_t, @ref number_unsigned_t,
13716  @ref number_float_t, and all convertible number types such as `int`,
13717  `size_t`, `int64_t`, `float` or `double` can be used.
13718  - **boolean**: @ref boolean_t / `bool` can be used.
13719 
13720  See the examples below.
13721 
13722  @tparam CompatibleType a type such that:
13723  - @a CompatibleType is not derived from `std::istream`,
13724  - @a CompatibleType is not @ref basic_json (to avoid hijacking copy/move
13725  constructors),
13726  - @a CompatibleType is not a different @ref basic_json type (i.e. with different template arguments)
13727  - @a CompatibleType is not a @ref basic_json nested type (e.g.,
13728  @ref json_pointer, @ref iterator, etc ...)
13729  - @ref @ref json_serializer<U> has a
13730  `to_json(basic_json_t&, CompatibleType&&)` method
13731 
13732  @tparam U = `uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`
13733 
13734  @param[in] val the value to be forwarded to the respective constructor
13735 
13736  @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
13737  depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
13738  method.
13739 
13740  @exceptionsafety Depends on the called constructor. For types directly
13741  supported by the library (i.e., all types for which no `to_json()` function
13742  was provided), strong guarantee holds: if an exception is thrown, there are
13743  no changes to any JSON value.
13744 
13745  @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with several
13746  compatible types.,basic_json__CompatibleType}
13747 
13748  @since version 2.1.0
13749  */
13750  template <typename CompatibleType,
13751  typename U = detail::uncvref_t<CompatibleType>,
13752  detail::enable_if_t<
13753  not detail::is_basic_json<U>::value and detail::is_compatible_type<basic_json_t, U>::value, int> = 0>
13754  basic_json(CompatibleType && val) noexcept(noexcept(
13755  JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(std::declval<basic_json_t&>(),
13756  std::forward<CompatibleType>(val))))
13757  {
13758  JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(*this, std::forward<CompatibleType>(val));
13759  assert_invariant();
13760  }
13761 
13762  /*!
13763  @brief create a JSON value from an existing one
13764 
13765  This is a constructor for existing @ref basic_json types.
13766  It does not hijack copy/move constructors, since the parameter has different
13767  template arguments than the current ones.
13768 
13769  The constructor tries to convert the internal @ref m_value of the parameter.
13770 
13771  @tparam BasicJsonType a type such that:
13772  - @a BasicJsonType is a @ref basic_json type.
13773  - @a BasicJsonType has different template arguments than @ref basic_json_t.
13774 
13775  @param[in] val the @ref basic_json value to be converted.
13776 
13777  @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
13778  depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
13779  method.
13780 
13781  @exceptionsafety Depends on the called constructor. For types directly
13782  supported by the library (i.e., all types for which no `to_json()` function
13783  was provided), strong guarantee holds: if an exception is thrown, there are
13784  no changes to any JSON value.
13785 
13786  @since version 3.2.0
13787  */
13788  template <typename BasicJsonType,
13789  detail::enable_if_t<
13790  detail::is_basic_json<BasicJsonType>::value and not std::is_same<basic_json, BasicJsonType>::value, int> = 0>
13791  basic_json(const BasicJsonType& val)
13792  {
13793  using other_boolean_t = typename BasicJsonType::boolean_t;
13794  using other_number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
13795  using other_number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
13796  using other_number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
13797  using other_string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
13798  using other_object_t = typename BasicJsonType::object_t;
13799  using other_array_t = typename BasicJsonType::array_t;
13800 
13801  switch (val.type())
13802  {
13803  case value_t::boolean:
13804  JSONSerializer<other_boolean_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_boolean_t>());
13805  break;
13806  case value_t::number_float:
13807  JSONSerializer<other_number_float_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_number_float_t>());
13808  break;
13809  case value_t::number_integer:
13810  JSONSerializer<other_number_integer_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_number_integer_t>());
13811  break;
13812  case value_t::number_unsigned:
13813  JSONSerializer<other_number_unsigned_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_number_unsigned_t>());
13814  break;
13815  case value_t::string:
13816  JSONSerializer<other_string_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get_ref<const other_string_t&>());
13817  break;
13818  case value_t::object:
13819  JSONSerializer<other_object_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get_ref<const other_object_t&>());
13820  break;
13821  case value_t::array:
13822  JSONSerializer<other_array_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get_ref<const other_array_t&>());
13823  break;
13824  case value_t::null:
13825  *this = nullptr;
13826  break;
13827  case value_t::discarded:
13828  m_type = value_t::discarded;
13829  break;
13830  }
13831  assert_invariant();
13832  }
13833 
13834  /*!
13835  @brief create a container (array or object) from an initializer list
13836 
13837  Creates a JSON value of type array or object from the passed initializer
13838  list @a init. In case @a type_deduction is `true` (default), the type of
13839  the JSON value to be created is deducted from the initializer list @a init
13840  according to the following rules:
13841 
13842  1. If the list is empty, an empty JSON object value `{}` is created.
13843  2. If the list consists of pairs whose first element is a string, a JSON
13844  object value is created where the first elements of the pairs are
13845  treated as keys and the second elements are as values.
13846  3. In all other cases, an array is created.
13847 
13848  The rules aim to create the best fit between a C++ initializer list and
13849  JSON values. The rationale is as follows:
13850 
13851  1. The empty initializer list is written as `{}` which is exactly an empty
13852  JSON object.
13853  2. C++ has no way of describing mapped types other than to list a list of
13854  pairs. As JSON requires that keys must be of type string, rule 2 is the
13855  weakest constraint one can pose on initializer lists to interpret them
13856  as an object.
13857  3. In all other cases, the initializer list could not be interpreted as
13858  JSON object type, so interpreting it as JSON array type is safe.
13859 
13860  With the rules described above, the following JSON values cannot be
13861  expressed by an initializer list:
13862 
13863  - the empty array (`[]`): use @ref array(initializer_list_t)
13864  with an empty initializer list in this case
13865  - arrays whose elements satisfy rule 2: use @ref
13866  array(initializer_list_t) with the same initializer list
13867  in this case
13868 
13869  @note When used without parentheses around an empty initializer list, @ref
13870  basic_json() is called instead of this function, yielding the JSON null
13871  value.
13872 
13873  @param[in] init initializer list with JSON values
13874 
13875  @param[in] type_deduction internal parameter; when set to `true`, the type
13876  of the JSON value is deducted from the initializer list @a init; when set
13877  to `false`, the type provided via @a manual_type is forced. This mode is
13878  used by the functions @ref array(initializer_list_t) and
13879  @ref object(initializer_list_t).
13880 
13881  @param[in] manual_type internal parameter; when @a type_deduction is set
13882  to `false`, the created JSON value will use the provided type (only @ref
13883  value_t::array and @ref value_t::object are valid); when @a type_deduction
13884  is set to `true`, this parameter has no effect
13885 
13886  @throw type_error.301 if @a type_deduction is `false`, @a manual_type is
13887  `value_t::object`, but @a init contains an element which is not a pair
13888  whose first element is a string. In this case, the constructor could not
13889  create an object. If @a type_deduction would have be `true`, an array
13890  would have been created. See @ref object(initializer_list_t)
13891  for an example.
13892 
13893  @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
13894 
13895  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
13896  changes to any JSON value.
13897 
13898  @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values are created from
13899  initializer lists.,basic_json__list_init_t}
13900 
13901  @sa @ref array(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON array
13902  value from an initializer list
13903  @sa @ref object(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON object
13904  value from an initializer list
13905 
13906  @since version 1.0.0
13907  */
13908  basic_json(initializer_list_t init,
13909  bool type_deduction = true,
13910  value_t manual_type = value_t::array)
13911  {
13912  // check if each element is an array with two elements whose first
13913  // element is a string
13914  bool is_an_object = std::all_of(init.begin(), init.end(),
13915  [](const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& element_ref)
13916  {
13917  return (element_ref->is_array() and element_ref->size() == 2 and (*element_ref)[0].is_string());
13918  });
13919 
13920  // adjust type if type deduction is not wanted
13921  if (not type_deduction)
13922  {
13923  // if array is wanted, do not create an object though possible
13924  if (manual_type == value_t::array)
13925  {
13926  is_an_object = false;
13927  }
13928 
13929  // if object is wanted but impossible, throw an exception
13930  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(manual_type == value_t::object and not is_an_object))
13931  {
13932  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(301, "cannot create object from initializer list"));
13933  }
13934  }
13935 
13936  if (is_an_object)
13937  {
13938  // the initializer list is a list of pairs -> create object
13939  m_type = value_t::object;
13940  m_value = value_t::object;
13941 
13942  std::for_each(init.begin(), init.end(), [this](const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& element_ref)
13943  {
13944  auto element = element_ref.moved_or_copied();
13945  m_value.object->emplace(
13946  std::move(*((*element.m_value.array)[0].m_value.string)),
13947  std::move((*element.m_value.array)[1]));
13948  });
13949  }
13950  else
13951  {
13952  // the initializer list describes an array -> create array
13953  m_type = value_t::array;
13954  m_value.array = create<array_t>(init.begin(), init.end());
13955  }
13956 
13957  assert_invariant();
13958  }
13959 
13960  /*!
13961  @brief explicitly create an array from an initializer list
13962 
13963  Creates a JSON array value from a given initializer list. That is, given a
13964  list of values `a, b, c`, creates the JSON value `[a, b, c]`. If the
13965  initializer list is empty, the empty array `[]` is created.
13966 
13967  @note This function is only needed to express two edge cases that cannot
13968  be realized with the initializer list constructor (@ref
13969  basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t)). These cases
13970  are:
13971  1. creating an array whose elements are all pairs whose first element is a
13972  string -- in this case, the initializer list constructor would create an
13973  object, taking the first elements as keys
13974  2. creating an empty array -- passing the empty initializer list to the
13975  initializer list constructor yields an empty object
13976 
13977  @param[in] init initializer list with JSON values to create an array from
13978  (optional)
13979 
13980  @return JSON array value
13981 
13982  @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
13983 
13984  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
13985  changes to any JSON value.
13986 
13987  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `array`
13988  function.,array}
13989 
13990  @sa @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t) --
13991  create a JSON value from an initializer list
13992  @sa @ref object(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON object
13993  value from an initializer list
13994 
13995  @since version 1.0.0
13996  */
13997  JSON_NODISCARD
13998  static basic_json array(initializer_list_t init = {})
13999  {
14000  return basic_json(init, false, value_t::array);
14001  }
14002 
14003  /*!
14004  @brief explicitly create an object from an initializer list
14005 
14006  Creates a JSON object value from a given initializer list. The initializer
14007  lists elements must be pairs, and their first elements must be strings. If
14008  the initializer list is empty, the empty object `{}` is created.
14009 
14010  @note This function is only added for symmetry reasons. In contrast to the
14011  related function @ref array(initializer_list_t), there are
14012  no cases which can only be expressed by this function. That is, any
14013  initializer list @a init can also be passed to the initializer list
14014  constructor @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t).
14015 
14016  @param[in] init initializer list to create an object from (optional)
14017 
14018  @return JSON object value
14019 
14020  @throw type_error.301 if @a init is not a list of pairs whose first
14021  elements are strings. In this case, no object can be created. When such a
14022  value is passed to @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t),
14023  an array would have been created from the passed initializer list @a init.
14024  See example below.
14025 
14026  @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
14027 
14028  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
14029  changes to any JSON value.
14030 
14031  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `object`
14032  function.,object}
14033 
14034  @sa @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t) --
14035  create a JSON value from an initializer list
14036  @sa @ref array(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON array
14037  value from an initializer list
14038 
14039  @since version 1.0.0
14040  */
14041  JSON_NODISCARD
14042  static basic_json object(initializer_list_t init = {})
14043  {
14044  return basic_json(init, false, value_t::object);
14045  }
14046 
14047  /*!
14048  @brief construct an array with count copies of given value
14049 
14050  Constructs a JSON array value by creating @a cnt copies of a passed value.
14051  In case @a cnt is `0`, an empty array is created.
14052 
14053  @param[in] cnt the number of JSON copies of @a val to create
14054  @param[in] val the JSON value to copy
14055 
14056  @post `std::distance(begin(),end()) == cnt` holds.
14057 
14058  @complexity Linear in @a cnt.
14059 
14060  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
14061  changes to any JSON value.
14062 
14063  @liveexample{The following code shows examples for the @ref
14064  basic_json(size_type\, const basic_json&)
14065  constructor.,basic_json__size_type_basic_json}
14066 
14067  @since version 1.0.0
14068  */
14069  basic_json(size_type cnt, const basic_json& val)
14070  : m_type(value_t::array)
14071  {
14072  m_value.array = create<array_t>(cnt, val);
14073  assert_invariant();
14074  }
14075 
14076  /*!
14077  @brief construct a JSON container given an iterator range
14078 
14079  Constructs the JSON value with the contents of the range `[first, last)`.
14080  The semantics depends on the different types a JSON value can have:
14081  - In case of a null type, invalid_iterator.206 is thrown.
14082  - In case of other primitive types (number, boolean, or string), @a first
14083  must be `begin()` and @a last must be `end()`. In this case, the value is
14084  copied. Otherwise, invalid_iterator.204 is thrown.
14085  - In case of structured types (array, object), the constructor behaves as
14086  similar versions for `std::vector` or `std::map`; that is, a JSON array
14087  or object is constructed from the values in the range.
14088 
14089  @tparam InputIT an input iterator type (@ref iterator or @ref
14090  const_iterator)
14091 
14092  @param[in] first begin of the range to copy from (included)
14093  @param[in] last end of the range to copy from (excluded)
14094 
14095  @pre Iterators @a first and @a last must be initialized. **This
14096  precondition is enforced with an assertion (see warning).** If
14097  assertions are switched off, a violation of this precondition yields
14098  undefined behavior.
14099 
14100  @pre Range `[first, last)` is valid. Usually, this precondition cannot be
14101  checked efficiently. Only certain edge cases are detected; see the
14102  description of the exceptions below. A violation of this precondition
14103  yields undefined behavior.
14104 
14105  @warning A precondition is enforced with a runtime assertion that will
14106  result in calling `std::abort` if this precondition is not met.
14107  Assertions can be disabled by defining `NDEBUG` at compile time.
14108  See https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/error/assert for more
14109  information.
14110 
14111  @throw invalid_iterator.201 if iterators @a first and @a last are not
14112  compatible (i.e., do not belong to the same JSON value). In this case,
14113  the range `[first, last)` is undefined.
14114  @throw invalid_iterator.204 if iterators @a first and @a last belong to a
14115  primitive type (number, boolean, or string), but @a first does not point
14116  to the first element any more. In this case, the range `[first, last)` is
14117  undefined. See example code below.
14118  @throw invalid_iterator.206 if iterators @a first and @a last belong to a
14119  null value. In this case, the range `[first, last)` is undefined.
14120 
14121  @complexity Linear in distance between @a first and @a last.
14122 
14123  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
14124  changes to any JSON value.
14125 
14126  @liveexample{The example below shows several ways to create JSON values by
14127  specifying a subrange with iterators.,basic_json__InputIt_InputIt}
14128 
14129  @since version 1.0.0
14130  */
14131  template<class InputIT, typename std::enable_if<
14132  std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
14133  std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value, int>::type = 0>
14134  basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last)
14135  {
14136  assert(first.m_object != nullptr);
14137  assert(last.m_object != nullptr);
14138 
14139  // make sure iterator fits the current value
14140  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
14141  {
14142  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(201, "iterators are not compatible"));
14143  }
14144 
14145  // copy type from first iterator
14146  m_type = first.m_object->m_type;
14147 
14148  // check if iterator range is complete for primitive values
14149  switch (m_type)
14150  {
14151  case value_t::boolean:
14152  case value_t::number_float:
14153  case value_t::number_integer:
14154  case value_t::number_unsigned:
14155  case value_t::string:
14156  {
14157  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()
14158  or not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end()))
14159  {
14160  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(204, "iterators out of range"));
14161  }
14162  break;
14163  }
14164 
14165  default:
14166  break;
14167  }
14168 
14169  switch (m_type)
14170  {
14171  case value_t::number_integer:
14172  {
14173  m_value.number_integer = first.m_object->m_value.number_integer;
14174  break;
14175  }
14176 
14177  case value_t::number_unsigned:
14178  {
14179  m_value.number_unsigned = first.m_object->m_value.number_unsigned;
14180  break;
14181  }
14182 
14183  case value_t::number_float:
14184  {
14185  m_value.number_float = first.m_object->m_value.number_float;
14186  break;
14187  }
14188 
14189  case value_t::boolean:
14190  {
14191  m_value.boolean = first.m_object->m_value.boolean;
14192  break;
14193  }
14194 
14195  case value_t::string:
14196  {
14197  m_value = *first.m_object->m_value.string;
14198  break;
14199  }
14200 
14201  case value_t::object:
14202  {
14203  m_value.object = create<object_t>(first.m_it.object_iterator,
14204  last.m_it.object_iterator);
14205  break;
14206  }
14207 
14208  case value_t::array:
14209  {
14210  m_value.array = create<array_t>(first.m_it.array_iterator,
14211  last.m_it.array_iterator);
14212  break;
14213  }
14214 
14215  default:
14216  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(206, "cannot construct with iterators from " +
14217  std::string(first.m_object->type_name())));
14218  }
14219 
14220  assert_invariant();
14221  }
14222 
14223 
14224  ///////////////////////////////////////
14225  // other constructors and destructor //
14226  ///////////////////////////////////////
14227 
14228  /// @private
14229  basic_json(const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& ref)
14230  : basic_json(ref.moved_or_copied())
14231  {}
14232 
14233  /*!
14234  @brief copy constructor
14235 
14236  Creates a copy of a given JSON value.
14237 
14238  @param[in] other the JSON value to copy
14239 
14240  @post `*this == other`
14241 
14242  @complexity Linear in the size of @a other.
14243 
14244  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
14245  changes to any JSON value.
14246 
14247  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
14248  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
14249  requirements:
14250  - The complexity is linear.
14251  - As postcondition, it holds: `other == basic_json(other)`.
14252 
14253  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the copy
14254  constructor.,basic_json__basic_json}
14255 
14256  @since version 1.0.0
14257  */
14258  basic_json(const basic_json& other)
14259  : m_type(other.m_type)
14260  {
14261  // check of passed value is valid
14262  other.assert_invariant();
14263 
14264  switch (m_type)
14265  {
14266  case value_t::object:
14267  {
14268  m_value = *other.m_value.object;
14269  break;
14270  }
14271 
14272  case value_t::array:
14273  {
14274  m_value = *other.m_value.array;
14275  break;
14276  }
14277 
14278  case value_t::string:
14279  {
14280  m_value = *other.m_value.string;
14281  break;
14282  }
14283 
14284  case value_t::boolean:
14285  {
14286  m_value = other.m_value.boolean;
14287  break;
14288  }
14289 
14290  case value_t::number_integer:
14291  {
14292  m_value = other.m_value.number_integer;
14293  break;
14294  }
14295 
14296  case value_t::number_unsigned:
14297  {
14298  m_value = other.m_value.number_unsigned;
14299  break;
14300  }
14301 
14302  case value_t::number_float:
14303  {
14304  m_value = other.m_value.number_float;
14305  break;
14306  }
14307 
14308  default:
14309  break;
14310  }
14311 
14312  assert_invariant();
14313  }
14314 
14315  /*!
14316  @brief move constructor
14317 
14318  Move constructor. Constructs a JSON value with the contents of the given
14319  value @a other using move semantics. It "steals" the resources from @a
14320  other and leaves it as JSON null value.
14321 
14322  @param[in,out] other value to move to this object
14323 
14324  @post `*this` has the same value as @a other before the call.
14325  @post @a other is a JSON null value.
14326 
14327  @complexity Constant.
14328 
14329  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
14330  exceptions.
14331 
14332  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
14333  [MoveConstructible](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/MoveConstructible)
14334  requirements.
14335 
14336  @liveexample{The code below shows the move constructor explicitly called
14337  via std::move.,basic_json__moveconstructor}
14338 
14339  @since version 1.0.0
14340  */
14341  basic_json(basic_json&& other) noexcept
14342  : m_type(std::move(other.m_type)),
14343  m_value(std::move(other.m_value))
14344  {
14345  // check that passed value is valid
14346  other.assert_invariant();
14347 
14348  // invalidate payload
14349  other.m_type = value_t::null;
14350  other.m_value = {};
14351 
14352  assert_invariant();
14353  }
14354 
14355  /*!
14356  @brief copy assignment
14357 
14358  Copy assignment operator. Copies a JSON value via the "copy and swap"
14359  strategy: It is expressed in terms of the copy constructor, destructor,
14360  and the `swap()` member function.
14361 
14362  @param[in] other value to copy from
14363 
14364  @complexity Linear.
14365 
14366  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
14367  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
14368  requirements:
14369  - The complexity is linear.
14370 
14371  @liveexample{The code below shows and example for the copy assignment. It
14372  creates a copy of value `a` which is then swapped with `b`. Finally\, the
14373  copy of `a` (which is the null value after the swap) is
14374  destroyed.,basic_json__copyassignment}
14375 
14376  @since version 1.0.0
14377  */
14378  basic_json& operator=(basic_json other) noexcept (
14379  std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
14380  std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
14381  std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
14382  std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value
14383  )
14384  {
14385  // check that passed value is valid
14386  other.assert_invariant();
14387 
14388  using std::swap;
14389  swap(m_type, other.m_type);
14390  swap(m_value, other.m_value);
14391 
14392  assert_invariant();
14393  return *this;
14394  }
14395 
14396  /*!
14397  @brief destructor
14398 
14399  Destroys the JSON value and frees all allocated memory.
14400 
14401  @complexity Linear.
14402 
14403  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
14404  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
14405  requirements:
14406  - The complexity is linear.
14407  - All stored elements are destroyed and all memory is freed.
14408 
14409  @since version 1.0.0
14410  */
14411  ~basic_json() noexcept
14412  {
14413  assert_invariant();
14414  m_value.destroy(m_type);
14415  }
14416 
14417  /// @}
14418 
14419  public:
14420  ///////////////////////
14421  // object inspection //
14422  ///////////////////////
14423 
14424  /// @name object inspection
14425  /// Functions to inspect the type of a JSON value.
14426  /// @{
14427 
14428  /*!
14429  @brief serialization
14430 
14431  Serialization function for JSON values. The function tries to mimic
14432  Python's `json.dumps()` function, and currently supports its @a indent
14433  and @a ensure_ascii parameters.
14434 
14435  @param[in] indent If indent is nonnegative, then array elements and object
14436  members will be pretty-printed with that indent level. An indent level of
14437  `0` will only insert newlines. `-1` (the default) selects the most compact
14438  representation.
14439  @param[in] indent_char The character to use for indentation if @a indent is
14440  greater than `0`. The default is ` ` (space).
14441  @param[in] ensure_ascii If @a ensure_ascii is true, all non-ASCII characters
14442  in the output are escaped with `\uXXXX` sequences, and the result consists
14443  of ASCII characters only.
14444  @param[in] error_handler how to react on decoding errors; there are three
14445  possible values: `strict` (throws and exception in case a decoding error
14446  occurs; default), `replace` (replace invalid UTF-8 sequences with U+FFFD),
14447  and `ignore` (ignore invalid UTF-8 sequences during serialization).
14448 
14449  @return string containing the serialization of the JSON value
14450 
14451  @throw type_error.316 if a string stored inside the JSON value is not
14452  UTF-8 encoded
14453 
14454  @complexity Linear.
14455 
14456  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
14457  changes in the JSON value.
14458 
14459  @liveexample{The following example shows the effect of different @a indent\,
14460  @a indent_char\, and @a ensure_ascii parameters to the result of the
14461  serialization.,dump}
14462 
14463  @see https://docs.python.org/2/library/json.html#json.dump
14464 
14465  @since version 1.0.0; indentation character @a indent_char, option
14466  @a ensure_ascii and exceptions added in version 3.0.0; error
14467  handlers added in version 3.4.0.
14468  */
14469  string_t dump(const int indent = -1,
14470  const char indent_char = ' ',
14471  const bool ensure_ascii = false,
14472  const error_handler_t error_handler = error_handler_t::strict) const
14473  {
14474  string_t result;
14475  serializer s(detail::output_adapter<char, string_t>(result), indent_char, error_handler);
14476 
14477  if (indent >= 0)
14478  {
14479  s.dump(*this, true, ensure_ascii, static_cast<unsigned int>(indent));
14480  }
14481  else
14482  {
14483  s.dump(*this, false, ensure_ascii, 0);
14484  }
14485 
14486  return result;
14487  }
14488 
14489  /*!
14490  @brief return the type of the JSON value (explicit)
14491 
14492  Return the type of the JSON value as a value from the @ref value_t
14493  enumeration.
14494 
14495  @return the type of the JSON value
14496  Value type | return value
14497  ------------------------- | -------------------------
14498  null | value_t::null
14499  boolean | value_t::boolean
14500  string | value_t::string
14501  number (integer) | value_t::number_integer
14502  number (unsigned integer) | value_t::number_unsigned
14503  number (floating-point) | value_t::number_float
14504  object | value_t::object
14505  array | value_t::array
14506  discarded | value_t::discarded
14507 
14508  @complexity Constant.
14509 
14510  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14511  exceptions.
14512 
14513  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `type()` for all JSON
14514  types.,type}
14515 
14516  @sa @ref operator value_t() -- return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
14517  @sa @ref type_name() -- return the type as string
14518 
14519  @since version 1.0.0
14520  */
14521  constexpr value_t type() const noexcept
14522  {
14523  return m_type;
14524  }
14525 
14526  /*!
14527  @brief return whether type is primitive
14528 
14529  This function returns true if and only if the JSON type is primitive
14530  (string, number, boolean, or null).
14531 
14532  @return `true` if type is primitive (string, number, boolean, or null),
14533  `false` otherwise.
14534 
14535  @complexity Constant.
14536 
14537  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14538  exceptions.
14539 
14540  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_primitive()` for all JSON
14541  types.,is_primitive}
14542 
14543  @sa @ref is_structured() -- returns whether JSON value is structured
14544  @sa @ref is_null() -- returns whether JSON value is `null`
14545  @sa @ref is_string() -- returns whether JSON value is a string
14546  @sa @ref is_boolean() -- returns whether JSON value is a boolean
14547  @sa @ref is_number() -- returns whether JSON value is a number
14548 
14549  @since version 1.0.0
14550  */
14551  constexpr bool is_primitive() const noexcept
14552  {
14553  return is_null() or is_string() or is_boolean() or is_number();
14554  }
14555 
14556  /*!
14557  @brief return whether type is structured
14558 
14559  This function returns true if and only if the JSON type is structured
14560  (array or object).
14561 
14562  @return `true` if type is structured (array or object), `false` otherwise.
14563 
14564  @complexity Constant.
14565 
14566  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14567  exceptions.
14568 
14569  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_structured()` for all JSON
14570  types.,is_structured}
14571 
14572  @sa @ref is_primitive() -- returns whether value is primitive
14573  @sa @ref is_array() -- returns whether value is an array
14574  @sa @ref is_object() -- returns whether value is an object
14575 
14576  @since version 1.0.0
14577  */
14578  constexpr bool is_structured() const noexcept
14579  {
14580  return is_array() or is_object();
14581  }
14582 
14583  /*!
14584  @brief return whether value is null
14585 
14586  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is null.
14587 
14588  @return `true` if type is null, `false` otherwise.
14589 
14590  @complexity Constant.
14591 
14592  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14593  exceptions.
14594 
14595  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_null()` for all JSON
14596  types.,is_null}
14597 
14598  @since version 1.0.0
14599  */
14600  constexpr bool is_null() const noexcept
14601  {
14602  return (m_type == value_t::null);
14603  }
14604 
14605  /*!
14606  @brief return whether value is a boolean
14607 
14608  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a boolean.
14609 
14610  @return `true` if type is boolean, `false` otherwise.
14611 
14612  @complexity Constant.
14613 
14614  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14615  exceptions.
14616 
14617  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_boolean()` for all JSON
14618  types.,is_boolean}
14619 
14620  @since version 1.0.0
14621  */
14622  constexpr bool is_boolean() const noexcept
14623  {
14624  return (m_type == value_t::boolean);
14625  }
14626 
14627  /*!
14628  @brief return whether value is a number
14629 
14630  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a number. This
14631  includes both integer (signed and unsigned) and floating-point values.
14632 
14633  @return `true` if type is number (regardless whether integer, unsigned
14634  integer or floating-type), `false` otherwise.
14635 
14636  @complexity Constant.
14637 
14638  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14639  exceptions.
14640 
14641  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number()` for all JSON
14642  types.,is_number}
14643 
14644  @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer or unsigned
14645  integer number
14646  @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
14647  number
14648  @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
14649 
14650  @since version 1.0.0
14651  */
14652  constexpr bool is_number() const noexcept
14653  {
14654  return is_number_integer() or is_number_float();
14655  }
14656 
14657  /*!
14658  @brief return whether value is an integer number
14659 
14660  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a signed or
14661  unsigned integer number. This excludes floating-point values.
14662 
14663  @return `true` if type is an integer or unsigned integer number, `false`
14664  otherwise.
14665 
14666  @complexity Constant.
14667 
14668  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14669  exceptions.
14670 
14671  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number_integer()` for all
14672  JSON types.,is_number_integer}
14673 
14674  @sa @ref is_number() -- check if value is a number
14675  @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
14676  number
14677  @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
14678 
14679  @since version 1.0.0
14680  */
14681  constexpr bool is_number_integer() const noexcept
14682  {
14683  return (m_type == value_t::number_integer or m_type == value_t::number_unsigned);
14684  }
14685 
14686  /*!
14687  @brief return whether value is an unsigned integer number
14688 
14689  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is an unsigned
14690  integer number. This excludes floating-point and signed integer values.
14691 
14692  @return `true` if type is an unsigned integer number, `false` otherwise.
14693 
14694  @complexity Constant.
14695 
14696  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14697  exceptions.
14698 
14699  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number_unsigned()` for all
14700  JSON types.,is_number_unsigned}
14701 
14702  @sa @ref is_number() -- check if value is a number
14703  @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer or unsigned
14704  integer number
14705  @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
14706 
14707  @since version 2.0.0
14708  */
14709  constexpr bool is_number_unsigned() const noexcept
14710  {
14711  return (m_type == value_t::number_unsigned);
14712  }
14713 
14714  /*!
14715  @brief return whether value is a floating-point number
14716 
14717  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a
14718  floating-point number. This excludes signed and unsigned integer values.
14719 
14720  @return `true` if type is a floating-point number, `false` otherwise.
14721 
14722  @complexity Constant.
14723 
14724  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14725  exceptions.
14726 
14727  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_number_float()` for all
14728  JSON types.,is_number_float}
14729 
14730  @sa @ref is_number() -- check if value is number
14731  @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer number
14732  @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
14733  number
14734 
14735  @since version 1.0.0
14736  */
14737  constexpr bool is_number_float() const noexcept
14738  {
14739  return (m_type == value_t::number_float);
14740  }
14741 
14742  /*!
14743  @brief return whether value is an object
14744 
14745  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is an object.
14746 
14747  @return `true` if type is object, `false` otherwise.
14748 
14749  @complexity Constant.
14750 
14751  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14752  exceptions.
14753 
14754  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_object()` for all JSON
14755  types.,is_object}
14756 
14757  @since version 1.0.0
14758  */
14759  constexpr bool is_object() const noexcept
14760  {
14761  return (m_type == value_t::object);
14762  }
14763 
14764  /*!
14765  @brief return whether value is an array
14766 
14767  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is an array.
14768 
14769  @return `true` if type is array, `false` otherwise.
14770 
14771  @complexity Constant.
14772 
14773  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14774  exceptions.
14775 
14776  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_array()` for all JSON
14777  types.,is_array}
14778 
14779  @since version 1.0.0
14780  */
14781  constexpr bool is_array() const noexcept
14782  {
14783  return (m_type == value_t::array);
14784  }
14785 
14786  /*!
14787  @brief return whether value is a string
14788 
14789  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a string.
14790 
14791  @return `true` if type is string, `false` otherwise.
14792 
14793  @complexity Constant.
14794 
14795  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14796  exceptions.
14797 
14798  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_string()` for all JSON
14799  types.,is_string}
14800 
14801  @since version 1.0.0
14802  */
14803  constexpr bool is_string() const noexcept
14804  {
14805  return (m_type == value_t::string);
14806  }
14807 
14808  /*!
14809  @brief return whether value is discarded
14810 
14811  This function returns true if and only if the JSON value was discarded
14812  during parsing with a callback function (see @ref parser_callback_t).
14813 
14814  @note This function will always be `false` for JSON values after parsing.
14815  That is, discarded values can only occur during parsing, but will be
14816  removed when inside a structured value or replaced by null in other cases.
14817 
14818  @return `true` if type is discarded, `false` otherwise.
14819 
14820  @complexity Constant.
14821 
14822  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14823  exceptions.
14824 
14825  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_discarded()` for all JSON
14826  types.,is_discarded}
14827 
14828  @since version 1.0.0
14829  */
14830  constexpr bool is_discarded() const noexcept
14831  {
14832  return (m_type == value_t::discarded);
14833  }
14834 
14835  /*!
14836  @brief return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
14837 
14838  Implicitly return the type of the JSON value as a value from the @ref
14839  value_t enumeration.
14840 
14841  @return the type of the JSON value
14842 
14843  @complexity Constant.
14844 
14845  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
14846  exceptions.
14847 
14848  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies the @ref value_t operator for
14849  all JSON types.,operator__value_t}
14850 
14851  @sa @ref type() -- return the type of the JSON value (explicit)
14852  @sa @ref type_name() -- return the type as string
14853
