14854  @since version 1.0.0
14855  */
14856  constexpr operator value_t() const noexcept
14857  {
14858  return m_type;
14859  }
14860 
14861  /// @}
14862 
14863  private:
14864  //////////////////
14865  // value access //
14866  //////////////////
14867 
14868  /// get a boolean (explicit)
14869  boolean_t get_impl(boolean_t* /*unused*/) const
14870  {
14871  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_boolean()))
14872  {
14873  return m_value.boolean;
14874  }
14875 
14876  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(302, "type must be boolean, but is " + std::string(type_name())));
14877  }
14878 
14879  /// get a pointer to the value (object)
14880  object_t* get_impl_ptr(object_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14881  {
14882  return is_object() ? m_value.object : nullptr;
14883  }
14884 
14885  /// get a pointer to the value (object)
14886  constexpr const object_t* get_impl_ptr(const object_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14887  {
14888  return is_object() ? m_value.object : nullptr;
14889  }
14890 
14891  /// get a pointer to the value (array)
14892  array_t* get_impl_ptr(array_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14893  {
14894  return is_array() ? m_value.array : nullptr;
14895  }
14896 
14897  /// get a pointer to the value (array)
14898  constexpr const array_t* get_impl_ptr(const array_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14899  {
14900  return is_array() ? m_value.array : nullptr;
14901  }
14902 
14903  /// get a pointer to the value (string)
14904  string_t* get_impl_ptr(string_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14905  {
14906  return is_string() ? m_value.string : nullptr;
14907  }
14908 
14909  /// get a pointer to the value (string)
14910  constexpr const string_t* get_impl_ptr(const string_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14911  {
14912  return is_string() ? m_value.string : nullptr;
14913  }
14914 
14915  /// get a pointer to the value (boolean)
14916  boolean_t* get_impl_ptr(boolean_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14917  {
14918  return is_boolean() ? &m_value.boolean : nullptr;
14919  }
14920 
14921  /// get a pointer to the value (boolean)
14922  constexpr const boolean_t* get_impl_ptr(const boolean_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14923  {
14924  return is_boolean() ? &m_value.boolean : nullptr;
14925  }
14926 
14927  /// get a pointer to the value (integer number)
14928  number_integer_t* get_impl_ptr(number_integer_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14929  {
14930  return is_number_integer() ? &m_value.number_integer : nullptr;
14931  }
14932 
14933  /// get a pointer to the value (integer number)
14934  constexpr const number_integer_t* get_impl_ptr(const number_integer_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14935  {
14936  return is_number_integer() ? &m_value.number_integer : nullptr;
14937  }
14938 
14939  /// get a pointer to the value (unsigned number)
14940  number_unsigned_t* get_impl_ptr(number_unsigned_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14941  {
14942  return is_number_unsigned() ? &m_value.number_unsigned : nullptr;
14943  }
14944 
14945  /// get a pointer to the value (unsigned number)
14946  constexpr const number_unsigned_t* get_impl_ptr(const number_unsigned_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14947  {
14948  return is_number_unsigned() ? &m_value.number_unsigned : nullptr;
14949  }
14950 
14951  /// get a pointer to the value (floating-point number)
14952  number_float_t* get_impl_ptr(number_float_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
14953  {
14954  return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
14955  }
14956 
14957  /// get a pointer to the value (floating-point number)
14958  constexpr const number_float_t* get_impl_ptr(const number_float_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
14959  {
14960  return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
14961  }
14962 
14963  /*!
14964  @brief helper function to implement get_ref()
14965 
14966  This function helps to implement get_ref() without code duplication for
14967  const and non-const overloads
14968 
14969  @tparam ThisType will be deduced as `basic_json` or `const basic_json`
14970 
14971  @throw type_error.303 if ReferenceType does not match underlying value
14972  type of the current JSON
14973  */
14974  template<typename ReferenceType, typename ThisType>
14975  static ReferenceType get_ref_impl(ThisType& obj)
14976  {
14977  // delegate the call to get_ptr<>()
14978  auto ptr = obj.template get_ptr<typename std::add_pointer<ReferenceType>::type>();
14979 
14980  if (JSON_LIKELY(ptr != nullptr))
14981  {
14982  return *ptr;
14983  }
14984 
14985  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(303, "incompatible ReferenceType for get_ref, actual type is " + std::string(obj.type_name())));
14986  }
14987 
14988  public:
14989  /// @name value access
14990  /// Direct access to the stored value of a JSON value.
14991  /// @{
14992 
14993  /*!
14994  @brief get special-case overload
14995 
14996  This overloads avoids a lot of template boilerplate, it can be seen as the
14997  identity method
14998 
14999  @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
15000 
15001  @return a copy of *this
15002 
15003  @complexity Constant.
15004 
15005  @since version 2.1.0
15006  */
15007  template<typename BasicJsonType, detail::enable_if_t<
15008  std::is_same<typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type, basic_json_t>::value,
15009  int> = 0>
15010  basic_json get() const
15011  {
15012  return *this;
15013  }
15014 
15015  /*!
15016  @brief get special-case overload
15017 
15018  This overloads converts the current @ref basic_json in a different
15019  @ref basic_json type
15020 
15021  @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
15022 
15023  @return a copy of *this, converted into @tparam BasicJsonType
15024 
15025  @complexity Depending on the implementation of the called `from_json()`
15026  method.
15027 
15028  @since version 3.2.0
15029  */
15030  template<typename BasicJsonType, detail::enable_if_t<
15031  not std::is_same<BasicJsonType, basic_json>::value and
15032  detail::is_basic_json<BasicJsonType>::value, int> = 0>
15033  BasicJsonType get() const
15034  {
15035  return *this;
15036  }
15037 
15038  /*!
15039  @brief get a value (explicit)
15040 
15041  Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
15042  which is [CopyConstructible](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/CopyConstructible)
15043  and [DefaultConstructible](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/DefaultConstructible).
15044  The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
15045  `from_json()` method.
15046 
15047  The function is equivalent to executing
15048  @code {.cpp}
15049  ValueType ret;
15050  JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
15051  return ret;
15052  @endcode
15053 
15054  This overloads is chosen if:
15055  - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json,
15056  - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
15057  `void from_json(const basic_json&, ValueType&)`, and
15058  - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> does not have a `from_json()` method of
15059  the form `ValueType from_json(const basic_json&)`
15060 
15061  @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
15062  @tparam ValueType the returned value type
15063 
15064  @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
15065 
15066  @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
15067 
15068  @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
15069  to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
15070  be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
15071  `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
15072  associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
15073  json>`.,get__ValueType_const}
15074 
15075  @since version 2.1.0
15076  */
15077  template<typename ValueTypeCV, typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
15078  detail::enable_if_t <
15079  not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value and
15080  detail::has_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
15081  not detail::has_non_default_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
15082  int> = 0>
15083  ValueType get() const noexcept(noexcept(
15084  JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>(), std::declval<ValueType&>())))
15085  {
15086  // we cannot static_assert on ValueTypeCV being non-const, because
15087  // there is support for get<const basic_json_t>(), which is why we
15088  // still need the uncvref
15089  static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
15090  "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might want to use get_ref()");
15091  static_assert(std::is_default_constructible<ValueType>::value,
15092  "types must be DefaultConstructible when used with get()");
15093 
15094  ValueType ret;
15095  JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
15096  return ret;
15097  }
15098 
15099  /*!
15100  @brief get a value (explicit); special case
15101 
15102  Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
15103  which is **not** [CopyConstructible](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/CopyConstructible)
15104  and **not** [DefaultConstructible](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/DefaultConstructible).
15105  The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
15106  `from_json()` method.
15107 
15108  The function is equivalent to executing
15109  @code {.cpp}
15110  return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
15111  @endcode
15112 
15113  This overloads is chosen if:
15114  - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json and
15115  - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
15116  `ValueType from_json(const basic_json&)`
15117 
15118  @note If @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has both overloads of
15119  `from_json()`, this one is chosen.
15120 
15121  @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
15122  @tparam ValueType the returned value type
15123 
15124  @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
15125 
15126  @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
15127 
15128  @since version 2.1.0
15129  */
15130  template<typename ValueTypeCV, typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
15131  detail::enable_if_t<not std::is_same<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
15132  detail::has_non_default_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
15133  int> = 0>
15134  ValueType get() const noexcept(noexcept(
15135  JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>())))
15136  {
15137  static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
15138  "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might want to use get_ref()");
15139  return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
15140  }
15141 
15142  /*!
15143  @brief get a value (explicit)
15144 
15145  Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value.
15146  The value is filled into the input parameter by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
15147  `from_json()` method.
15148 
15149  The function is equivalent to executing
15150  @code {.cpp}
15151  ValueType v;
15152  JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, v);
15153  @endcode
15154 
15155  This overloads is chosen if:
15156  - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json,
15157  - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
15158  `void from_json(const basic_json&, ValueType&)`, and
15159 
15160  @tparam ValueType the input parameter type.
15161 
15162  @return the input parameter, allowing chaining calls.
15163 
15164  @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
15165 
15166  @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
15167  to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
15168  be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
15169  `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
15170  associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
15171  json>`.,get_to}
15172 
15173  @since version 3.3.0
15174  */
15175  template<typename ValueType,
15176  detail::enable_if_t <
15177  not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value and
15178  detail::has_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
15179  int> = 0>
15180  ValueType & get_to(ValueType& v) const noexcept(noexcept(
15181  JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>(), v)))
15182  {
15183  JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, v);
15184  return v;
15185  }
15186 
15187 
15188  /*!
15189  @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
15190 
15191  Implicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
15192  made.
15193 
15194  @warning Writing data to the pointee of the result yields an undefined
15195  state.
15196 
15197  @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
15198  object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
15199  @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t. Enforced by a static
15200  assertion.
15201 
15202  @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
15203  pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
15204 
15205  @complexity Constant.
15206 
15207  @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
15208  JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
15209  `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
15210  match.,get_ptr}
15211 
15212  @since version 1.0.0
15213  */
15214  template<typename PointerType, typename std::enable_if<
15215  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value, int>::type = 0>
15216  auto get_ptr() noexcept -> decltype(std::declval<basic_json_t&>().get_impl_ptr(std::declval<PointerType>()))
15217  {
15218  // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>()
15219  return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<PointerType>(nullptr));
15220  }
15221 
15222  /*!
15223  @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
15224  @copydoc get_ptr()
15225  */
15226  template<typename PointerType, typename std::enable_if<
15227  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value and
15228  std::is_const<typename std::remove_pointer<PointerType>::type>::value, int>::type = 0>
15229  constexpr auto get_ptr() const noexcept -> decltype(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>().get_impl_ptr(std::declval<PointerType>()))
15230  {
15231  // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>() const
15232  return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<PointerType>(nullptr));
15233  }
15234 
15235  /*!
15236  @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
15237 
15238  Explicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
15239  made.
15240 
15241  @warning The pointer becomes invalid if the underlying JSON object
15242  changes.
15243 
15244  @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
15245  object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
15246  @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t.
15247 
15248  @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
15249  pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
15250 
15251  @complexity Constant.
15252 
15253  @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
15254  JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
15255  `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
15256  match.,get__PointerType}
15257 
15258  @sa @ref get_ptr() for explicit pointer-member access
15259 
15260  @since version 1.0.0
15261  */
15262  template<typename PointerType, typename std::enable_if<
15263  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value, int>::type = 0>
15264  auto get() noexcept -> decltype(std::declval<basic_json_t&>().template get_ptr<PointerType>())
15265  {
15266  // delegate the call to get_ptr
15267  return get_ptr<PointerType>();
15268  }
15269 
15270  /*!
15271  @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
15272  @copydoc get()
15273  */
15274  template<typename PointerType, typename std::enable_if<
15275  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value, int>::type = 0>
15276  constexpr auto get() const noexcept -> decltype(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>().template get_ptr<PointerType>())
15277  {
15278  // delegate the call to get_ptr
15279  return get_ptr<PointerType>();
15280  }
15281 
15282  /*!
15283  @brief get a reference value (implicit)
15284 
15285  Implicit reference access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies
15286  are made.
15287 
15288  @warning Writing data to the referee of the result yields an undefined
15289  state.
15290 
15291  @tparam ReferenceType reference type; must be a reference to @ref array_t,
15292  @ref object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t, or
15293  @ref number_float_t. Enforced by static assertion.
15294 
15295  @return reference to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
15296  reference type @a ReferenceType fits to the JSON value; throws
15297  type_error.303 otherwise
15298 
15299  @throw type_error.303 in case passed type @a ReferenceType is incompatible
15300  with the stored JSON value; see example below
15301 
15302  @complexity Constant.
15303 
15304  @liveexample{The example shows several calls to `get_ref()`.,get_ref}
15305 
15306  @since version 1.1.0
15307  */
15308  template<typename ReferenceType, typename std::enable_if<
15309  std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value, int>::type = 0>
15310  ReferenceType get_ref()
15311  {
15312  // delegate call to get_ref_impl
15313  return get_ref_impl<ReferenceType>(*this);
15314  }
15315 
15316  /*!
15317  @brief get a reference value (implicit)
15318  @copydoc get_ref()
15319  */
15320  template<typename ReferenceType, typename std::enable_if<
15321  std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value and
15322  std::is_const<typename std::remove_reference<ReferenceType>::type>::value, int>::type = 0>
15323  ReferenceType get_ref() const
15324  {
15325  // delegate call to get_ref_impl
15326  return get_ref_impl<ReferenceType>(*this);
15327  }
15328 
15329  /*!
15330  @brief get a value (implicit)
15331 
15332  Implicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value.
15333  The call is realized by calling @ref get() const.
15334 
15335  @tparam ValueType non-pointer type compatible to the JSON value, for
15336  instance `int` for JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or
15337  `std::vector` types for JSON arrays. The character type of @ref string_t
15338  as well as an initializer list of this type is excluded to avoid
15339  ambiguities as these types implicitly convert to `std::string`.
15340 
15341  @return copy of the JSON value, converted to type @a ValueType
15342 
15343  @throw type_error.302 in case passed type @a ValueType is incompatible
15344  to the JSON value type (e.g., the JSON value is of type boolean, but a
15345  string is requested); see example below
15346 
15347  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
15348 
15349  @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
15350  to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
15351  be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
15352  `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
15353  associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
15354  json>`.,operator__ValueType}
15355 
15356  @since version 1.0.0
15357  */
15358  template < typename ValueType, typename std::enable_if <
15359  not std::is_pointer<ValueType>::value and
15360  not std::is_same<ValueType, detail::json_ref<basic_json>>::value and
15361  not std::is_same<ValueType, typename string_t::value_type>::value and
15362  not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value
15363 
15364 #ifndef _MSC_VER // fix for issue #167 operator<< ambiguity under VS2015
15365  and not std::is_same<ValueType, std::initializer_list<typename string_t::value_type>>::value
15366 #if defined(JSON_HAS_CPP_17) && defined(_MSC_VER) and _MSC_VER <= 1914
15367  and not std::is_same<ValueType, typename std::string_view>::value
15368 #endif
15369 #endif
15370  and detail::is_detected<detail::get_template_function, const basic_json_t&, ValueType>::value
15371  , int >::type = 0 >
15372  operator ValueType() const
15373  {
15374  // delegate the call to get<>() const
15375  return get<ValueType>();
15376  }
15377 
15378  /// @}
15379 
15380 
15381  ////////////////////
15382  // element access //
15383  ////////////////////
15384 
15385  /// @name element access
15386  /// Access to the JSON value.
15387  /// @{
15388 
15389  /*!
15390  @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
15391 
15392  Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx, with
15393  bounds checking.
15394 
15395  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
15396 
15397  @return reference to the element at index @a idx
15398 
15399  @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an array; in this case,
15400  calling `at` with an index makes no sense. See example below.
15401  @throw out_of_range.401 if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
15402  that is, `idx >= size()`. See example below.
15403 
15404  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
15405  changes in the JSON value.
15406 
15407  @complexity Constant.
15408 
15409  @since version 1.0.0
15410 
15411  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
15412  written using `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that
15413  can be thrown.,at__size_type}
15414  */
15415  reference at(size_type idx)
15416  {
15417  // at only works for arrays
15418  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
15419  {
15420  JSON_TRY
15421  {
15422  return m_value.array->at(idx);
15423  }
15424  JSON_CATCH (std::out_of_range&)
15425  {
15426  // create better exception explanation
15427  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
15428  }
15429  }
15430  else
15431  {
15432  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " + std::string(type_name())));
15433  }
15434  }
15435 
15436  /*!
15437  @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
15438 
15439  Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx,
15440  with bounds checking.
15441 
15442  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
15443 
15444  @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
15445 
15446  @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an array; in this case,
15447  calling `at` with an index makes no sense. See example below.
15448  @throw out_of_range.401 if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
15449  that is, `idx >= size()`. See example below.
15450 
15451  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
15452  changes in the JSON value.
15453 
15454  @complexity Constant.
15455 
15456  @since version 1.0.0
15457 
15458  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
15459  `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that can be thrown.,
15460  at__size_type_const}
15461  */
15462  const_reference at(size_type idx) const
15463  {
15464  // at only works for arrays
15465  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
15466  {
15467  JSON_TRY
15468  {
15469  return m_value.array->at(idx);
15470  }
15471  JSON_CATCH (std::out_of_range&)
15472  {
15473  // create better exception explanation
15474  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
15475  }
15476  }
15477  else
15478  {
15479  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " + std::string(type_name())));
15480  }
15481  }
15482 
15483  /*!
15484  @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
15485 
15486  Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key, with
15487  bounds checking.
15488 
15489  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15490 
15491  @return reference to the element at key @a key
15492 
15493  @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an object; in this case,
15494  calling `at` with a key makes no sense. See example below.
15495  @throw out_of_range.403 if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
15496  that is, `find(key) == end()`. See example below.
15497 
15498  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
15499  changes in the JSON value.
15500 
15501  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15502 
15503  @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
15504  access by reference
15505  @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
15506 
15507  @since version 1.0.0
15508 
15509  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
15510  written using `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that
15511  can be thrown.,at__object_t_key_type}
15512  */
15513  reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
15514  {
15515  // at only works for objects
15516  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15517  {
15518  JSON_TRY
15519  {
15520  return m_value.object->at(key);
15521  }
15522  JSON_CATCH (std::out_of_range&)
15523  {
15524  // create better exception explanation
15525  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + key + "' not found"));
15526  }
15527  }
15528  else
15529  {
15530  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " + std::string(type_name())));
15531  }
15532  }
15533 
15534  /*!
15535  @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
15536 
15537  Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key,
15538  with bounds checking.
15539 
15540  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15541 
15542  @return const reference to the element at key @a key
15543 
15544  @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an object; in this case,
15545  calling `at` with a key makes no sense. See example below.
15546  @throw out_of_range.403 if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
15547  that is, `find(key) == end()`. See example below.
15548 
15549  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
15550  changes in the JSON value.
15551 
15552  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15553 
15554  @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
15555  access by reference
15556  @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
15557 
15558  @since version 1.0.0
15559 
15560  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
15561  `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that can be thrown.,
15562  at__object_t_key_type_const}
15563  */
15564  const_reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key) const
15565  {
15566  // at only works for objects
15567  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15568  {
15569  JSON_TRY
15570  {
15571  return m_value.object->at(key);
15572  }
15573  JSON_CATCH (std::out_of_range&)
15574  {
15575  // create better exception explanation
15576  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + key + "' not found"));
15577  }
15578  }
15579  else
15580  {
15581  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " + std::string(type_name())));
15582  }
15583  }
15584 
15585  /*!
15586  @brief access specified array element
15587 
15588  Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
15589 
15590  @note If @a idx is beyond the range of the array (i.e., `idx >= size()`),
15591  then the array is silently filled up with `null` values to make `idx` a
15592  valid reference to the last stored element.
15593 
15594  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
15595 
15596  @return reference to the element at index @a idx
15597 
15598  @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an array or null; in that
15599  cases, using the [] operator with an index makes no sense.
15600 
15601  @complexity Constant if @a idx is in the range of the array. Otherwise
15602  linear in `idx - size()`.
15603 
15604  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
15605  written using `[]` operator. Note the addition of `null`
15606  values.,operatorarray__size_type}
15607 
15608  @since version 1.0.0
15609  */
15610  reference operator[](size_type idx)
15611  {
15612  // implicitly convert null value to an empty array
15613  if (is_null())
15614  {
15615  m_type = value_t::array;
15616  m_value.array = create<array_t>();
15617  assert_invariant();
15618  }
15619 
15620  // operator[] only works for arrays
15621  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
15622  {
15623  // fill up array with null values if given idx is outside range
15624  if (idx >= m_value.array->size())
15625  {
15626  m_value.array->insert(m_value.array->end(),
15627  idx - m_value.array->size() + 1,
15628  basic_json());
15629  }
15630 
15631  return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
15632  }
15633 
15634  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with a numeric argument with " + std::string(type_name())));
15635  }
15636 
15637  /*!
15638  @brief access specified array element
15639 
15640  Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
15641 
15642  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
15643 
15644  @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
15645 
15646  @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an array; in that case,
15647  using the [] operator with an index makes no sense.
15648 
15649  @complexity Constant.
15650 
15651  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
15652  the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__size_type_const}
15653 
15654  @since version 1.0.0
15655  */
15656  const_reference operator[](size_type idx) const
15657  {
15658  // const operator[] only works for arrays
15659  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
15660  {
15661  return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
15662  }
15663 
15664  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with a numeric argument with " + std::string(type_name())));
15665  }
15666 
15667  /*!
15668  @brief access specified object element
15669 
15670  Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
15671 
15672  @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
15673  the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
15674  In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
15675 
15676  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15677 
15678  @return reference to the element at key @a key
15679 
15680  @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object or null; in that
15681  cases, using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
15682 
15683  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15684 
15685  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
15686  written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
15687 
15688  @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
15689  with range checking
15690  @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
15691 
15692  @since version 1.0.0
15693  */
15694  reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key)
15695  {
15696  // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
15697  if (is_null())
15698  {
15699  m_type = value_t::object;
15700  m_value.object = create<object_t>();
15701  assert_invariant();
15702  }
15703 
15704  // operator[] only works for objects
15705  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15706  {
15707  return m_value.object->operator[](key);
15708  }
15709 
15710  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with a string argument with " + std::string(type_name())));
15711  }
15712 
15713  /*!
15714  @brief read-only access specified object element
15715 
15716  Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key. No
15717  bounds checking is performed.
15718 
15719  @warning If the element with key @a key does not exist, the behavior is
15720  undefined.
15721 
15722  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15723 
15724  @return const reference to the element at key @a key
15725 
15726  @pre The element with key @a key must exist. **This precondition is
15727  enforced with an assertion.**
15728 
15729  @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
15730  using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
15731 
15732  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15733 
15734  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
15735  the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}
15736 
15737  @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
15738  with range checking
15739  @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
15740 
15741  @since version 1.0.0
15742  */
15743  const_reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key) const
15744  {
15745  // const operator[] only works for objects
15746  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15747  {
15748  assert(m_value.object->find(key) != m_value.object->end());
15749  return m_value.object->find(key)->second;
15750  }
15751 
15752  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with a string argument with " + std::string(type_name())));
15753  }
15754 
15755  /*!
15756  @brief access specified object element
15757 
15758  Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
15759 
15760  @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
15761  the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
15762  In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
15763 
15764  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15765 
15766  @return reference to the element at key @a key
15767 
15768  @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object or null; in that
15769  cases, using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
15770 
15771  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15772 
15773  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
15774  written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
15775 
15776  @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
15777  with range checking
15778  @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
15779 
15780  @since version 1.1.0
15781  */
15782  template<typename T>
15783  reference operator[](T* key)
15784  {
15785  // implicitly convert null to object
15786  if (is_null())
15787  {
15788  m_type = value_t::object;
15789  m_value = value_t::object;
15790  assert_invariant();
15791  }
15792 
15793  // at only works for objects
15794  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15795  {
15796  return m_value.object->operator[](key);
15797  }
15798 
15799  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with a string argument with " + std::string(type_name())));
15800  }
15801 
15802  /*!
15803  @brief read-only access specified object element
15804 
15805  Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key. No
15806  bounds checking is performed.
15807 
15808  @warning If the element with key @a key does not exist, the behavior is
15809  undefined.
15810 
15811  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15812 
15813  @return const reference to the element at key @a key
15814 
15815  @pre The element with key @a key must exist. **This precondition is
15816  enforced with an assertion.**
15817 
15818  @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
15819  using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
15820 
15821  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15822 
15823  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
15824  the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}
15825 
15826  @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
15827  with range checking
15828  @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
15829 
15830  @since version 1.1.0
15831  */
15832  template<typename T>
15833  const_reference operator[](T* key) const
15834  {
15835  // at only works for objects
15836  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15837  {
15838  assert(m_value.object->find(key) != m_value.object->end());
15839  return m_value.object->find(key)->second;
15840  }
15841 
15842  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with a string argument with " + std::string(type_name())));
15843  }
15844 
15845  /*!
15846  @brief access specified object element with default value
15847 
15848  Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
15849  or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
15850 
15851  The function is basically equivalent to executing
15852  @code {.cpp}
15853  try {
15854  return at(key);
15855  } catch(out_of_range) {
15856  return default_value;
15857  }
15858  @endcode
15859 
15860  @note Unlike @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&), this function
15861  does not throw if the given key @a key was not found.
15862 
15863  @note Unlike @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key), this
15864  function does not implicitly add an element to the position defined by @a
15865  key. This function is furthermore also applicable to const objects.
15866 
15867  @param[in] key key of the element to access
15868  @param[in] default_value the value to return if @a key is not found
15869 
15870  @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
15871  JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
15872  JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
15873  value @a default_value must be compatible.
15874 
15875  @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
15876  is not found
15877 
15878  @throw type_error.306 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
15879  using `value()` with a key makes no sense.
15880 
15881  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15882 
15883  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
15884  with a default value.,basic_json__value}
15885 
15886  @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
15887  with range checking
15888  @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
15889  access by reference
15890 
15891  @since version 1.0.0
15892  */
15893  template<class ValueType, typename std::enable_if<
15894  std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
15895  ValueType value(const typename object_t::key_type& key, const ValueType& default_value) const
15896  {
15897  // at only works for objects
15898  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15899  {
15900  // if key is found, return value and given default value otherwise
15901  const auto it = find(key);
15902  if (it != end())
15903  {
15904  return *it;
15905  }
15906 
15907  return default_value;
15908  }
15909 
15910  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(306, "cannot use value() with " + std::string(type_name())));
15911  }
15912 
15913  /*!
15914  @brief overload for a default value of type const char*
15915  @copydoc basic_json::value(const typename object_t::key_type&, const ValueType&) const
15916  */
15917  string_t value(const typename object_t::key_type& key, const char* default_value) const
15918  {
15919  return value(key, string_t(default_value));
15920  }
15921 
15922  /*!
15923  @brief access specified object element via JSON Pointer with default value
15924 
15925  Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
15926  or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
15927 
15928  The function is basically equivalent to executing
15929  @code {.cpp}
15930  try {
15931  return at(ptr);
15932  } catch(out_of_range) {
15933  return default_value;
15934  }
15935  @endcode
15936 
15937  @note Unlike @ref at(const json_pointer&), this function does not throw
15938  if the given key @a key was not found.
15939 
15940  @param[in] ptr a JSON pointer to the element to access
15941  @param[in] default_value the value to return if @a ptr found no value
15942 
15943  @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
15944  JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
15945  JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
15946  value @a default_value must be compatible.
15947 
15948  @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
15949  is not found
15950 
15951  @throw type_error.306 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
15952  using `value()` with a key makes no sense.
15953 
15954  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
15955 
15956  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
15957  with a default value.,basic_json__value_ptr}
15958 
15959  @sa @ref operator[](const json_pointer&) for unchecked access by reference
15960 
15961  @since version 2.0.2
15962  */
15963  template<class ValueType, typename std::enable_if<
15964  std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
15965  ValueType value(const json_pointer& ptr, const ValueType& default_value) const
15966  {
15967  // at only works for objects
15968  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
15969  {
15970  // if pointer resolves a value, return it or use default value
15971  JSON_TRY
15972  {
15973  return ptr.get_checked(this);
15974  }
15975  JSON_INTERNAL_CATCH (out_of_range&)
15976  {
15977  return default_value;
15978  }
15979  }
15980 
15981  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(306, "cannot use value() with " + std::string(type_name())));
15982  }
15983 
15984  /*!
15985  @brief overload for a default value of type const char*
15986  @copydoc basic_json::value(const json_pointer&, ValueType) const
15987  */
15988  string_t value(const json_pointer& ptr, const char* default_value) const
15989  {
15990  return value(ptr, string_t(default_value));
15991  }
15992 
15993  /*!
15994  @brief access the first element
15995 
15996  Returns a reference to the first element in the container. For a JSON
15997  container `c`, the expression `c.front()` is equivalent to `*c.begin()`.
15998 
15999  @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
16000  first element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
16001  reference to the value is returned.
16002 
16003  @complexity Constant.
16004 
16005  @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
16006  or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
16007  assertions**).
16008  @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
16009 
16010  @throw invalid_iterator.214 when called on `null` value
16011 
16012  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `front()`.,front}
16013 
16014  @sa @ref back() -- access the last element
16015 
16016  @since version 1.0.0
16017  */
16018  reference front()
16019  {
16020  return *begin();
16021  }
16022 
16023  /*!
16024  @copydoc basic_json::front()
16025  */
16026  const_reference front() const
16027  {
16028  return *cbegin();
16029  }
16030 
16031  /*!
16032  @brief access the last element
16033 
16034  Returns a reference to the last element in the container. For a JSON
16035  container `c`, the expression `c.back()` is equivalent to
16036  @code {.cpp}
16037  auto tmp = c.end();
16038  --tmp;
16039  return *tmp;
16040  @endcode
16041 
16042  @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
16043  last element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
16044  reference to the value is returned.
16045 
16046  @complexity Constant.
16047 
16048  @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
16049  or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
16050  assertions**).
16051  @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
16052 
16053  @throw invalid_iterator.214 when called on a `null` value. See example
16054  below.
16055 
16056  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `back()`.,back}
16057 
16058  @sa @ref front() -- access the first element
16059 
16060  @since version 1.0.0
16061  */
16062  reference back()
16063  {
16064  auto tmp = end();
16065  --tmp;
16066  return *tmp;
16067  }
16068 
16069  /*!
16070  @copydoc basic_json::back()
16071  */
16072  const_reference back() const
16073  {
16074  auto tmp = cend();
16075  --tmp;
16076  return *tmp;
16077  }
16078 
16079  /*!
16080  @brief remove element given an iterator
16081 
16082  Removes the element specified by iterator @a pos. The iterator @a pos must
16083  be valid and dereferenceable. Thus the `end()` iterator (which is valid,
16084  but is not dereferenceable) cannot be used as a value for @a pos.
16085 
16086  If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
16087  will be `null`.
16088 
16089  @param[in] pos iterator to the element to remove
16090  @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
16091  pos refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
16092 
16093  @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
16094 
16095  @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
16096  erase, including the `end()` iterator.
16097 
16098  @throw type_error.307 if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot use
16099  erase() with null"`
16100  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if called on an iterator which does not belong
16101  to the current JSON value; example: `"iterator does not fit current
16102  value"`
16103  @throw invalid_iterator.205 if called on a primitive type with invalid
16104  iterator (i.e., any iterator which is not `begin()`); example: `"iterator
16105  out of range"`
16106 
16107  @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
16108  - objects: amortized constant
16109  - arrays: linear in distance between @a pos and the end of the container
16110  - strings: linear in the length of the string
16111  - other types: constant
16112 
16113  @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
16114  types.,erase__IteratorType}
16115 
16116  @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
16117  the given range
16118  @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
16119  from an object at the given key
16120  @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
16121  the given index
16122 
16123  @since version 1.0.0
16124  */
16125  template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
16126  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
16127  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value, int>::type
16128  = 0>
16129  IteratorType erase(IteratorType pos)
16130  {
16131  // make sure iterator fits the current value
16132  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(this != pos.m_object))
16133  {
16134  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
16135  }
16136 
16137  IteratorType result = end();
16138 
16139  switch (m_type)
16140  {
16141  case value_t::boolean:
16142  case value_t::number_float:
16143  case value_t::number_integer:
16144  case value_t::number_unsigned:
16145  case value_t::string:
16146  {
16147  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not pos.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()))
16148  {
16149  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(205, "iterator out of range"));
16150  }
16151 
16152  if (is_string())
16153  {
16154  AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
16155  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, m_value.string);
16156  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, m_value.string, 1);
16157  m_value.string = nullptr;
16158  }
16159 
16160  m_type = value_t::null;
16161  assert_invariant();
16162  break;
16163  }
16164 
16165  case value_t::object:
16166  {
16167  result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->erase(pos.m_it.object_iterator);
16168  break;
16169  }
16170 
16171  case value_t::array:
16172  {
16173  result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->erase(pos.m_it.array_iterator);
16174  break;
16175  }
16176 
16177  default:
16178  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
16179  }
16180 
16181  return result;
16182  }
16183 
16184  /*!
16185  @brief remove elements given an iterator range
16186 
16187  Removes the element specified by the range `[first; last)`. The iterator
16188  @a first does not need to be dereferenceable if `first == last`: erasing
16189  an empty range is a no-op.
16190 
16191  If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
16192  will be `null`.
16193 
16194  @param[in] first iterator to the beginning of the range to remove
16195  @param[in] last iterator past the end of the range to remove
16196  @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
16197  second refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
16198 
16199  @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
16200 
16201  @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
16202  erase, including the `end()` iterator.
16203 
16204  @throw type_error.307 if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot use
16205  erase() with null"`
16206  @throw invalid_iterator.203 if called on iterators which does not belong
16207  to the current JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit current value"`
16208  @throw invalid_iterator.204 if called on a primitive type with invalid
16209  iterators (i.e., if `first != begin()` and `last != end()`); example:
16210  `"iterators out of range"`
16211 
16212  @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
16213  - objects: `log(size()) + std::distance(first, last)`
16214  - arrays: linear in the distance between @a first and @a last, plus linear
16215  in the distance between @a last and end of the container
16216  - strings: linear in the length of the string
16217  - other types: constant
16218 
16219  @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
16220  types.,erase__IteratorType_IteratorType}
16221 
16222  @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
16223  @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
16224  from an object at the given key
16225  @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
16226  the given index
16227 
16228  @since version 1.0.0
16229  */
16230  template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
16231  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
16232  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value, int>::type
16233  = 0>
16234  IteratorType erase(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
16235  {
16236  // make sure iterator fits the current value
16237  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(this != first.m_object or this != last.m_object))
16238  {
16239  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(203, "iterators do not fit current value"));
16240  }
16241 
16242  IteratorType result = end();
16243 
16244  switch (m_type)
16245  {
16246  case value_t::boolean:
16247  case value_t::number_float:
16248  case value_t::number_integer:
16249  case value_t::number_unsigned:
16250  case value_t::string:
16251  {
16252  if (JSON_LIKELY(not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()
16253  or not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end()))
16254  {
16255  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(204, "iterators out of range"));
16256  }
16257 
16258  if (is_string())
16259  {
16260  AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
16261  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, m_value.string);
16262  std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, m_value.string, 1);
16263  m_value.string = nullptr;
16264  }
16265 
16266  m_type = value_t::null;
16267  assert_invariant();
16268  break;
16269  }
16270 
16271  case value_t::object:
16272  {
16273  result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->erase(first.m_it.object_iterator,
16274  last.m_it.object_iterator);
16275  break;
16276  }
16277 
16278  case value_t::array:
16279  {
16280  result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->erase(first.m_it.array_iterator,
16281  last.m_it.array_iterator);
16282  break;
16283  }
16284 
16285  default:
16286  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
16287  }
16288 
16289  return result;
16290  }
16291 
16292  /*!
16293  @brief remove element from a JSON object given a key
16294 
16295  Removes elements from a JSON object with the key value @a key.
16296 
16297  @param[in] key value of the elements to remove
16298 
16299  @return Number of elements removed. If @a ObjectType is the default
16300  `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was not
16301  found) or `1` (@a key was found).
16302 
16303  @post References and iterators to the erased elements are invalidated.
16304  Other references and iterators are not affected.
16305 
16306  @throw type_error.307 when called on a type other than JSON object;
16307  example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
16308 
16309  @complexity `log(size()) + count(key)`
16310 
16311  @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__key_type}
16312 
16313  @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
16314  @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
16315  the given range
16316  @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
16317  the given index
16318 
16319  @since version 1.0.0
16320  */
16321  size_type erase(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
16322  {
16323  // this erase only works for objects
16324  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
16325  {
16326  return m_value.object->erase(key);
16327  }
16328 
16329  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
16330  }
16331 
16332  /*!
16333  @brief remove element from a JSON array given an index
16334 
16335  Removes element from a JSON array at the index @a idx.
16336 
16337  @param[in] idx index of the element to remove
16338 
16339  @throw type_error.307 when called on a type other than JSON object;
16340  example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
16341  @throw out_of_range.401 when `idx >= size()`; example: `"array index 17
16342  is out of range"`
16343 
16344  @complexity Linear in distance between @a idx and the end of the container.
16345 
16346  @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__size_type}
16347 
16348  @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
16349  @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
16350  the given range
16351  @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
16352  from an object at the given key
16353 
16354  @since version 1.0.0
16355  */
16356  void erase(const size_type idx)
16357  {
16358  // this erase only works for arrays
16359  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
16360  {
16361  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(idx >= size()))
16362  {
16363  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
16364  }
16365 
16366  m_value.array->erase(m_value.array->begin() + static_cast<difference_type>(idx));
16367  }
16368  else
16369  {
16370  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
16371  }
16372  }
16373 
16374  /// @}
16375 
16376 
16377  ////////////
16378  // lookup //
16379  ////////////
16380 
16381  /// @name lookup
16382  /// @{
16383 
16384  /*!
16385  @brief find an element in a JSON object
16386 
16387  Finds an element in a JSON object with key equivalent to @a key. If the
16388  element is not found or the JSON value is not an object, end() is
16389  returned.
16390 
16391  @note This method always returns @ref end() when executed on a JSON type
16392  that is not an object.
16393 
16394  @param[in] key key value of the element to search for.
16395 
16396  @return Iterator to an element with key equivalent to @a key. If no such
16397  element is found or the JSON value is not an object, past-the-end (see
16398  @ref end()) iterator is returned.
16399 
16400  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
16401 
16402  @liveexample{The example shows how `find()` is used.,find__key_type}
16403 
16404  @since version 1.0.0
16405  */
16406  template<typename KeyT>
16407  iterator find(KeyT&& key)
16408  {
16409  auto result = end();
16410 
16411  if (is_object())
16412  {
16413  result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->find(std::forward<KeyT>(key));
16414  }
16415 
16416  return result;
16417  }
16418 
16419  /*!
16420  @brief find an element in a JSON object
16421  @copydoc find(KeyT&&)
16422  */
16423  template<typename KeyT>
16424  const_iterator find(KeyT&& key) const
16425  {
16426  auto result = cend();
16427 
16428  if (is_object())
16429  {
16430  result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->find(std::forward<KeyT>(key));
16431  }
16432 
16433  return result;
16434  }
16435 
16436  /*!
16437  @brief returns the number of occurrences of a key in a JSON object
16438 
16439  Returns the number of elements with key @a key. If ObjectType is the
16440  default `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was
16441  not found) or `1` (@a key was found).
16442 
16443  @note This method always returns `0` when executed on a JSON type that is
16444  not an object.
16445 
16446  @param[in] key key value of the element to count
16447 
16448  @return Number of elements with key @a key. If the JSON value is not an
16449  object, the return value will be `0`.
16450 
16451  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
16452 
16453  @liveexample{The example shows how `count()` is used.,count}
16454 
16455  @since version 1.0.0
16456  */
16457  template<typename KeyT>
16458  size_type count(KeyT&& key) const
16459  {
16460  // return 0 for all nonobject types
16461  return is_object() ? m_value.object->count(std::forward<KeyT>(key)) : 0;
16462  }
16463 
16464  /// @}
16465 
16466 
16467  ///////////////
16468  // iterators //
16469  ///////////////
16470 
16471  /// @name iterators
16472  /// @{
16473 
16474  /*!
16475  @brief returns an iterator to the first element
16476 
16477  Returns an iterator to the first element.
16478 
16479  @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16480 
16481  @return iterator to the first element
16482 
16483  @complexity Constant.
16484 
16485  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16486  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
16487  requirements:
16488  - The complexity is constant.
16489 
16490  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `begin()`.,begin}
16491 
16492  @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
16493  @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
16494  @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
16495 
16496  @since version 1.0.0
16497  */
16498  iterator begin() noexcept
16499  {
16500  iterator result(this);
16501  result.set_begin();
16502  return result;
16503  }
16504 
16505  /*!
16506  @copydoc basic_json::cbegin()
16507  */
16508  const_iterator begin() const noexcept
16509  {
16510  return cbegin();
16511  }
16512 
16513  /*!
16514  @brief returns a const iterator to the first element
16515 
16516  Returns a const iterator to the first element.
16517 
16518  @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16519 
16520  @return const iterator to the first element
16521 
16522  @complexity Constant.
16523 
16524  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16525  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
16526  requirements:
16527  - The complexity is constant.
16528  - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).begin()`.
16529 
16530  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `cbegin()`.,cbegin}
16531 
16532  @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
16533  @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
16534  @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
16535 
16536  @since version 1.0.0
16537  */
16538  const_iterator cbegin() const noexcept
16539  {
16540  const_iterator result(this);
16541  result.set_begin();
16542  return result;
16543  }
16544 
16545  /*!
16546  @brief returns an iterator to one past the last element
16547 
16548  Returns an iterator to one past the last element.
16549 
16550  @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16551 
16552  @return iterator one past the last element
16553 
16554  @complexity Constant.
16555 
16556  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16557  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
16558  requirements:
16559  - The complexity is constant.
16560 
16561  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `end()`.,end}
16562 
16563  @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
16564  @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
16565  @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
16566 
16567  @since version 1.0.0
16568  */
16569  iterator end() noexcept
16570  {
16571  iterator result(this);
16572  result.set_end();
16573  return result;
16574  }
16575 
16576  /*!
16577  @copydoc basic_json::cend()
16578  */
16579  const_iterator end() const noexcept
16580  {
16581  return cend();
16582  }
16583 
16584  /*!
16585  @brief returns a const iterator to one past the last element
16586 
16587  Returns a const iterator to one past the last element.
16588 
16589  @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16590 
16591  @return const iterator one past the last element
16592 
16593  @complexity Constant.
16594 
16595  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16596  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
16597  requirements:
16598  - The complexity is constant.
16599  - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).end()`.
16600 
16601  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `cend()`.,cend}
16602 
16603  @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
16604  @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
16605  @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
16606 
16607  @since version 1.0.0
16608  */
16609  const_iterator cend() const noexcept
16610  {
16611  const_iterator result(this);
16612  result.set_end();
16613  return result;
16614  }
16615 
16616  /*!
16617  @brief returns an iterator to the reverse-beginning
16618 
16619  Returns an iterator to the reverse-beginning; that is, the last element.
16620 
16621  @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16622 
16623  @complexity Constant.
16624 
16625  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16626  [ReversibleContainer](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/ReversibleContainer)
16627  requirements:
16628  - The complexity is constant.
16629  - Has the semantics of `reverse_iterator(end())`.
16630 
16631  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `rbegin()`.,rbegin}
16632 
16633  @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
16634  @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
16635  @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
16636 
16637  @since version 1.0.0
16638  */
16639  reverse_iterator rbegin() noexcept
16640  {
16641  return reverse_iterator(end());
16642  }
16643 
16644  /*!
16645  @copydoc basic_json::crbegin()
16646  */
16647  const_reverse_iterator rbegin() const noexcept
16648  {
16649  return crbegin();
16650  }
16651 
16652  /*!
16653  @brief returns an iterator to the reverse-end
16654 
16655  Returns an iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before the first
16656  element.
16657 
16658  @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16659 
16660  @complexity Constant.
16661 
16662  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16663  [ReversibleContainer](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/ReversibleContainer)
16664  requirements:
16665  - The complexity is constant.
16666  - Has the semantics of `reverse_iterator(begin())`.
16667 
16668  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `rend()`.,rend}
16669 
16670  @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
16671  @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
16672  @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
16673 
16674  @since version 1.0.0
16675  */
16676  reverse_iterator rend() noexcept
16677  {
16678  return reverse_iterator(begin());
16679  }
16680 
16681  /*!
16682  @copydoc basic_json::crend()
16683  */
16684  const_reverse_iterator rend() const noexcept
16685  {
16686  return crend();
16687  }
16688 
16689  /*!
16690  @brief returns a const reverse iterator to the last element
16691 
16692  Returns a const iterator to the reverse-beginning; that is, the last
16693  element.
16694 
16695  @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16696 
16697  @complexity Constant.
16698 
16699  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16700  [ReversibleContainer](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/ReversibleContainer)
16701  requirements:
16702  - The complexity is constant.
16703  - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rbegin()`.
16704 
16705  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crbegin()`.,crbegin}
16706 
16707  @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
16708  @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
16709  @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
16710 
16711  @since version 1.0.0
16712  */
16713  const_reverse_iterator crbegin() const noexcept
16714  {
16715  return const_reverse_iterator(cend());
16716  }
16717 
16718  /*!
16719  @brief returns a const reverse iterator to one before the first
16720 
16721  Returns a const reverse iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before
16722  the first element.
16723 
16724  @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
16725 
16726  @complexity Constant.
16727 
16728  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16729  [ReversibleContainer](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/ReversibleContainer)
16730  requirements:
16731  - The complexity is constant.
16732  - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rend()`.
16733 
16734  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crend()`.,crend}
16735 
16736  @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
16737  @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
16738  @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
16739 
16740  @since version 1.0.0
16741  */
16742  const_reverse_iterator crend() const noexcept
16743  {
16744  return const_reverse_iterator(cbegin());
16745  }
16746 
16747  public:
16748  /*!
16749  @brief wrapper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
16750 
16751  This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
16752  iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
16753  reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
16754  underlying iterator.
16755 
16756  For loop without iterator_wrapper:
16757 
16758  @code{cpp}
16759  for (auto it = j_object.begin(); it != j_object.end(); ++it)
16760  {
16761  std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
16762  }
16763  @endcode
16764 
16765  Range-based for loop without iterator proxy:
16766 
16767  @code{cpp}
16768  for (auto it : j_object)
16769  {
16770  // "it" is of type json::reference and has no key() member
16771  std::cout << "value: " << it << '\n';
16772  }
16773  @endcode
16774 
16775  Range-based for loop with iterator proxy:
16776 
16777  @code{cpp}
16778  for (auto it : json::iterator_wrapper(j_object))
16779  {
16780  std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
16781  }
16782  @endcode
16783 
16784  @note When iterating over an array, `key()` will return the index of the
16785  element as string (see example).
16786 
16787  @param[in] ref reference to a JSON value
16788  @return iteration proxy object wrapping @a ref with an interface to use in
16789  range-based for loops
16790 
16791  @liveexample{The following code shows how the wrapper is used,iterator_wrapper}
16792 
16793  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
16794  changes in the JSON value.
16795 
16796  @complexity Constant.
16797 
16798  @note The name of this function is not yet final and may change in the
16799  future.
16800 
16801  @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
16802  future 4.0.0 of the library. Please use @ref items() instead;
16803  that is, replace `json::iterator_wrapper(j)` with `j.items()`.
16804  */
16805  JSON_DEPRECATED
16806  static iteration_proxy<iterator> iterator_wrapper(reference ref) noexcept
16807  {
16808  return ref.items();
16809  }
16810 
16811  /*!
16812  @copydoc iterator_wrapper(reference)
16813  */
16814  JSON_DEPRECATED
16815  static iteration_proxy<const_iterator> iterator_wrapper(const_reference ref) noexcept
16816  {
16817  return ref.items();
16818  }
16819 
16820  /*!
16821  @brief helper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
16822 
16823  This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
16824  iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
16825  reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
16826  underlying iterator.
16827 
16828  For loop without `items()` function:
16829 
16830  @code{cpp}
16831  for (auto it = j_object.begin(); it != j_object.end(); ++it)
16832  {
16833  std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
16834  }
16835  @endcode
16836 
16837  Range-based for loop without `items()` function:
16838 
16839  @code{cpp}
16840  for (auto it : j_object)
16841  {
16842  // "it" is of type json::reference and has no key() member
16843  std::cout << "value: " << it << '\n';
16844  }
16845  @endcode
16846 
16847  Range-based for loop with `items()` function:
16848 
16849  @code{cpp}
16850  for (auto& el : j_object.items())
16851  {
16852  std::cout << "key: " << el.key() << ", value:" << el.value() << '\n';
16853  }
16854  @endcode
16855 
16856  The `items()` function also allows to use
16857  [structured bindings](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/structured_binding)
16858  (C++17):
16859 
16860  @code{cpp}
16861  for (auto& [key, val] : j_object.items())
16862  {
16863  std::cout << "key: " << key << ", value:" << val << '\n';
16864  }
16865  @endcode
16866 
16867  @note When iterating over an array, `key()` will return the index of the
16868  element as string (see example). For primitive types (e.g., numbers),
16869  `key()` returns an empty string.
16870 
16871  @return iteration proxy object wrapping @a ref with an interface to use in
16872  range-based for loops
16873 
16874  @liveexample{The following code shows how the function is used.,items}
16875 
16876  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
16877  changes in the JSON value.
16878 
16879  @complexity Constant.
16880 
16881  @since version 3.1.0, structured bindings support since 3.5.0.
16882  */
16883  iteration_proxy<iterator> items() noexcept
16884  {
16885  return iteration_proxy<iterator>(*this);
16886  }
16887 
16888  /*!
16889  @copydoc items()
16890  */
16891  iteration_proxy<const_iterator> items() const noexcept
16892  {
16893  return iteration_proxy<const_iterator>(*this);
16894  }
16895 
16896  /// @}
16897 
16898 
16899  //////////////
16900  // capacity //
16901  //////////////
16902 
16903  /// @name capacity
16904  /// @{
16905 
16906  /*!
16907  @brief checks whether the container is empty.
16908 
16909  Checks if a JSON value has no elements (i.e. whether its @ref size is `0`).
16910 
16911  @return The return value depends on the different types and is
16912  defined as follows:
16913  Value type | return value
16914  ----------- | -------------
16915  null | `true`
16916  boolean | `false`
16917  string | `false`
16918  number | `false`
16919  object | result of function `object_t::empty()`
16920  array | result of function `array_t::empty()`
16921 
16922  @liveexample{The following code uses `empty()` to check if a JSON
16923  object contains any elements.,empty}
16924 
16925  @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
16926  the Container concept; that is, their `empty()` functions have constant
16927  complexity.
16928 
16929  @iterators No changes.
16930 
16931  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
16932 
16933  @note This function does not return whether a string stored as JSON value
16934  is empty - it returns whether the JSON container itself is empty which is
16935  false in the case of a string.
16936 
16937  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
16938  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
16939  requirements:
16940  - The complexity is constant.
16941  - Has the semantics of `begin() == end()`.
16942 
16943  @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
16944 
16945  @since version 1.0.0
16946  */
16947  bool empty() const noexcept
16948  {
16949  switch (m_type)
16950  {
16951  case value_t::null:
16952  {
16953  // null values are empty
16954  return true;
16955  }
16956 
16957  case value_t::array:
16958  {
16959  // delegate call to array_t::empty()
16960  return m_value.array->empty();
16961  }
16962 
16963  case value_t::object:
16964  {
16965  // delegate call to object_t::empty()
16966  return m_value.object->empty();
16967  }
16968 
16969  default:
16970  {
16971  // all other types are nonempty
16972  return false;
16973  }
16974  }
16975  }
16976 
16977  /*!
16978  @brief returns the number of elements
16979 
16980  Returns the number of elements in a JSON value.
16981 
16982  @return The return value depends on the different types and is
16983  defined as follows:
16984  Value type | return value
16985  ----------- | -------------
16986  null | `0`
16987  boolean | `1`
16988  string | `1`
16989  number | `1`
16990  object | result of function object_t::size()
16991  array | result of function array_t::size()
16992 
16993  @liveexample{The following code calls `size()` on the different value
16994  types.,size}
16995 
16996  @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
16997  the Container concept; that is, their size() functions have constant
16998  complexity.
16999 
17000  @iterators No changes.
17001 
17002  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
17003 
17004  @note This function does not return the length of a string stored as JSON
17005  value - it returns the number of elements in the JSON value which is 1 in
17006  the case of a string.
17007 
17008  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
17009  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
17010  requirements:
17011  - The complexity is constant.
17012  - Has the semantics of `std::distance(begin(), end())`.
17013 
17014  @sa @ref empty() -- checks whether the container is empty
17015  @sa @ref max_size() -- returns the maximal number of elements
17016 
17017  @since version 1.0.0
17018  */
17019  size_type size() const noexcept
17020  {
17021  switch (m_type)
17022  {
17023  case value_t::null:
17024  {
17025  // null values are empty
17026  return 0;
17027  }
17028 
17029  case value_t::array:
17030  {
17031  // delegate call to array_t::size()
17032  return m_value.array->size();
17033  }
17034 
17035  case value_t::object:
17036  {
17037  // delegate call to object_t::size()
17038  return m_value.object->size();
17039  }
17040 
17041  default:
17042  {
17043  // all other types have size 1
17044  return 1;
17045  }
17046  }
17047  }
17048 
17049  /*!
17050  @brief returns the maximum possible number of elements
17051 
17052  Returns the maximum number of elements a JSON value is able to hold due to
17053  system or library implementation limitations, i.e. `std::distance(begin(),
17054  end())` for the JSON value.
17055 
17056  @return The return value depends on the different types and is
17057  defined as follows:
17058  Value type | return value
17059  ----------- | -------------
17060  null | `0` (same as `size()`)
17061  boolean | `1` (same as `size()`)
17062  string | `1` (same as `size()`)
17063  number | `1` (same as `size()`)
17064  object | result of function `object_t::max_size()`
17065  array | result of function `array_t::max_size()`
17066 
17067  @liveexample{The following code calls `max_size()` on the different value
17068  types. Note the output is implementation specific.,max_size}
17069 
17070  @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
17071  the Container concept; that is, their `max_size()` functions have constant
17072  complexity.
17073 
17074  @iterators No changes.
17075 
17076  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
17077 
17078  @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
17079  [Container](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/Container)
17080  requirements:
17081  - The complexity is constant.
17082  - Has the semantics of returning `b.size()` where `b` is the largest
17083  possible JSON value.
17084 
17085  @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
17086 
17087  @since version 1.0.0
17088  */
17089  size_type max_size() const noexcept
17090  {
17091  switch (m_type)
17092  {
17093  case value_t::array:
17094  {
17095  // delegate call to array_t::max_size()
17096  return m_value.array->max_size();
17097  }
17098 
17099  case value_t::object:
17100  {
17101  // delegate call to object_t::max_size()
17102  return m_value.object->max_size();
17103  }
17104 
17105  default:
17106  {
17107  // all other types have max_size() == size()
17108  return size();
17109  }
17110  }
17111  }
17112 
17113  /// @}
17114 
17115 
17116  ///////////////
17117  // modifiers //
17118  ///////////////
17119 
17120  /// @name modifiers
17121  /// @{
17122 
17123  /*!
17124  @brief clears the contents
17125 
17126  Clears the content of a JSON value and resets it to the default value as
17127  if @ref basic_json(value_t) would have been called with the current value
17128  type from @ref type():
17129 
17130  Value type | initial value
17131  ----------- | -------------
17132  null | `null`
17133  boolean | `false`
17134  string | `""`
17135  number | `0`
17136  object | `{}`
17137  array | `[]`
17138 
17139  @post Has the same effect as calling
17140  @code {.cpp}
17141  *this = basic_json(type());
17142  @endcode
17143 
17144  @liveexample{The example below shows the effect of `clear()` to different
17145  JSON types.,clear}
17146 
17147  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
17148 
17149  @iterators All iterators, pointers and references related to this container
17150  are invalidated.
17151 
17152  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
17153 
17154  @sa @ref basic_json(value_t) -- constructor that creates an object with the
17155  same value than calling `clear()`
17156 
17157  @since version 1.0.0
17158  */
17159  void clear() noexcept
17160  {
17161  switch (m_type)
17162  {
17163  case value_t::number_integer:
17164  {
17165  m_value.number_integer = 0;
17166  break;
17167  }
17168
