17169  case value_t::number_unsigned:
17170  {
17171  m_value.number_unsigned = 0;
17172  break;
17173  }
17174 
17175  case value_t::number_float:
17176  {
17177  m_value.number_float = 0.0;
17178  break;
17179  }
17180 
17181  case value_t::boolean:
17182  {
17183  m_value.boolean = false;
17184  break;
17185  }
17186 
17187  case value_t::string:
17188  {
17189  m_value.string->clear();
17190  break;
17191  }
17192 
17193  case value_t::array:
17194  {
17195  m_value.array->clear();
17196  break;
17197  }
17198 
17199  case value_t::object:
17200  {
17201  m_value.object->clear();
17202  break;
17203  }
17204 
17205  default:
17206  break;
17207  }
17208  }
17209 
17210  /*!
17211  @brief add an object to an array
17212 
17213  Appends the given element @a val to the end of the JSON value. If the
17214  function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array is created before
17215  appending @a val.
17216 
17217  @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON array
17218 
17219  @throw type_error.308 when called on a type other than JSON array or
17220  null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
17221 
17222  @complexity Amortized constant.
17223 
17224  @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
17225  add elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently
17226  converted to a JSON array.,push_back}
17227 
17228  @since version 1.0.0
17229  */
17230  void push_back(basic_json&& val)
17231  {
17232  // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
17233  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
17234  {
17235  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17236  }
17237 
17238  // transform null object into an array
17239  if (is_null())
17240  {
17241  m_type = value_t::array;
17242  m_value = value_t::array;
17243  assert_invariant();
17244  }
17245 
17246  // add element to array (move semantics)
17247  m_value.array->push_back(std::move(val));
17248  // invalidate object
17249  val.m_type = value_t::null;
17250  }
17251 
17252  /*!
17253  @brief add an object to an array
17254  @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
17255  */
17256  reference operator+=(basic_json&& val)
17257  {
17258  push_back(std::move(val));
17259  return *this;
17260  }
17261 
17262  /*!
17263  @brief add an object to an array
17264  @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
17265  */
17266  void push_back(const basic_json& val)
17267  {
17268  // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
17269  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
17270  {
17271  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17272  }
17273 
17274  // transform null object into an array
17275  if (is_null())
17276  {
17277  m_type = value_t::array;
17278  m_value = value_t::array;
17279  assert_invariant();
17280  }
17281 
17282  // add element to array
17283  m_value.array->push_back(val);
17284  }
17285 
17286  /*!
17287  @brief add an object to an array
17288  @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
17289  */
17290  reference operator+=(const basic_json& val)
17291  {
17292  push_back(val);
17293  return *this;
17294  }
17295 
17296  /*!
17297  @brief add an object to an object
17298 
17299  Inserts the given element @a val to the JSON object. If the function is
17300  called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before inserting
17301  @a val.
17302 
17303  @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON object
17304 
17305  @throw type_error.308 when called on a type other than JSON object or
17306  null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
17307 
17308  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
17309 
17310  @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
17311  add elements to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently
17312  converted to a JSON object.,push_back__object_t__value}
17313 
17314  @since version 1.0.0
17315  */
17316  void push_back(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
17317  {
17318  // push_back only works for null objects or objects
17319  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_object())))
17320  {
17321  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17322  }
17323 
17324  // transform null object into an object
17325  if (is_null())
17326  {
17327  m_type = value_t::object;
17328  m_value = value_t::object;
17329  assert_invariant();
17330  }
17331 
17332  // add element to array
17333  m_value.object->insert(val);
17334  }
17335 
17336  /*!
17337  @brief add an object to an object
17338  @copydoc push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&)
17339  */
17340  reference operator+=(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
17341  {
17342  push_back(val);
17343  return *this;
17344  }
17345 
17346  /*!
17347  @brief add an object to an object
17348 
17349  This function allows to use `push_back` with an initializer list. In case
17350 
17351  1. the current value is an object,
17352  2. the initializer list @a init contains only two elements, and
17353  3. the first element of @a init is a string,
17354 
17355  @a init is converted into an object element and added using
17356  @ref push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&). Otherwise, @a init
17357  is converted to a JSON value and added using @ref push_back(basic_json&&).
17358 
17359  @param[in] init an initializer list
17360 
17361  @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
17362 
17363  @note This function is required to resolve an ambiguous overload error,
17364  because pairs like `{"key", "value"}` can be both interpreted as
17365  `object_t::value_type` or `std::initializer_list<basic_json>`, see
17366  https://github.com/nlohmann/json/issues/235 for more information.
17367 
17368  @liveexample{The example shows how initializer lists are treated as
17369  objects when possible.,push_back__initializer_list}
17370  */
17371  void push_back(initializer_list_t init)
17372  {
17373  if (is_object() and init.size() == 2 and (*init.begin())->is_string())
17374  {
17375  basic_json&& key = init.begin()->moved_or_copied();
17376  push_back(typename object_t::value_type(
17377  std::move(key.get_ref<string_t&>()), (init.begin() + 1)->moved_or_copied()));
17378  }
17379  else
17380  {
17381  push_back(basic_json(init));
17382  }
17383  }
17384 
17385  /*!
17386  @brief add an object to an object
17387  @copydoc push_back(initializer_list_t)
17388  */
17389  reference operator+=(initializer_list_t init)
17390  {
17391  push_back(init);
17392  return *this;
17393  }
17394 
17395  /*!
17396  @brief add an object to an array
17397 
17398  Creates a JSON value from the passed parameters @a args to the end of the
17399  JSON value. If the function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array
17400  is created before appending the value created from @a args.
17401 
17402  @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
17403  @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
17404 
17405  @throw type_error.311 when called on a type other than JSON array or
17406  null; example: `"cannot use emplace_back() with number"`
17407 
17408  @complexity Amortized constant.
17409 
17410  @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` can be used to add
17411  elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently converted
17412  to a JSON array.,emplace_back}
17413 
17414  @since version 2.0.8
17415  */
17416  template<class... Args>
17417  void emplace_back(Args&& ... args)
17418  {
17419  // emplace_back only works for null objects or arrays
17420  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
17421  {
17422  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(311, "cannot use emplace_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17423  }
17424 
17425  // transform null object into an array
17426  if (is_null())
17427  {
17428  m_type = value_t::array;
17429  m_value = value_t::array;
17430  assert_invariant();
17431  }
17432 
17433  // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
17434  m_value.array->emplace_back(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
17435  }
17436 
17437  /*!
17438  @brief add an object to an object if key does not exist
17439 
17440  Inserts a new element into a JSON object constructed in-place with the
17441  given @a args if there is no element with the key in the container. If the
17442  function is called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before
17443  appending the value created from @a args.
17444 
17445  @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
17446  @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
17447 
17448  @return a pair consisting of an iterator to the inserted element, or the
17449  already-existing element if no insertion happened, and a bool
17450  denoting whether the insertion took place.
17451 
17452  @throw type_error.311 when called on a type other than JSON object or
17453  null; example: `"cannot use emplace() with number"`
17454 
17455  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
17456 
17457  @liveexample{The example shows how `emplace()` can be used to add elements
17458  to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently converted to a
17459  JSON object. Further note how no value is added if there was already one
17460  value stored with the same key.,emplace}
17461 
17462  @since version 2.0.8
17463  */
17464  template<class... Args>
17465  std::pair<iterator, bool> emplace(Args&& ... args)
17466  {
17467  // emplace only works for null objects or arrays
17468  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_object())))
17469  {
17470  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(311, "cannot use emplace() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17471  }
17472 
17473  // transform null object into an object
17474  if (is_null())
17475  {
17476  m_type = value_t::object;
17477  m_value = value_t::object;
17478  assert_invariant();
17479  }
17480 
17481  // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
17482  auto res = m_value.object->emplace(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
17483  // create result iterator and set iterator to the result of emplace
17484  auto it = begin();
17485  it.m_it.object_iterator = res.first;
17486 
17487  // return pair of iterator and boolean
17488  return {it, res.second};
17489  }
17490 
17491  /// Helper for insertion of an iterator
17492  /// @note: This uses std::distance to support GCC 4.8,
17493  /// see https://github.com/nlohmann/json/pull/1257
17494  template<typename... Args>
17495  iterator insert_iterator(const_iterator pos, Args&& ... args)
17496  {
17497  iterator result(this);
17498  assert(m_value.array != nullptr);
17499 
17500  auto insert_pos = std::distance(m_value.array->begin(), pos.m_it.array_iterator);
17501  m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator, std::forward<Args>(args)...);
17502  result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->begin() + insert_pos;
17503 
17504  // This could have been written as:
17505  // result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator, cnt, val);
17506  // but the return value of insert is missing in GCC 4.8, so it is written this way instead.
17507 
17508  return result;
17509  }
17510 
17511  /*!
17512  @brief inserts element
17513 
17514  Inserts element @a val before iterator @a pos.
17515 
17516  @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
17517  the end() iterator
17518  @param[in] val element to insert
17519  @return iterator pointing to the inserted @a val.
17520 
17521  @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays;
17522  example: `"cannot use insert() with string"`
17523  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
17524  example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
17525 
17526  @complexity Constant plus linear in the distance between @a pos and end of
17527  the container.
17528 
17529  @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert}
17530 
17531  @since version 1.0.0
17532  */
17533  iterator insert(const_iterator pos, const basic_json& val)
17534  {
17535  // insert only works for arrays
17536  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
17537  {
17538  // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
17539  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
17540  {
17541  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
17542  }
17543 
17544  // insert to array and return iterator
17545  return insert_iterator(pos, val);
17546  }
17547 
17548  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17549  }
17550 
17551  /*!
17552  @brief inserts element
17553  @copydoc insert(const_iterator, const basic_json&)
17554  */
17555  iterator insert(const_iterator pos, basic_json&& val)
17556  {
17557  return insert(pos, val);
17558  }
17559 
17560  /*!
17561  @brief inserts elements
17562 
17563  Inserts @a cnt copies of @a val before iterator @a pos.
17564 
17565  @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
17566  the end() iterator
17567  @param[in] cnt number of copies of @a val to insert
17568  @param[in] val element to insert
17569  @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
17570  `cnt==0`
17571 
17572  @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays; example:
17573  `"cannot use insert() with string"`
17574  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
17575  example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
17576 
17577  @complexity Linear in @a cnt plus linear in the distance between @a pos
17578  and end of the container.
17579 
17580  @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__count}
17581 
17582  @since version 1.0.0
17583  */
17584  iterator insert(const_iterator pos, size_type cnt, const basic_json& val)
17585  {
17586  // insert only works for arrays
17587  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
17588  {
17589  // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
17590  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
17591  {
17592  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
17593  }
17594 
17595  // insert to array and return iterator
17596  return insert_iterator(pos, cnt, val);
17597  }
17598 
17599  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17600  }
17601 
17602  /*!
17603  @brief inserts elements
17604 
17605  Inserts elements from range `[first, last)` before iterator @a pos.
17606 
17607  @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
17608  the end() iterator
17609  @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
17610  @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
17611 
17612  @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays; example:
17613  `"cannot use insert() with string"`
17614  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
17615  example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
17616  @throw invalid_iterator.210 if @a first and @a last do not belong to the
17617  same JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
17618  @throw invalid_iterator.211 if @a first or @a last are iterators into
17619  container for which insert is called; example: `"passed iterators may not
17620  belong to container"`
17621 
17622  @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
17623  `first==last`
17624 
17625  @complexity Linear in `std::distance(first, last)` plus linear in the
17626  distance between @a pos and end of the container.
17627 
17628  @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__range}
17629 
17630  @since version 1.0.0
17631  */
17632  iterator insert(const_iterator pos, const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
17633  {
17634  // insert only works for arrays
17635  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_array()))
17636  {
17637  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17638  }
17639 
17640  // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
17641  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
17642  {
17643  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
17644  }
17645 
17646  // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
17647  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
17648  {
17649  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
17650  }
17651 
17652  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object == this))
17653  {
17654  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(211, "passed iterators may not belong to container"));
17655  }
17656 
17657  // insert to array and return iterator
17658  return insert_iterator(pos, first.m_it.array_iterator, last.m_it.array_iterator);
17659  }
17660 
17661  /*!
17662  @brief inserts elements
17663 
17664  Inserts elements from initializer list @a ilist before iterator @a pos.
17665 
17666  @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
17667  the end() iterator
17668  @param[in] ilist initializer list to insert the values from
17669 
17670  @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than arrays; example:
17671  `"cannot use insert() with string"`
17672  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if @a pos is not an iterator of *this;
17673  example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
17674 
17675  @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
17676  `ilist` is empty
17677 
17678  @complexity Linear in `ilist.size()` plus linear in the distance between
17679  @a pos and end of the container.
17680 
17681  @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__ilist}
17682 
17683  @since version 1.0.0
17684  */
17685  iterator insert(const_iterator pos, initializer_list_t ilist)
17686  {
17687  // insert only works for arrays
17688  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_array()))
17689  {
17690  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17691  }
17692 
17693  // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
17694  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(pos.m_object != this))
17695  {
17696  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
17697  }
17698 
17699  // insert to array and return iterator
17700  return insert_iterator(pos, ilist.begin(), ilist.end());
17701  }
17702 
17703  /*!
17704  @brief inserts elements
17705 
17706  Inserts elements from range `[first, last)`.
17707 
17708  @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
17709  @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
17710 
17711  @throw type_error.309 if called on JSON values other than objects; example:
17712  `"cannot use insert() with string"`
17713  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if iterator @a first or @a last does does not
17714  point to an object; example: `"iterators first and last must point to
17715  objects"`
17716  @throw invalid_iterator.210 if @a first and @a last do not belong to the
17717  same JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
17718 
17719  @complexity Logarithmic: `O(N*log(size() + N))`, where `N` is the number
17720  of elements to insert.
17721 
17722  @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__range_object}
17723 
17724  @since version 3.0.0
17725  */
17726  void insert(const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
17727  {
17728  // insert only works for objects
17729  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_object()))
17730  {
17731  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(309, "cannot use insert() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17732  }
17733 
17734  // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
17735  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
17736  {
17737  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
17738  }
17739 
17740  // passed iterators must belong to objects
17741  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_object->is_object()))
17742  {
17743  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterators first and last must point to objects"));
17744  }
17745 
17746  m_value.object->insert(first.m_it.object_iterator, last.m_it.object_iterator);
17747  }
17748 
17749  /*!
17750  @brief updates a JSON object from another object, overwriting existing keys
17751 
17752  Inserts all values from JSON object @a j and overwrites existing keys.
17753 
17754  @param[in] j JSON object to read values from
17755 
17756  @throw type_error.312 if called on JSON values other than objects; example:
17757  `"cannot use update() with string"`
17758 
17759  @complexity O(N*log(size() + N)), where N is the number of elements to
17760  insert.
17761 
17762  @liveexample{The example shows how `update()` is used.,update}
17763 
17764  @sa https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/stdtypes.html#dict.update
17765 
17766  @since version 3.0.0
17767  */
17768  void update(const_reference j)
17769  {
17770  // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
17771  if (is_null())
17772  {
17773  m_type = value_t::object;
17774  m_value.object = create<object_t>();
17775  assert_invariant();
17776  }
17777 
17778  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_object()))
17779  {
17780  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(312, "cannot use update() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17781  }
17782  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not j.is_object()))
17783  {
17784  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(312, "cannot use update() with " + std::string(j.type_name())));
17785  }
17786 
17787  for (auto it = j.cbegin(); it != j.cend(); ++it)
17788  {
17789  m_value.object->operator[](it.key()) = it.value();
17790  }
17791  }
17792 
17793  /*!
17794  @brief updates a JSON object from another object, overwriting existing keys
17795 
17796  Inserts all values from from range `[first, last)` and overwrites existing
17797  keys.
17798 
17799  @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
17800  @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
17801 
17802  @throw type_error.312 if called on JSON values other than objects; example:
17803  `"cannot use update() with string"`
17804  @throw invalid_iterator.202 if iterator @a first or @a last does does not
17805  point to an object; example: `"iterators first and last must point to
17806  objects"`
17807  @throw invalid_iterator.210 if @a first and @a last do not belong to the
17808  same JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
17809 
17810  @complexity O(N*log(size() + N)), where N is the number of elements to
17811  insert.
17812 
17813  @liveexample{The example shows how `update()` is used__range.,update}
17814 
17815  @sa https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/stdtypes.html#dict.update
17816 
17817  @since version 3.0.0
17818  */
17819  void update(const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
17820  {
17821  // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
17822  if (is_null())
17823  {
17824  m_type = value_t::object;
17825  m_value.object = create<object_t>();
17826  assert_invariant();
17827  }
17828 
17829  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not is_object()))
17830  {
17831  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(312, "cannot use update() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17832  }
17833 
17834  // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
17835  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
17836  {
17837  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
17838  }
17839 
17840  // passed iterators must belong to objects
17841  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_object->is_object()
17842  or not last.m_object->is_object()))
17843  {
17844  JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterators first and last must point to objects"));
17845  }
17846 
17847  for (auto it = first; it != last; ++it)
17848  {
17849  m_value.object->operator[](it.key()) = it.value();
17850  }
17851  }
17852 
17853  /*!
17854  @brief exchanges the values
17855 
17856  Exchanges the contents of the JSON value with those of @a other. Does not
17857  invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
17858  iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
17859  invalidated.
17860 
17861  @param[in,out] other JSON value to exchange the contents with
17862 
17863  @complexity Constant.
17864 
17865  @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values can be swapped with
17866  `swap()`.,swap__reference}
17867 
17868  @since version 1.0.0
17869  */
17870  void swap(reference other) noexcept (
17871  std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
17872  std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
17873  std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
17874  std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value
17875  )
17876  {
17877  std::swap(m_type, other.m_type);
17878  std::swap(m_value, other.m_value);
17879  assert_invariant();
17880  }
17881 
17882  /*!
17883  @brief exchanges the values
17884 
17885  Exchanges the contents of a JSON array with those of @a other. Does not
17886  invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
17887  iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
17888  invalidated.
17889 
17890  @param[in,out] other array to exchange the contents with
17891 
17892  @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not an array; example: `"cannot
17893  use swap() with string"`
17894 
17895  @complexity Constant.
17896 
17897  @liveexample{The example below shows how arrays can be swapped with
17898  `swap()`.,swap__array_t}
17899 
17900  @since version 1.0.0
17901  */
17902  void swap(array_t& other)
17903  {
17904  // swap only works for arrays
17905  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
17906  {
17907  std::swap(*(m_value.array), other);
17908  }
17909  else
17910  {
17911  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17912  }
17913  }
17914 
17915  /*!
17916  @brief exchanges the values
17917 
17918  Exchanges the contents of a JSON object with those of @a other. Does not
17919  invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
17920  iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
17921  invalidated.
17922 
17923  @param[in,out] other object to exchange the contents with
17924 
17925  @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not an object; example:
17926  `"cannot use swap() with string"`
17927 
17928  @complexity Constant.
17929 
17930  @liveexample{The example below shows how objects can be swapped with
17931  `swap()`.,swap__object_t}
17932 
17933  @since version 1.0.0
17934  */
17935  void swap(object_t& other)
17936  {
17937  // swap only works for objects
17938  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
17939  {
17940  std::swap(*(m_value.object), other);
17941  }
17942  else
17943  {
17944  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17945  }
17946  }
17947 
17948  /*!
17949  @brief exchanges the values
17950 
17951  Exchanges the contents of a JSON string with those of @a other. Does not
17952  invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
17953  iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
17954  invalidated.
17955 
17956  @param[in,out] other string to exchange the contents with
17957 
17958  @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not a string; example: `"cannot
17959  use swap() with boolean"`
17960 
17961  @complexity Constant.
17962 
17963  @liveexample{The example below shows how strings can be swapped with
17964  `swap()`.,swap__string_t}
17965 
17966  @since version 1.0.0
17967  */
17968  void swap(string_t& other)
17969  {
17970  // swap only works for strings
17971  if (JSON_LIKELY(is_string()))
17972  {
17973  std::swap(*(m_value.string), other);
17974  }
17975  else
17976  {
17977  JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " + std::string(type_name())));
17978  }
17979  }
17980 
17981  /// @}
17982 
17983  public:
17984  //////////////////////////////////////////
17985  // lexicographical comparison operators //
17986  //////////////////////////////////////////
17987 
17988  /// @name lexicographical comparison operators
17989  /// @{
17990 
17991  /*!
17992  @brief comparison: equal
17993 
17994  Compares two JSON values for equality according to the following rules:
17995  - Two JSON values are equal if (1) they are from the same type and (2)
17996  their stored values are the same according to their respective
17997  `operator==`.
17998  - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
17999  comparison. Note than two NaN values are always treated as unequal.
18000  - Two JSON null values are equal.
18001 
18002  @note Floating-point inside JSON values numbers are compared with
18003  `json::number_float_t::operator==` which is `double::operator==` by
18004  default. To compare floating-point while respecting an epsilon, an alternative
18005  [comparison function](https://github.com/mariokonrad/marnav/blob/master/src/marnav/math/floatingpoint.hpp#L34-#L39)
18006  could be used, for instance
18007  @code {.cpp}
18008  template<typename T, typename = typename std::enable_if<std::is_floating_point<T>::value, T>::type>
18009  inline bool is_same(T a, T b, T epsilon = std::numeric_limits<T>::epsilon()) noexcept
18010  {
18011  return std::abs(a - b) <= epsilon;
18012  }
18013  @endcode
18014 
18015  @note NaN values never compare equal to themselves or to other NaN values.
18016 
18017  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
18018  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
18019  @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are equal
18020 
18021  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18022 
18023  @complexity Linear.
18024 
18025  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
18026  types.,operator__equal}
18027 
18028  @since version 1.0.0
18029  */
18030  friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18031  {
18032  const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
18033  const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
18034 
18035  if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
18036  {
18037  switch (lhs_type)
18038  {
18039  case value_t::array:
18040  return (*lhs.m_value.array == *rhs.m_value.array);
18041 
18042  case value_t::object:
18043  return (*lhs.m_value.object == *rhs.m_value.object);
18044 
18045  case value_t::null:
18046  return true;
18047 
18048  case value_t::string:
18049  return (*lhs.m_value.string == *rhs.m_value.string);
18050 
18051  case value_t::boolean:
18052  return (lhs.m_value.boolean == rhs.m_value.boolean);
18053 
18054  case value_t::number_integer:
18055  return (lhs.m_value.number_integer == rhs.m_value.number_integer);
18056 
18057  case value_t::number_unsigned:
18058  return (lhs.m_value.number_unsigned == rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
18059 
18060  case value_t::number_float:
18061  return (lhs.m_value.number_float == rhs.m_value.number_float);
18062 
18063  default:
18064  return false;
18065  }
18066  }
18067  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
18068  {
18069  return (static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) == rhs.m_value.number_float);
18070  }
18071  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
18072  {
18073  return (lhs.m_value.number_float == static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer));
18074  }
18075  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
18076  {
18077  return (static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) == rhs.m_value.number_float);
18078  }
18079  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
18080  {
18081  return (lhs.m_value.number_float == static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned));
18082  }
18083  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
18084  {
18085  return (static_cast<number_integer_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) == rhs.m_value.number_integer);
18086  }
18087  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
18088  {
18089  return (lhs.m_value.number_integer == static_cast<number_integer_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned));
18090  }
18091 
18092  return false;
18093  }
18094 
18095  /*!
18096  @brief comparison: equal
18097  @copydoc operator==(const_reference, const_reference)
18098  */
18099  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18100  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18101  friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
18102  {
18103  return (lhs == basic_json(rhs));
18104  }
18105 
18106  /*!
18107  @brief comparison: equal
18108  @copydoc operator==(const_reference, const_reference)
18109  */
18110  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18111  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18112  friend bool operator==(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18113  {
18114  return (basic_json(lhs) == rhs);
18115  }
18116 
18117  /*!
18118  @brief comparison: not equal
18119 
18120  Compares two JSON values for inequality by calculating `not (lhs == rhs)`.
18121 
18122  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
18123  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
18124  @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are not equal
18125 
18126  @complexity Linear.
18127 
18128  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18129 
18130  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
18131  types.,operator__notequal}
18132 
18133  @since version 1.0.0
18134  */
18135  friend bool operator!=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18136  {
18137  return not (lhs == rhs);
18138  }
18139 
18140  /*!
18141  @brief comparison: not equal
18142  @copydoc operator!=(const_reference, const_reference)
18143  */
18144  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18145  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18146  friend bool operator!=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
18147  {
18148  return (lhs != basic_json(rhs));
18149  }
18150 
18151  /*!
18152  @brief comparison: not equal
18153  @copydoc operator!=(const_reference, const_reference)
18154  */
18155  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18156  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18157  friend bool operator!=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18158  {
18159  return (basic_json(lhs) != rhs);
18160  }
18161 
18162  /*!
18163  @brief comparison: less than
18164 
18165  Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than another JSON value @a
18166  rhs according to the following rules:
18167  - If @a lhs and @a rhs have the same type, the values are compared using
18168  the default `<` operator.
18169  - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
18170  comparison
18171  - In case @a lhs and @a rhs have different types, the values are ignored
18172  and the order of the types is considered, see
18173  @ref operator<(const value_t, const value_t).
18174 
18175  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
18176  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
18177  @return whether @a lhs is less than @a rhs
18178 
18179  @complexity Linear.
18180 
18181  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18182 
18183  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
18184  types.,operator__less}
18185 
18186  @since version 1.0.0
18187  */
18188  friend bool operator<(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18189  {
18190  const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
18191  const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
18192 
18193  if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
18194  {
18195  switch (lhs_type)
18196  {
18197  case value_t::array:
18198  return (*lhs.m_value.array) < (*rhs.m_value.array);
18199 
18200  case value_t::object:
18201  return *lhs.m_value.object < *rhs.m_value.object;
18202 
18203  case value_t::null:
18204  return false;
18205 
18206  case value_t::string:
18207  return *lhs.m_value.string < *rhs.m_value.string;
18208 
18209  case value_t::boolean:
18210  return lhs.m_value.boolean < rhs.m_value.boolean;
18211 
18212  case value_t::number_integer:
18213  return lhs.m_value.number_integer < rhs.m_value.number_integer;
18214 
18215  case value_t::number_unsigned:
18216  return lhs.m_value.number_unsigned < rhs.m_value.number_unsigned;
18217 
18218  case value_t::number_float:
18219  return lhs.m_value.number_float < rhs.m_value.number_float;
18220 
18221  default:
18222  return false;
18223  }
18224  }
18225  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
18226  {
18227  return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) < rhs.m_value.number_float;
18228  }
18229  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
18230  {
18231  return lhs.m_value.number_float < static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer);
18232  }
18233  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
18234  {
18235  return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) < rhs.m_value.number_float;
18236  }
18237  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
18238  {
18239  return lhs.m_value.number_float < static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
18240  }
18241  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
18242  {
18243  return lhs.m_value.number_integer < static_cast<number_integer_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
18244  }
18245  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
18246  {
18247  return static_cast<number_integer_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) < rhs.m_value.number_integer;
18248  }
18249 
18250  // We only reach this line if we cannot compare values. In that case,
18251  // we compare types. Note we have to call the operator explicitly,
18252  // because MSVC has problems otherwise.
18253  return operator<(lhs_type, rhs_type);
18254  }
18255 
18256  /*!
18257  @brief comparison: less than
18258  @copydoc operator<(const_reference, const_reference)
18259  */
18260  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18261  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18262  friend bool operator<(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
18263  {
18264  return (lhs < basic_json(rhs));
18265  }
18266 
18267  /*!
18268  @brief comparison: less than
18269  @copydoc operator<(const_reference, const_reference)
18270  */
18271  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18272  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18273  friend bool operator<(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18274  {
18275  return (basic_json(lhs) < rhs);
18276  }
18277 
18278  /*!
18279  @brief comparison: less than or equal
18280 
18281  Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than or equal to another
18282  JSON value by calculating `not (rhs < lhs)`.
18283 
18284  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
18285  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
18286  @return whether @a lhs is less than or equal to @a rhs
18287 
18288  @complexity Linear.
18289 
18290  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18291 
18292  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
18293  types.,operator__greater}
18294 
18295  @since version 1.0.0
18296  */
18297  friend bool operator<=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18298  {
18299  return not (rhs < lhs);
18300  }
18301 
18302  /*!
18303  @brief comparison: less than or equal
18304  @copydoc operator<=(const_reference, const_reference)
18305  */
18306  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18307  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18308  friend bool operator<=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
18309  {
18310  return (lhs <= basic_json(rhs));
18311  }
18312 
18313  /*!
18314  @brief comparison: less than or equal
18315  @copydoc operator<=(const_reference, const_reference)
18316  */
18317  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18318  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18319  friend bool operator<=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18320  {
18321  return (basic_json(lhs) <= rhs);
18322  }
18323 
18324  /*!
18325  @brief comparison: greater than
18326 
18327  Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than another
18328  JSON value by calculating `not (lhs <= rhs)`.
18329 
18330  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
18331  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
18332  @return whether @a lhs is greater than to @a rhs
18333 
18334  @complexity Linear.
18335 
18336  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18337 
18338  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
18339  types.,operator__lessequal}
18340 
18341  @since version 1.0.0
18342  */
18343  friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18344  {
18345  return not (lhs <= rhs);
18346  }
18347 
18348  /*!
18349  @brief comparison: greater than
18350  @copydoc operator>(const_reference, const_reference)
18351  */
18352  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18353  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18354  friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
18355  {
18356  return (lhs > basic_json(rhs));
18357  }
18358 
18359  /*!
18360  @brief comparison: greater than
18361  @copydoc operator>(const_reference, const_reference)
18362  */
18363  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18364  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18365  friend bool operator>(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18366  {
18367  return (basic_json(lhs) > rhs);
18368  }
18369 
18370  /*!
18371  @brief comparison: greater than or equal
18372 
18373  Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than or equal to another
18374  JSON value by calculating `not (lhs < rhs)`.
18375 
18376  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
18377  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
18378  @return whether @a lhs is greater than or equal to @a rhs
18379 
18380  @complexity Linear.
18381 
18382  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18383 
18384  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
18385  types.,operator__greaterequal}
18386 
18387  @since version 1.0.0
18388  */
18389  friend bool operator>=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18390  {
18391  return not (lhs < rhs);
18392  }
18393 
18394  /*!
18395  @brief comparison: greater than or equal
18396  @copydoc operator>=(const_reference, const_reference)
18397  */
18398  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18399  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18400  friend bool operator>=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
18401  {
18402  return (lhs >= basic_json(rhs));
18403  }
18404 
18405  /*!
18406  @brief comparison: greater than or equal
18407  @copydoc operator>=(const_reference, const_reference)
18408  */
18409  template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
18410  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
18411  friend bool operator>=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
18412  {
18413  return (basic_json(lhs) >= rhs);
18414  }
18415 
18416  /// @}
18417 
18418  ///////////////////
18419  // serialization //
18420  ///////////////////
18421 
18422  /// @name serialization
18423  /// @{
18424 
18425  /*!
18426  @brief serialize to stream
18427 
18428  Serialize the given JSON value @a j to the output stream @a o. The JSON
18429  value will be serialized using the @ref dump member function.
18430 
18431  - The indentation of the output can be controlled with the member variable
18432  `width` of the output stream @a o. For instance, using the manipulator
18433  `std::setw(4)` on @a o sets the indentation level to `4` and the
18434  serialization result is the same as calling `dump(4)`.
18435 
18436  - The indentation character can be controlled with the member variable
18437  `fill` of the output stream @a o. For instance, the manipulator
18438  `std::setfill('\\t')` sets indentation to use a tab character rather than
18439  the default space character.
18440 
18441  @param[in,out] o stream to serialize to
18442  @param[in] j JSON value to serialize
18443 
18444  @return the stream @a o
18445 
18446  @throw type_error.316 if a string stored inside the JSON value is not
18447  UTF-8 encoded
18448 
18449  @complexity Linear.
18450 
18451  @liveexample{The example below shows the serialization with different
18452  parameters to `width` to adjust the indentation level.,operator_serialize}
18453 
18454  @since version 1.0.0; indentation character added in version 3.0.0
18455  */
18456  friend std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& o, const basic_json& j)
18457  {
18458  // read width member and use it as indentation parameter if nonzero
18459  const bool pretty_print = (o.width() > 0);
18460  const auto indentation = (pretty_print ? o.width() : 0);
18461 
18462  // reset width to 0 for subsequent calls to this stream
18463  o.width(0);
18464 
18465  // do the actual serialization
18466  serializer s(detail::output_adapter<char>(o), o.fill());
18467  s.dump(j, pretty_print, false, static_cast<unsigned int>(indentation));
18468  return o;
18469  }
18470 
18471  /*!
18472  @brief serialize to stream
18473  @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
18474  future 4.0.0 of the library. Please use
18475  @ref operator<<(std::ostream&, const basic_json&)
18476  instead; that is, replace calls like `j >> o;` with `o << j;`.
18477  @since version 1.0.0; deprecated since version 3.0.0
18478  */
18479  JSON_DEPRECATED
18480  friend std::ostream& operator>>(const basic_json& j, std::ostream& o)
18481  {
18482  return o << j;
18483  }
18484 
18485  /// @}
18486 
18487 
18488  /////////////////////
18489  // deserialization //
18490  /////////////////////
18491 
18492  /// @name deserialization
18493  /// @{
18494 
18495  /*!
18496  @brief deserialize from a compatible input
18497 
18498  This function reads from a compatible input. Examples are:
18499  - an array of 1-byte values
18500  - strings with character/literal type with size of 1 byte
18501  - input streams
18502  - container with contiguous storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container
18503  types include `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`,
18504  `std::valarray`, and `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style
18505  arrays can be used with `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined
18506  containers can be used as long as they implement random-access iterators
18507  and a contiguous storage.
18508 
18509  @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
18510  precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
18511  with a static assertion.**
18512 
18513  @pre The container storage is contiguous. Violating this precondition
18514  yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an
18515  assertion.**
18516  @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
18517  precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
18518  with a static assertion.**
18519 
18520  @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
18521  the function is called with a noncompliant container and with
18522  assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
18523  likely yield segmentation violation.
18524 
18525  @param[in] i input to read from
18526  @param[in] cb a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
18527  which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
18528  (optional)
18529  @param[in] allow_exceptions whether to throw exceptions in case of a
18530  parse error (optional, true by default)
18531 
18532  @return deserialized JSON value; in case of a parse error and
18533  @a allow_exceptions set to `false`, the return value will be
18534  value_t::discarded.
18535 
18536  @throw parse_error.101 if a parse error occurs; example: `""unexpected end
18537  of input; expected string literal""`
18538  @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
18539  @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
18540 
18541  @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
18542  LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
18543  @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
18544 
18545  @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
18546 
18547  @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
18548  from an array.,parse__array__parser_callback_t}
18549 
18550  @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
18551  and without callback function.,parse__string__parser_callback_t}
18552 
18553  @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
18554  and without callback function.,parse__istream__parser_callback_t}
18555 
18556  @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
18557  from a contiguous container.,parse__contiguouscontainer__parser_callback_t}
18558 
18559  @since version 2.0.3 (contiguous containers)
18560  */
18561  JSON_NODISCARD
18562  static basic_json parse(detail::input_adapter&& i,
18563  const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
18564  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
18565  {
18566  basic_json result;
18567  parser(i, cb, allow_exceptions).parse(true, result);
18568  return result;
18569  }
18570 
18571  static bool accept(detail::input_adapter&& i)
18572  {
18573  return parser(i).accept(true);
18574  }
18575 
18576  /*!
18577  @brief generate SAX events
18578 
18579  The SAX event lister must follow the interface of @ref json_sax.
18580 
18581  This function reads from a compatible input. Examples are:
18582  - an array of 1-byte values
18583  - strings with character/literal type with size of 1 byte
18584  - input streams
18585  - container with contiguous storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container
18586  types include `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`,
18587  `std::valarray`, and `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style
18588  arrays can be used with `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined
18589  containers can be used as long as they implement random-access iterators
18590  and a contiguous storage.
18591 
18592  @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
18593  precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
18594  with a static assertion.**
18595 
18596  @pre The container storage is contiguous. Violating this precondition
18597  yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an
18598  assertion.**
18599  @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
18600  precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
18601  with a static assertion.**
18602 
18603  @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
18604  the function is called with a noncompliant container and with
18605  assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
18606  likely yield segmentation violation.
18607 
18608  @param[in] i input to read from
18609  @param[in,out] sax SAX event listener
18610  @param[in] format the format to parse (JSON, CBOR, MessagePack, or UBJSON)
18611  @param[in] strict whether the input has to be consumed completely
18612 
18613  @return return value of the last processed SAX event
18614 
18615  @throw parse_error.101 if a parse error occurs; example: `""unexpected end
18616  of input; expected string literal""`
18617  @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
18618  @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
18619 
18620  @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
18621  LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the SAX consumer @a sax has
18622  a super-linear complexity.
18623 
18624  @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
18625 
18626  @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `sax_parse()` function
18627  reading from string and processing the events with a user-defined SAX
18628  event consumer.,sax_parse}
18629 
18630  @since version 3.2.0
18631  */
18632  template <typename SAX>
18633  static bool sax_parse(detail::input_adapter&& i, SAX* sax,
18634  input_format_t format = input_format_t::json,
18635  const bool strict = true)
18636  {
18637  assert(sax);
18638  switch (format)
18639  {
18640  case input_format_t::json:
18641  return parser(std::move(i)).sax_parse(sax, strict);
18642  default:
18643  return detail::binary_reader<basic_json, SAX>(std::move(i)).sax_parse(format, sax, strict);
18644  }
18645  }
18646 
18647  /*!
18648  @brief deserialize from an iterator range with contiguous storage
18649 
18650  This function reads from an iterator range of a container with contiguous
18651  storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container types include
18652  `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`, `std::valarray`, and
18653  `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style arrays can be used with
18654  `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined containers can be used as long
18655  as they implement random-access iterators and a contiguous storage.
18656 
18657  @pre The iterator range is contiguous. Violating this precondition yields
18658  undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an assertion.**
18659  @pre Each element in the range has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
18660  precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
18661  with a static assertion.**
18662 
18663  @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
18664  the function is called with noncompliant iterators and with
18665  assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
18666  likely yield segmentation violation.
18667 
18668  @tparam IteratorType iterator of container with contiguous storage
18669  @param[in] first begin of the range to parse (included)
18670  @param[in] last end of the range to parse (excluded)
18671  @param[in] cb a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
18672  which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
18673  (optional)
18674  @param[in] allow_exceptions whether to throw exceptions in case of a
18675  parse error (optional, true by default)
18676 
18677  @return deserialized JSON value; in case of a parse error and
18678  @a allow_exceptions set to `false`, the return value will be
18679  value_t::discarded.
18680 
18681  @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
18682  @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
18683  @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
18684 
18685  @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
18686  LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
18687  @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
18688 
18689  @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
18690 
18691  @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
18692  from an iterator range.,parse__iteratortype__parser_callback_t}
18693 
18694  @since version 2.0.3
18695  */
18696  template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
18697  std::is_base_of<
18698  std::random_access_iterator_tag,
18699  typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value, int>::type = 0>
18700  static basic_json parse(IteratorType first, IteratorType last,
18701  const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
18702  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
18703  {
18704  basic_json result;
18705  parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last), cb, allow_exceptions).parse(true, result);
18706  return result;
18707  }
18708 
18709  template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
18710  std::is_base_of<
18711  std::random_access_iterator_tag,
18712  typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value, int>::type = 0>
18713  static bool accept(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
18714  {
18715  return parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last)).accept(true);
18716  }
18717 
18718  template<class IteratorType, class SAX, typename std::enable_if<
18719  std::is_base_of<
18720  std::random_access_iterator_tag,
18721  typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value, int>::type = 0>
18722  static bool sax_parse(IteratorType first, IteratorType last, SAX* sax)
18723  {
18724  return parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last)).sax_parse(sax);
18725  }
18726 
18727  /*!
18728  @brief deserialize from stream
18729  @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
18730  version 4.0.0 of the library. Please use
18731  @ref operator>>(std::istream&, basic_json&)
18732  instead; that is, replace calls like `j << i;` with `i >> j;`.
18733  @since version 1.0.0; deprecated since version 3.0.0
18734  */
18735  JSON_DEPRECATED
18736  friend std::istream& operator<<(basic_json& j, std::istream& i)
18737  {
18738  return operator>>(i, j);
18739  }
18740 
18741  /*!
18742  @brief deserialize from stream
18743 
18744  Deserializes an input stream to a JSON value.
18745 
18746  @param[in,out] i input stream to read a serialized JSON value from
18747  @param[in,out] j JSON value to write the deserialized input to
18748 
18749  @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
18750  @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
18751  @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
18752 
18753  @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
18754  LL(1) parser.
18755 
18756  @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
18757 
18758  @liveexample{The example below shows how a JSON value is constructed by
18759  reading a serialization from a stream.,operator_deserialize}
18760 
18761  @sa parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t) for a variant with a
18762  parser callback function to filter values while parsing
18763 
18764  @since version 1.0.0
18765  */
18766  friend std::istream& operator>>(std::istream& i, basic_json& j)
18767  {
18768  parser(detail::input_adapter(i)).parse(false, j);
18769  return i;
18770  }
18771 
18772  /// @}
18773 
18774  ///////////////////////////
18775  // convenience functions //
18776  ///////////////////////////
18777 
18778  /*!
18779  @brief return the type as string
18780 
18781  Returns the type name as string to be used in error messages - usually to
18782  indicate that a function was called on a wrong JSON type.
18783 
18784  @return a string representation of a the @a m_type member:
18785  Value type | return value
18786  ----------- | -------------
18787  null | `"null"`
18788  boolean | `"boolean"`
18789  string | `"string"`
18790  number | `"number"` (for all number types)
18791  object | `"object"`
18792  array | `"array"`
18793  discarded | `"discarded"`
18794 
18795  @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
18796 
18797  @complexity Constant.
18798 
18799  @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `type_name()` for all JSON
18800  types.,type_name}
18801 
18802  @sa @ref type() -- return the type of the JSON value
18803  @sa @ref operator value_t() -- return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
18804 
18805  @since version 1.0.0, public since 2.1.0, `const char*` and `noexcept`
18806  since 3.0.0
18807  */
18808  const char* type_name() const noexcept
18809  {
18810  {
18811  switch (m_type)
18812  {
18813  case value_t::null:
18814  return "null";
18815  case value_t::object:
18816  return "object";
18817  case value_t::array:
18818  return "array";
18819  case value_t::string:
18820  return "string";
18821  case value_t::boolean:
18822  return "boolean";
18823  case value_t::discarded:
18824  return "discarded";
18825  default:
18826  return "number";
18827  }
18828  }
18829  }
18830 
18831 
18832  private:
18833  //////////////////////
18834  // member variables //
18835  //////////////////////
18836 
18837  /// the type of the current element
18838  value_t m_type = value_t::null;
18839 
18840  /// the value of the current element
18841  json_value m_value = {};
18842 
18843  //////////////////////////////////////////
18844  // binary serialization/deserialization //
18845  //////////////////////////////////////////
18846 
18847  /// @name binary serialization/deserialization support
18848  /// @{
18849 
18850  public:
18851  /*!
18852  @brief create a CBOR serialization of a given JSON value
18853 
18854  Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the CBOR (Concise
18855  Binary Object Representation) serialization format. CBOR is a binary
18856  serialization format which aims to be more compact than JSON itself, yet
18857  more efficient to parse.
18858 
18859  The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
18860  CBOR types according to the CBOR specification (RFC 7049):
18861 
18862  JSON value type | value/range | CBOR type | first byte
18863  --------------- | ------------------------------------------ | ---------------------------------- | ---------------
18864  null | `null` | Null | 0xF6
18865  boolean | `true` | True | 0xF5
18866  boolean | `false` | False | 0xF4
18867  number_integer | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | Negative integer (8 bytes follow) | 0x3B
18868  number_integer | -2147483648..-32769 | Negative integer (4 bytes follow) | 0x3A
18869  number_integer | -32768..-129 | Negative integer (2 bytes follow) | 0x39
18870  number_integer | -128..-25 | Negative integer (1 byte follow) | 0x38
18871  number_integer | -24..-1 | Negative integer | 0x20..0x37
18872  number_integer | 0..23 | Integer | 0x00..0x17
18873  number_integer | 24..255 | Unsigned integer (1 byte follow) | 0x18
18874  number_integer | 256..65535 | Unsigned integer (2 bytes follow) | 0x19
18875  number_integer | 65536..4294967295 | Unsigned integer (4 bytes follow) | 0x1A
18876  number_integer | 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | Unsigned integer (8 bytes follow) | 0x1B
18877  number_unsigned | 0..23 | Integer | 0x00..0x17
18878  number_unsigned | 24..255 | Unsigned integer (1 byte follow) | 0x18
18879  number_unsigned | 256..65535 | Unsigned integer (2 bytes follow) | 0x19
18880  number_unsigned | 65536..4294967295 | Unsigned integer (4 bytes follow) | 0x1A
18881  number_unsigned | 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | Unsigned integer (8 bytes follow) | 0x1B
18882  number_float | *any value* | Double-Precision Float | 0xFB
18883  string | *length*: 0..23 | UTF-8 string | 0x60..0x77
18884  string | *length*: 23..255 | UTF-8 string (1 byte follow) | 0x78
18885  string | *length*: 256..65535 | UTF-8 string (2 bytes follow) | 0x79
18886  string | *length*: 65536..4294967295 | UTF-8 string (4 bytes follow) | 0x7A
18887  string | *length*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | UTF-8 string (8 bytes follow) | 0x7B
18888  array | *size*: 0..23 | array | 0x80..0x97
18889  array | *size*: 23..255 | array (1 byte follow) | 0x98
18890  array | *size*: 256..65535 | array (2 bytes follow) | 0x99
18891  array | *size*: 65536..4294967295 | array (4 bytes follow) | 0x9A
18892  array | *size*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | array (8 bytes follow) | 0x9B
18893  object | *size*: 0..23 | map | 0xA0..0xB7
18894  object | *size*: 23..255 | map (1 byte follow) | 0xB8
18895  object | *size*: 256..65535 | map (2 bytes follow) | 0xB9
18896  object | *size*: 65536..4294967295 | map (4 bytes follow) | 0xBA
18897  object | *size*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | map (8 bytes follow) | 0xBB
18898 
18899  @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
18900  can be converted to a CBOR value.
18901 
18902  @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
18903  serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
18904  function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
18905 
18906  @note The following CBOR types are not used in the conversion:
18907  - byte strings (0x40..0x5F)
18908  - UTF-8 strings terminated by "break" (0x7F)
18909  - arrays terminated by "break" (0x9F)
18910  - maps terminated by "break" (0xBF)
18911  - date/time (0xC0..0xC1)
18912  - bignum (0xC2..0xC3)
18913  - decimal fraction (0xC4)
18914  - bigfloat (0xC5)
18915  - tagged items (0xC6..0xD4, 0xD8..0xDB)
18916  - expected conversions (0xD5..0xD7)
18917  - simple values (0xE0..0xF3, 0xF8)
18918  - undefined (0xF7)
18919  - half and single-precision floats (0xF9-0xFA)
18920  - break (0xFF)
18921 
18922  @param[in] j JSON value to serialize
18923  @return MessagePack serialization as byte vector
18924 
18925  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
18926 
18927  @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
18928  vector in CBOR format.,to_cbor}
18929 
18930  @sa http://cbor.io
18931  @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
18932  analogous deserialization
18933  @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
18934  @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
18935  related UBJSON format
18936 
18937  @since version 2.0.9
18938  */
18939  static std::vector<uint8_t> to_cbor(const basic_json& j)
18940  {
18941  std::vector<uint8_t> result;
18942  to_cbor(j, result);
18943  return result;
18944  }
18945 
18946  static void to_cbor(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
18947  {
18948  binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_cbor(j);
18949  }
18950 
18951  static void to_cbor(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
18952  {
18953  binary_writer<char>(o).write_cbor(j);
18954  }
18955 
18956  /*!
18957  @brief create a MessagePack serialization of a given JSON value
18958 
18959  Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the MessagePack
18960  serialization format. MessagePack is a binary serialization format which
18961  aims to be more compact than JSON itself, yet more efficient to parse.
18962 
18963  The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
18964  MessagePack types according to the MessagePack specification:
18965 
18966  JSON value type | value/range | MessagePack type | first byte
18967  --------------- | --------------------------------- | ---------------- | ----------
18968  null | `null` | nil | 0xC0
18969  boolean | `true` | true | 0xC3
18970  boolean | `false` | false | 0xC2
18971  number_integer | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64 | 0xD3
18972  number_integer | -2147483648..-32769 | int32 | 0xD2
18973  number_integer | -32768..-129 | int16 | 0xD1
18974  number_integer | -128..-33 | int8 | 0xD0
18975  number_integer | -32..-1 | negative fixint | 0xE0..0xFF
18976  number_integer | 0..127 | positive fixint | 0x00..0x7F
18977  number_integer | 128..255 | uint 8 | 0xCC
18978  number_integer | 256..65535 | uint 16 | 0xCD
18979  number_integer | 65536..4294967295 | uint 32 | 0xCE
18980  number_integer | 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | uint 64 | 0xCF
18981  number_unsigned | 0..127 | positive fixint | 0x00..0x7F
18982  number_unsigned | 128..255 | uint 8 | 0xCC
18983  number_unsigned | 256..65535 | uint 16 | 0xCD
18984  number_unsigned | 65536..4294967295 | uint 32 | 0xCE
18985  number_unsigned | 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | uint 64 | 0xCF
18986  number_float | *any value* | float 64 | 0xCB
18987  string | *length*: 0..31 | fixstr | 0xA0..0xBF
18988  string | *length*: 32..255 | str 8 | 0xD9
18989  string | *length*: 256..65535 | str 16 | 0xDA
18990  string | *length*: 65536..4294967295 | str 32 | 0xDB
18991  array | *size*: 0..15 | fixarray | 0x90..0x9F
18992  array | *size*: 16..65535 | array 16 | 0xDC
18993  array | *size*: 65536..4294967295 | array 32 | 0xDD
18994  object | *size*: 0..15 | fix map | 0x80..0x8F
18995  object | *size*: 16..65535 | map 16 | 0xDE
18996  object | *size*: 65536..4294967295 | map 32 | 0xDF
18997 
18998  @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
18999  can be converted to a MessagePack value.
19000 
19001  @note The following values can **not** be converted to a MessagePack value:
19002  - strings with more than 4294967295 bytes
19003  - arrays with more than 4294967295 elements
19004  - objects with more than 4294967295 elements
19005 
19006  @note The following MessagePack types are not used in the conversion:
19007  - bin 8 - bin 32 (0xC4..0xC6)
19008  - ext 8 - ext 32 (0xC7..0xC9)
19009  - float 32 (0xCA)
19010  - fixext 1 - fixext 16 (0xD4..0xD8)
19011 
19012  @note Any MessagePack output created @ref to_msgpack can be successfully
19013  parsed by @ref from_msgpack.
19014 
19015  @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
19016  serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
19017  function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
19018 
19019  @param[in] j JSON value to serialize
19020  @return MessagePack serialization as byte vector
19021 
19022  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
19023 
19024  @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
19025  vector in MessagePack format.,to_msgpack}
19026 
19027  @sa http://msgpack.org
19028  @sa @ref from_msgpack for the analogous deserialization
19029  @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json& for the related CBOR format
19030  @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
19031  related UBJSON format
19032 
19033  @since version 2.0.9
19034  */
19035  static std::vector<uint8_t> to_msgpack(const basic_json& j)
19036  {
19037  std::vector<uint8_t> result;
19038  to_msgpack(j, result);
19039  return result;
19040  }
19041 
19042  static void to_msgpack(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
19043  {
19044  binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_msgpack(j);
19045  }
19046 
19047  static void to_msgpack(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
19048  {
19049  binary_writer<char>(o).write_msgpack(j);
19050  }
19051 
19052  /*!
19053  @brief create a UBJSON serialization of a given JSON value
19054 
19055  Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the UBJSON
19056  (Universal Binary JSON) serialization format. UBJSON aims to be more compact
19057  than JSON itself, yet more efficient to parse.
19058 
19059  The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
19060  UBJSON types according to the UBJSON specification:
19061 
19062  JSON value type | value/range | UBJSON type | marker
19063  --------------- | --------------------------------- | ----------- | ------
19064  null | `null` | null | `Z`
19065  boolean | `true` | true | `T`
19066  boolean | `false` | false | `F`
19067  number_integer | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64 | `L`
19068  number_integer | -2147483648..-32769 | int32 | `l`
19069  number_integer | -32768..-129 | int16 | `I`
19070  number_integer | -128..127 | int8 | `i`
19071  number_integer | 128..255 | uint8 | `U`
19072  number_integer | 256..32767 | int16 | `I`
19073  number_integer | 32768..2147483647 | int32 | `l`
19074  number_integer | 2147483648..9223372036854775807 | int64 | `L`
19075  number_unsigned | 0..127 | int8 | `i`
19076  number_unsigned | 128..255 | uint8 | `U`
19077  number_unsigned | 256..32767 | int16 | `I`
19078  number_unsigned | 32768..2147483647 | int32 | `l`
19079  number_unsigned | 2147483648..9223372036854775807 | int64 | `L`
19080  number_float | *any value* | float64 | `D`
19081  string | *with shortest length indicator* | string | `S`
19082  array | *see notes on optimized format* | array | `[`
19083  object | *see notes on optimized format* | map | `{`
19084 
19085  @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
19086  can be converted to a UBJSON value.
19087 
19088  @note The following values can **not** be converted to a UBJSON value:
19089  - strings with more than 9223372036854775807 bytes (theoretical)
19090  - unsigned integer numbers above 9223372036854775807
19091 
19092  @note The following markers are not used in the conversion:
19093  - `Z`: no-op values are not created.
19094  - `C`: single-byte strings are serialized with `S` markers.
19095 
19096  @note Any UBJSON output created @ref to_ubjson can be successfully parsed
19097  by @ref from_ubjson.
19098 
19099  @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
19100  serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
19101  function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
19102 
19103  @note The optimized formats for containers are supported: Parameter
19104  @a use_size adds size information to the beginning of a container and
19105  removes the closing marker. Parameter @a use_type further checks
19106  whether all elements of a container have the same type and adds the
19107  type marker to the beginning of the container. The @a use_type
19108  parameter must only be used together with @a use_size = true. Note
19109  that @a use_size = true alone may result in larger representations -
19110  the benefit of this parameter is that the receiving side is
19111  immediately informed on the number of elements of the container.
19112 
19113  @param[in] j JSON value to serialize
19114  @param[in] use_size whether to add size annotations to container types
19115  @param[in] use_type whether to add type annotations to container types
19116  (must be combined with @a use_size = true)
19117  @return UBJSON serialization as byte vector
19118 
19119  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
19120 
19121  @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
19122  vector in UBJSON format.,to_ubjson}
19123 
19124  @sa http://ubjson.org
19125  @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19126  analogous deserialization
19127  @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json& for the related CBOR format
19128  @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
19129 
19130  @since version 3.1.0
19131  */
19132  static std::vector<uint8_t> to_ubjson(const basic_json& j,
19133  const bool use_size = false,
19134  const bool use_type = false)
19135  {
19136  std::vector<uint8_t> result;
19137  to_ubjson(j, result, use_size, use_type);
19138  return result;
19139  }
19140 
19141  static void to_ubjson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o,
19142  const bool use_size = false, const bool use_type = false)
19143  {
19144  binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_ubjson(j, use_size, use_type);
19145  }
19146 
19147  static void to_ubjson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o,
19148  const bool use_size = false, const bool use_type = false)
19149  {
19150  binary_writer<char>(o).write_ubjson(j, use_size, use_type);
19151  }
19152 
19153 
19154  /*!
19155  @brief Serializes the given JSON object `j` to BSON and returns a vector
19156  containing the corresponding BSON-representation.
19157 
19158  BSON (Binary JSON) is a binary format in which zero or more ordered key/value pairs are
19159  stored as a single entity (a so-called document).
19160 
19161  The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to BSON types:
19162 
19163  JSON value type | value/range | BSON type | marker
19164  --------------- | --------------------------------- | ----------- | ------
19165  null | `null` | null | 0x0A
19166  boolean | `true`, `false` | boolean | 0x08
19167  number_integer | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64 | 0x12
19168  number_integer | -2147483648..2147483647 | int32 | 0x10
19169  number_integer | 2147483648..9223372036854775807 | int64 | 0x12
19170  number_unsigned | 0..2147483647 | int32 | 0x10
19171  number_unsigned | 2147483648..9223372036854775807 | int64 | 0x12
19172  number_unsigned | 9223372036854775808..18446744073709551615| -- | --
19173  number_float | *any value* | double | 0x01
19174  string | *any value* | string | 0x02
19175  array | *any value* | document | 0x04
19176  object | *any value* | document | 0x03
19177 
19178  @warning The mapping is **incomplete**, since only JSON-objects (and things
19179  contained therein) can be serialized to BSON.
19180  Also, integers larger than 9223372036854775807 cannot be serialized to BSON,
19181  and the keys may not contain U+0000, since they are serialized a
19182  zero-terminated c-strings.
19183 
19184  @throw out_of_range.407 if `j.is_number_unsigned() && j.get<std::uint64_t>() > 9223372036854775807`
19185  @throw out_of_range.409 if a key in `j` contains a NULL (U+0000)
19186  @throw type_error.317 if `!j.is_object()`
19187 
19188  @pre The input `j` is required to be an object: `j.is_object() == true`.
19189 
19190  @note Any BSON output created via @ref to_bson can be successfully parsed
19191  by @ref from_bson.
19192 
19193  @param[in] j JSON value to serialize
19194  @return BSON serialization as byte vector
19195 
19196  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
19197 
19198  @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
19199  vector in BSON format.,to_bson}
19200 
19201  @sa http://bsonspec.org/spec.html
19202  @sa @ref from_bson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool strict) for the
19203  analogous deserialization
19204  @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
19205  related UBJSON format
19206  @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json&) for the related CBOR format
19207  @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
19208  */
19209  static std::vector<uint8_t> to_bson(const basic_json& j)
19210  {
19211  std::vector<uint8_t> result;
19212  to_bson(j, result);
19213  return result;
19214  }
19215 
19216  /*!
19217  @brief Serializes the given JSON object `j` to BSON and forwards the
19218  corresponding BSON-representation to the given output_adapter `o`.
19219  @param j The JSON object to convert to BSON.
19220  @param o The output adapter that receives the binary BSON representation.
19221  @pre The input `j` shall be an object: `j.is_object() == true`
19222  @sa @ref to_bson(const basic_json&)
19223  */
19224  static void to_bson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
19225  {
19226  binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_bson(j);
19227  }
19228 
19229  /*!
19230  @copydoc to_bson(const basic_json&, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t>)
19231  */
19232  static void to_bson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
19233  {
19234  binary_writer<char>(o).write_bson(j);
19235  }
19236 
19237 
19238  /*!
19239  @brief create a JSON value from an input in CBOR format
19240 
19241  Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the CBOR (Concise
19242  Binary Object Representation) serialization format.
19243 
19244  The library maps CBOR types to JSON value types as follows:
19245 
19246  CBOR type | JSON value type | first byte
19247  ---------------------- | --------------- | ----------
19248  Integer | number_unsigned | 0x00..0x17
19249  Unsigned integer | number_unsigned | 0x18
19250  Unsigned integer | number_unsigned | 0x19
19251  Unsigned integer | number_unsigned | 0x1A
19252  Unsigned integer | number_unsigned | 0x1B
19253  Negative integer | number_integer | 0x20..0x37
19254  Negative integer | number_integer | 0x38
19255  Negative integer | number_integer | 0x39
19256  Negative integer | number_integer | 0x3A
19257  Negative integer | number_integer | 0x3B
19258  Negative integer | number_integer | 0x40..0x57
19259  UTF-8 string | string | 0x60..0x77
19260  UTF-8 string | string | 0x78
19261  UTF-8 string | string | 0x79
19262  UTF-8 string | string | 0x7A
