19263  UTF-8 string | string | 0x7B
19264  UTF-8 string | string | 0x7F
19265  array | array | 0x80..0x97
19266  array | array | 0x98
19267  array | array | 0x99
19268  array | array | 0x9A
19269  array | array | 0x9B
19270  array | array | 0x9F
19271  map | object | 0xA0..0xB7
19272  map | object | 0xB8
19273  map | object | 0xB9
19274  map | object | 0xBA
19275  map | object | 0xBB
19276  map | object | 0xBF
19277  False | `false` | 0xF4
19278  True | `true` | 0xF5
19279  Null | `null` | 0xF6
19280  Half-Precision Float | number_float | 0xF9
19281  Single-Precision Float | number_float | 0xFA
19282  Double-Precision Float | number_float | 0xFB
19283 
19284  @warning The mapping is **incomplete** in the sense that not all CBOR
19285  types can be converted to a JSON value. The following CBOR types
19286  are not supported and will yield parse errors (parse_error.112):
19287  - byte strings (0x40..0x5F)
19288  - date/time (0xC0..0xC1)
19289  - bignum (0xC2..0xC3)
19290  - decimal fraction (0xC4)
19291  - bigfloat (0xC5)
19292  - tagged items (0xC6..0xD4, 0xD8..0xDB)
19293  - expected conversions (0xD5..0xD7)
19294  - simple values (0xE0..0xF3, 0xF8)
19295  - undefined (0xF7)
19296 
19297  @warning CBOR allows map keys of any type, whereas JSON only allows
19298  strings as keys in object values. Therefore, CBOR maps with keys
19299  other than UTF-8 strings are rejected (parse_error.113).
19300 
19301  @note Any CBOR output created @ref to_cbor can be successfully parsed by
19302  @ref from_cbor.
19303 
19304  @param[in] i an input in CBOR format convertible to an input adapter
19305  @param[in] strict whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
19306  (true by default)
19307  @param[in] allow_exceptions whether to throw exceptions in case of a
19308  parse error (optional, true by default)
19309 
19310  @return deserialized JSON value; in case of a parse error and
19311  @a allow_exceptions set to `false`, the return value will be
19312  value_t::discarded.
19313 
19314  @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
19315  file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
19316  @throw parse_error.112 if unsupported features from CBOR were
19317  used in the given input @a v or if the input is not valid CBOR
19318  @throw parse_error.113 if a string was expected as map key, but not found
19319 
19320  @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
19321 
19322  @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in CBOR
19323  format to a JSON value.,from_cbor}
19324 
19325  @sa http://cbor.io
19326  @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
19327  @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19328  related MessagePack format
19329  @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19330  related UBJSON format
19331 
19332  @since version 2.0.9; parameter @a start_index since 2.1.1; changed to
19333  consume input adapters, removed start_index parameter, and added
19334  @a strict parameter since 3.0.0; added @a allow_exceptions parameter
19335  since 3.2.0
19336  */
19337  JSON_NODISCARD
19338  static basic_json from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&& i,
19339  const bool strict = true,
19340  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19341  {
19342  basic_json result;
19343  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19344  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::cbor, &sdp, strict);
19345  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19346  }
19347 
19348  /*!
19349  @copydoc from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool)
19350  */
19351  template<typename A1, typename A2,
19352  detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
19353  JSON_NODISCARD
19354  static basic_json from_cbor(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
19355  const bool strict = true,
19356  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19357  {
19358  basic_json result;
19359  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19360  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1), std::forward<A2>(a2))).sax_parse(input_format_t::cbor, &sdp, strict);
19361  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19362  }
19363 
19364  /*!
19365  @brief create a JSON value from an input in MessagePack format
19366 
19367  Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the MessagePack
19368  serialization format.
19369 
19370  The library maps MessagePack types to JSON value types as follows:
19371 
19372  MessagePack type | JSON value type | first byte
19373  ---------------- | --------------- | ----------
19374  positive fixint | number_unsigned | 0x00..0x7F
19375  fixmap | object | 0x80..0x8F
19376  fixarray | array | 0x90..0x9F
19377  fixstr | string | 0xA0..0xBF
19378  nil | `null` | 0xC0
19379  false | `false` | 0xC2
19380  true | `true` | 0xC3
19381  float 32 | number_float | 0xCA
19382  float 64 | number_float | 0xCB
19383  uint 8 | number_unsigned | 0xCC
19384  uint 16 | number_unsigned | 0xCD
19385  uint 32 | number_unsigned | 0xCE
19386  uint 64 | number_unsigned | 0xCF
19387  int 8 | number_integer | 0xD0
19388  int 16 | number_integer | 0xD1
19389  int 32 | number_integer | 0xD2
19390  int 64 | number_integer | 0xD3
19391  str 8 | string | 0xD9
19392  str 16 | string | 0xDA
19393  str 32 | string | 0xDB
19394  array 16 | array | 0xDC
19395  array 32 | array | 0xDD
19396  map 16 | object | 0xDE
19397  map 32 | object | 0xDF
19398  negative fixint | number_integer | 0xE0-0xFF
19399 
19400  @warning The mapping is **incomplete** in the sense that not all
19401  MessagePack types can be converted to a JSON value. The following
19402  MessagePack types are not supported and will yield parse errors:
19403  - bin 8 - bin 32 (0xC4..0xC6)
19404  - ext 8 - ext 32 (0xC7..0xC9)
19405  - fixext 1 - fixext 16 (0xD4..0xD8)
19406 
19407  @note Any MessagePack output created @ref to_msgpack can be successfully
19408  parsed by @ref from_msgpack.
19409 
19410  @param[in] i an input in MessagePack format convertible to an input
19411  adapter
19412  @param[in] strict whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
19413  (true by default)
19414  @param[in] allow_exceptions whether to throw exceptions in case of a
19415  parse error (optional, true by default)
19416 
19417  @return deserialized JSON value; in case of a parse error and
19418  @a allow_exceptions set to `false`, the return value will be
19419  value_t::discarded.
19420 
19421  @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
19422  file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
19423  @throw parse_error.112 if unsupported features from MessagePack were
19424  used in the given input @a i or if the input is not valid MessagePack
19425  @throw parse_error.113 if a string was expected as map key, but not found
19426 
19427  @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
19428 
19429  @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
19430  MessagePack format to a JSON value.,from_msgpack}
19431 
19432  @sa http://msgpack.org
19433  @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
19434  @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19435  related CBOR format
19436  @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for
19437  the related UBJSON format
19438  @sa @ref from_bson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for
19439  the related BSON format
19440 
19441  @since version 2.0.9; parameter @a start_index since 2.1.1; changed to
19442  consume input adapters, removed start_index parameter, and added
19443  @a strict parameter since 3.0.0; added @a allow_exceptions parameter
19444  since 3.2.0
19445  */
19446  JSON_NODISCARD
19447  static basic_json from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter&& i,
19448  const bool strict = true,
19449  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19450  {
19451  basic_json result;
19452  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19453  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::msgpack, &sdp, strict);
19454  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19455  }
19456 
19457  /*!
19458  @copydoc from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool)
19459  */
19460  template<typename A1, typename A2,
19461  detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
19462  JSON_NODISCARD
19463  static basic_json from_msgpack(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
19464  const bool strict = true,
19465  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19466  {
19467  basic_json result;
19468  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19469  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1), std::forward<A2>(a2))).sax_parse(input_format_t::msgpack, &sdp, strict);
19470  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19471  }
19472 
19473  /*!
19474  @brief create a JSON value from an input in UBJSON format
19475 
19476  Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the UBJSON (Universal
19477  Binary JSON) serialization format.
19478 
19479  The library maps UBJSON types to JSON value types as follows:
19480 
19481  UBJSON type | JSON value type | marker
19482  ----------- | --------------------------------------- | ------
19483  no-op | *no value, next value is read* | `N`
19484  null | `null` | `Z`
19485  false | `false` | `F`
19486  true | `true` | `T`
19487  float32 | number_float | `d`
19488  float64 | number_float | `D`
19489  uint8 | number_unsigned | `U`
19490  int8 | number_integer | `i`
19491  int16 | number_integer | `I`
19492  int32 | number_integer | `l`
19493  int64 | number_integer | `L`
19494  string | string | `S`
19495  char | string | `C`
19496  array | array (optimized values are supported) | `[`
19497  object | object (optimized values are supported) | `{`
19498 
19499  @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any UBJSON value can
19500  be converted to a JSON value.
19501 
19502  @param[in] i an input in UBJSON format convertible to an input adapter
19503  @param[in] strict whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
19504  (true by default)
19505  @param[in] allow_exceptions whether to throw exceptions in case of a
19506  parse error (optional, true by default)
19507 
19508  @return deserialized JSON value; in case of a parse error and
19509  @a allow_exceptions set to `false`, the return value will be
19510  value_t::discarded.
19511 
19512  @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
19513  file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
19514  @throw parse_error.112 if a parse error occurs
19515  @throw parse_error.113 if a string could not be parsed successfully
19516 
19517  @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
19518 
19519  @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
19520  UBJSON format to a JSON value.,from_ubjson}
19521 
19522  @sa http://ubjson.org
19523  @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
19524  analogous serialization
19525  @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19526  related CBOR format
19527  @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for
19528  the related MessagePack format
19529  @sa @ref from_bson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for
19530  the related BSON format
19531 
19532  @since version 3.1.0; added @a allow_exceptions parameter since 3.2.0
19533  */
19534  JSON_NODISCARD
19535  static basic_json from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&& i,
19536  const bool strict = true,
19537  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19538  {
19539  basic_json result;
19540  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19541  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::ubjson, &sdp, strict);
19542  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19543  }
19544 
19545  /*!
19546  @copydoc from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool)
19547  */
19548  template<typename A1, typename A2,
19549  detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
19550  JSON_NODISCARD
19551  static basic_json from_ubjson(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
19552  const bool strict = true,
19553  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19554  {
19555  basic_json result;
19556  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19557  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1), std::forward<A2>(a2))).sax_parse(input_format_t::ubjson, &sdp, strict);
19558  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19559  }
19560 
19561  /*!
19562  @brief Create a JSON value from an input in BSON format
19563 
19564  Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the BSON (Binary JSON)
19565  serialization format.
19566 
19567  The library maps BSON record types to JSON value types as follows:
19568 
19569  BSON type | BSON marker byte | JSON value type
19570  --------------- | ---------------- | ---------------------------
19571  double | 0x01 | number_float
19572  string | 0x02 | string
19573  document | 0x03 | object
19574  array | 0x04 | array
19575  binary | 0x05 | still unsupported
19576  undefined | 0x06 | still unsupported
19577  ObjectId | 0x07 | still unsupported
19578  boolean | 0x08 | boolean
19579  UTC Date-Time | 0x09 | still unsupported
19580  null | 0x0A | null
19581  Regular Expr. | 0x0B | still unsupported
19582  DB Pointer | 0x0C | still unsupported
19583  JavaScript Code | 0x0D | still unsupported
19584  Symbol | 0x0E | still unsupported
19585  JavaScript Code | 0x0F | still unsupported
19586  int32 | 0x10 | number_integer
19587  Timestamp | 0x11 | still unsupported
19588  128-bit decimal float | 0x13 | still unsupported
19589  Max Key | 0x7F | still unsupported
19590  Min Key | 0xFF | still unsupported
19591 
19592  @warning The mapping is **incomplete**. The unsupported mappings
19593  are indicated in the table above.
19594 
19595  @param[in] i an input in BSON format convertible to an input adapter
19596  @param[in] strict whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
19597  (true by default)
19598  @param[in] allow_exceptions whether to throw exceptions in case of a
19599  parse error (optional, true by default)
19600 
19601  @return deserialized JSON value; in case of a parse error and
19602  @a allow_exceptions set to `false`, the return value will be
19603  value_t::discarded.
19604 
19605  @throw parse_error.114 if an unsupported BSON record type is encountered
19606 
19607  @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
19608 
19609  @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
19610  BSON format to a JSON value.,from_bson}
19611 
19612  @sa http://bsonspec.org/spec.html
19613  @sa @ref to_bson(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
19614  @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19615  related CBOR format
19616  @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for
19617  the related MessagePack format
19618  @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool) for the
19619  related UBJSON format
19620  */
19621  JSON_NODISCARD
19622  static basic_json from_bson(detail::input_adapter&& i,
19623  const bool strict = true,
19624  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19625  {
19626  basic_json result;
19627  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19628  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::bson, &sdp, strict);
19629  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19630  }
19631 
19632  /*!
19633  @copydoc from_bson(detail::input_adapter&&, const bool, const bool)
19634  */
19635  template<typename A1, typename A2,
19636  detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
19637  JSON_NODISCARD
19638  static basic_json from_bson(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
19639  const bool strict = true,
19640  const bool allow_exceptions = true)
19641  {
19642  basic_json result;
19643  detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
19644  const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1), std::forward<A2>(a2))).sax_parse(input_format_t::bson, &sdp, strict);
19645  return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
19646  }
19647 
19648 
19649 
19650  /// @}
19651 
19652  //////////////////////////
19653  // JSON Pointer support //
19654  //////////////////////////
19655 
19656  /// @name JSON Pointer functions
19657  /// @{
19658 
19659  /*!
19660  @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
19661 
19662  Uses a JSON pointer to retrieve a reference to the respective JSON value.
19663  No bound checking is performed. Similar to @ref operator[](const typename
19664  object_t::key_type&), `null` values are created in arrays and objects if
19665  necessary.
19666 
19667  In particular:
19668  - If the JSON pointer points to an object key that does not exist, it
19669  is created an filled with a `null` value before a reference to it
19670  is returned.
19671  - If the JSON pointer points to an array index that does not exist, it
19672  is created an filled with a `null` value before a reference to it
19673  is returned. All indices between the current maximum and the given
19674  index are also filled with `null`.
19675  - The special value `-` is treated as a synonym for the index past the
19676  end.
19677 
19678  @param[in] ptr a JSON pointer
19679 
19680  @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
19681 
19682  @complexity Constant.
19683 
19684  @throw parse_error.106 if an array index begins with '0'
19685  @throw parse_error.109 if an array index was not a number
19686  @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer can not be resolved
19687 
19688  @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,operatorjson_pointer}
19689 
19690  @since version 2.0.0
19691  */
19692  reference operator[](const json_pointer& ptr)
19693  {
19694  return ptr.get_unchecked(this);
19695  }
19696 
19697  /*!
19698  @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
19699 
19700  Uses a JSON pointer to retrieve a reference to the respective JSON value.
19701  No bound checking is performed. The function does not change the JSON
19702  value; no `null` values are created. In particular, the the special value
19703  `-` yields an exception.
19704 
19705  @param[in] ptr JSON pointer to the desired element
19706 
19707  @return const reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
19708 
19709  @complexity Constant.
19710 
19711  @throw parse_error.106 if an array index begins with '0'
19712  @throw parse_error.109 if an array index was not a number
19713  @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used
19714  @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer can not be resolved
19715 
19716  @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,operatorjson_pointer_const}
19717 
19718  @since version 2.0.0
19719  */
19720  const_reference operator[](const json_pointer& ptr) const
19721  {
19722  return ptr.get_unchecked(this);
19723  }
19724 
19725  /*!
19726  @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
19727 
19728  Returns a reference to the element at with specified JSON pointer @a ptr,
19729  with bounds checking.
19730 
19731  @param[in] ptr JSON pointer to the desired element
19732 
19733  @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
19734 
19735  @throw parse_error.106 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
19736  begins with '0'. See example below.
19737 
19738  @throw parse_error.109 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
19739  is not a number. See example below.
19740 
19741  @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
19742  is out of range. See example below.
19743 
19744  @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used in the passed JSON
19745  pointer @a ptr. As `at` provides checked access (and no elements are
19746  implicitly inserted), the index '-' is always invalid. See example below.
19747 
19748  @throw out_of_range.403 if the JSON pointer describes a key of an object
19749  which cannot be found. See example below.
19750 
19751  @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer @a ptr can not be resolved.
19752  See example below.
19753 
19754  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
19755  changes in the JSON value.
19756 
19757  @complexity Constant.
19758 
19759  @since version 2.0.0
19760 
19761  @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,at_json_pointer}
19762  */
19763  reference at(const json_pointer& ptr)
19764  {
19765  return ptr.get_checked(this);
19766  }
19767 
19768  /*!
19769  @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
19770 
19771  Returns a const reference to the element at with specified JSON pointer @a
19772  ptr, with bounds checking.
19773 
19774  @param[in] ptr JSON pointer to the desired element
19775 
19776  @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
19777 
19778  @throw parse_error.106 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
19779  begins with '0'. See example below.
19780 
19781  @throw parse_error.109 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
19782  is not a number. See example below.
19783 
19784  @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
19785  is out of range. See example below.
19786 
19787  @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used in the passed JSON
19788  pointer @a ptr. As `at` provides checked access (and no elements are
19789  implicitly inserted), the index '-' is always invalid. See example below.
19790 
19791  @throw out_of_range.403 if the JSON pointer describes a key of an object
19792  which cannot be found. See example below.
19793 
19794  @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer @a ptr can not be resolved.
19795  See example below.
19796 
19797  @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
19798  changes in the JSON value.
19799 
19800  @complexity Constant.
19801 
19802  @since version 2.0.0
19803 
19804  @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,at_json_pointer_const}
19805  */
19806  const_reference at(const json_pointer& ptr) const
19807  {
19808  return ptr.get_checked(this);
19809  }
19810 
19811  /*!
19812  @brief return flattened JSON value
19813 
19814  The function creates a JSON object whose keys are JSON pointers (see [RFC
19815  6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)) and whose values are all
19816  primitive. The original JSON value can be restored using the @ref
19817  unflatten() function.
19818 
19819  @return an object that maps JSON pointers to primitive values
19820 
19821  @note Empty objects and arrays are flattened to `null` and will not be
19822  reconstructed correctly by the @ref unflatten() function.
19823 
19824  @complexity Linear in the size the JSON value.
19825 
19826  @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON object is flattened to an
19827  object whose keys consist of JSON pointers.,flatten}
19828 
19829  @sa @ref unflatten() for the reverse function
19830 
19831  @since version 2.0.0
19832  */
19833  basic_json flatten() const
19834  {
19835  basic_json result(value_t::object);
19836  json_pointer::flatten("", *this, result);
19837  return result;
19838  }
19839 
19840  /*!
19841  @brief unflatten a previously flattened JSON value
19842 
19843  The function restores the arbitrary nesting of a JSON value that has been
19844  flattened before using the @ref flatten() function. The JSON value must
19845  meet certain constraints:
19846  1. The value must be an object.
19847  2. The keys must be JSON pointers (see
19848  [RFC 6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901))
19849  3. The mapped values must be primitive JSON types.
19850 
19851  @return the original JSON from a flattened version
19852 
19853  @note Empty objects and arrays are flattened by @ref flatten() to `null`
19854  values and can not unflattened to their original type. Apart from
19855  this example, for a JSON value `j`, the following is always true:
19856  `j == j.flatten().unflatten()`.
19857 
19858  @complexity Linear in the size the JSON value.
19859 
19860  @throw type_error.314 if value is not an object
19861  @throw type_error.315 if object values are not primitive
19862 
19863  @liveexample{The following code shows how a flattened JSON object is
19864  unflattened into the original nested JSON object.,unflatten}
19865 
19866  @sa @ref flatten() for the reverse function
19867 
19868  @since version 2.0.0
19869  */
19870  basic_json unflatten() const
19871  {
19872  return json_pointer::unflatten(*this);
19873  }
19874 
19875  /// @}
19876 
19877  //////////////////////////
19878  // JSON Patch functions //
19879  //////////////////////////
19880 
19881  /// @name JSON Patch functions
19882  /// @{
19883 
19884  /*!
19885  @brief applies a JSON patch
19886 
19887  [JSON Patch](http://jsonpatch.com) defines a JSON document structure for
19888  expressing a sequence of operations to apply to a JSON) document. With
19889  this function, a JSON Patch is applied to the current JSON value by
19890  executing all operations from the patch.
19891 
19892  @param[in] json_patch JSON patch document
19893  @return patched document
19894 
19895  @note The application of a patch is atomic: Either all operations succeed
19896  and the patched document is returned or an exception is thrown. In
19897  any case, the original value is not changed: the patch is applied
19898  to a copy of the value.
19899 
19900  @throw parse_error.104 if the JSON patch does not consist of an array of
19901  objects
19902 
19903  @throw parse_error.105 if the JSON patch is malformed (e.g., mandatory
19904  attributes are missing); example: `"operation add must have member path"`
19905 
19906  @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index is out of range.
19907 
19908  @throw out_of_range.403 if a JSON pointer inside the patch could not be
19909  resolved successfully in the current JSON value; example: `"key baz not
19910  found"`
19911 
19912  @throw out_of_range.405 if JSON pointer has no parent ("add", "remove",
19913  "move")
19914 
19915  @throw other_error.501 if "test" operation was unsuccessful
19916 
19917  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value and the length of the
19918  JSON patch. As usually only a fraction of the JSON value is affected by
19919  the patch, the complexity can usually be neglected.
19920 
19921  @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON patch is applied to a
19922  value.,patch}
19923 
19924  @sa @ref diff -- create a JSON patch by comparing two JSON values
19925 
19926  @sa [RFC 6902 (JSON Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6902)
19927  @sa [RFC 6901 (JSON Pointer)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)
19928 
19929  @since version 2.0.0
19930  */
19931  basic_json patch(const basic_json& json_patch) const
19932  {
19933  // make a working copy to apply the patch to
19934  basic_json result = *this;
19935 
19936  // the valid JSON Patch operations
19937  enum class patch_operations {add, remove, replace, move, copy, test, invalid};
19938 
19939  const auto get_op = [](const std::string & op)
19940  {
19941  if (op == "add")
19942  {
19943  return patch_operations::add;
19944  }
19945  if (op == "remove")
19946  {
19947  return patch_operations::remove;
19948  }
19949  if (op == "replace")
19950  {
19951  return patch_operations::replace;
19952  }
19953  if (op == "move")
19954  {
19955  return patch_operations::move;
19956  }
19957  if (op == "copy")
19958  {
19959  return patch_operations::copy;
19960  }
19961  if (op == "test")
19962  {
19963  return patch_operations::test;
19964  }
19965 
19966  return patch_operations::invalid;
19967  };
19968 
19969  // wrapper for "add" operation; add value at ptr
19970  const auto operation_add = [&result](json_pointer & ptr, basic_json val)
19971  {
19972  // adding to the root of the target document means replacing it
19973  if (ptr.is_root())
19974  {
19975  result = val;
19976  }
19977  else
19978  {
19979  // make sure the top element of the pointer exists
19980  json_pointer top_pointer = ptr.top();
19981  if (top_pointer != ptr)
19982  {
19983  result.at(top_pointer);
19984  }
19985 
19986  // get reference to parent of JSON pointer ptr
19987  const auto last_path = ptr.pop_back();
19988  basic_json& parent = result[ptr];
19989 
19990  switch (parent.m_type)
19991  {
19992  case value_t::null:
19993  case value_t::object:
19994  {
19995  // use operator[] to add value
19996  parent[last_path] = val;
19997  break;
19998  }
19999 
20000  case value_t::array:
20001  {
20002  if (last_path == "-")
20003  {
20004  // special case: append to back
20005  parent.push_back(val);
20006  }
20007  else
20008  {
20009  const auto idx = json_pointer::array_index(last_path);
20010  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(static_cast<size_type>(idx) > parent.size()))
20011  {
20012  // avoid undefined behavior
20013  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
20014  }
20015 
20016  // default case: insert add offset
20017  parent.insert(parent.begin() + static_cast<difference_type>(idx), val);
20018  }
20019  break;
20020  }
20021 
20022  // LCOV_EXCL_START
20023  default:
20024  {
20025  // if there exists a parent it cannot be primitive
20026  assert(false);
20027  }
20028  // LCOV_EXCL_STOP
20029  }
20030  }
20031  };
20032 
20033  // wrapper for "remove" operation; remove value at ptr
20034  const auto operation_remove = [&result](json_pointer & ptr)
20035  {
20036  // get reference to parent of JSON pointer ptr
20037  const auto last_path = ptr.pop_back();
20038  basic_json& parent = result.at(ptr);
20039 
20040  // remove child
20041  if (parent.is_object())
20042  {
20043  // perform range check
20044  auto it = parent.find(last_path);
20045  if (JSON_LIKELY(it != parent.end()))
20046  {
20047  parent.erase(it);
20048  }
20049  else
20050  {
20051  JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + last_path + "' not found"));
20052  }
20053  }
20054  else if (parent.is_array())
20055  {
20056  // note erase performs range check
20057  parent.erase(static_cast<size_type>(json_pointer::array_index(last_path)));
20058  }
20059  };
20060 
20061  // type check: top level value must be an array
20062  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not json_patch.is_array()))
20063  {
20064  JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(104, 0, "JSON patch must be an array of objects"));
20065  }
20066 
20067  // iterate and apply the operations
20068  for (const auto& val : json_patch)
20069  {
20070  // wrapper to get a value for an operation
20071  const auto get_value = [&val](const std::string & op,
20072  const std::string & member,
20073  bool string_type) -> basic_json &
20074  {
20075  // find value
20076  auto it = val.m_value.object->find(member);
20077 
20078  // context-sensitive error message
20079  const auto error_msg = (op == "op") ? "operation" : "operation '" + op + "'";
20080 
20081  // check if desired value is present
20082  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(it == val.m_value.object->end()))
20083  {
20084  JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(105, 0, error_msg + " must have member '" + member + "'"));
20085  }
20086 
20087  // check if result is of type string
20088  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(string_type and not it->second.is_string()))
20089  {
20090  JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(105, 0, error_msg + " must have string member '" + member + "'"));
20091  }
20092 
20093  // no error: return value
20094  return it->second;
20095  };
20096 
20097  // type check: every element of the array must be an object
20098  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not val.is_object()))
20099  {
20100  JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(104, 0, "JSON patch must be an array of objects"));
20101  }
20102 
20103  // collect mandatory members
20104  const std::string op = get_value("op", "op", true);
20105  const std::string path = get_value(op, "path", true);
20106  json_pointer ptr(path);
20107 
20108  switch (get_op(op))
20109  {
20110  case patch_operations::add:
20111  {
20112  operation_add(ptr, get_value("add", "value", false));
20113  break;
20114  }
20115 
20116  case patch_operations::remove:
20117  {
20118  operation_remove(ptr);
20119  break;
20120  }
20121 
20122  case patch_operations::replace:
20123  {
20124  // the "path" location must exist - use at()
20125  result.at(ptr) = get_value("replace", "value", false);
20126  break;
20127  }
20128 
20129  case patch_operations::move:
20130  {
20131  const std::string from_path = get_value("move", "from", true);
20132  json_pointer from_ptr(from_path);
20133 
20134  // the "from" location must exist - use at()
20135  basic_json v = result.at(from_ptr);
20136 
20137  // The move operation is functionally identical to a
20138  // "remove" operation on the "from" location, followed
20139  // immediately by an "add" operation at the target
20140  // location with the value that was just removed.
20141  operation_remove(from_ptr);
20142  operation_add(ptr, v);
20143  break;
20144  }
20145 
20146  case patch_operations::copy:
20147  {
20148  const std::string from_path = get_value("copy", "from", true);
20149  const json_pointer from_ptr(from_path);
20150 
20151  // the "from" location must exist - use at()
20152  basic_json v = result.at(from_ptr);
20153 
20154  // The copy is functionally identical to an "add"
20155  // operation at the target location using the value
20156  // specified in the "from" member.
20157  operation_add(ptr, v);
20158  break;
20159  }
20160 
20161  case patch_operations::test:
20162  {
20163  bool success = false;
20164  JSON_TRY
20165  {
20166  // check if "value" matches the one at "path"
20167  // the "path" location must exist - use at()
20168  success = (result.at(ptr) == get_value("test", "value", false));
20169  }
20170  JSON_INTERNAL_CATCH (out_of_range&)
20171  {
20172  // ignore out of range errors: success remains false
20173  }
20174 
20175  // throw an exception if test fails
20176  if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not success))
20177  {
20178  JSON_THROW(other_error::create(501, "unsuccessful: " + val.dump()));
20179  }
20180 
20181  break;
20182  }
20183 
20184  case patch_operations::invalid:
20185  {
20186  // op must be "add", "remove", "replace", "move", "copy", or
20187  // "test"
20188  JSON_THROW(parse_error::create(105, 0, "operation value '" + op + "' is invalid"));
20189  }
20190  }
20191  }
20192 
20193  return result;
20194  }
20195 
20196  /*!
20197  @brief creates a diff as a JSON patch
20198 
20199  Creates a [JSON Patch](http://jsonpatch.com) so that value @a source can
20200  be changed into the value @a target by calling @ref patch function.
20201 
20202  @invariant For two JSON values @a source and @a target, the following code
20203  yields always `true`:
20204  @code {.cpp}
20205  source.patch(diff(source, target)) == target;
20206  @endcode
20207 
20208  @note Currently, only `remove`, `add`, and `replace` operations are
20209  generated.
20210 
20211  @param[in] source JSON value to compare from
20212  @param[in] target JSON value to compare against
20213  @param[in] path helper value to create JSON pointers
20214 
20215  @return a JSON patch to convert the @a source to @a target
20216 
20217  @complexity Linear in the lengths of @a source and @a target.
20218 
20219  @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON patch is created as a
20220  diff for two JSON values.,diff}
20221 
20222  @sa @ref patch -- apply a JSON patch
20223  @sa @ref merge_patch -- apply a JSON Merge Patch
20224 
20225  @sa [RFC 6902 (JSON Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6902)
20226 
20227  @since version 2.0.0
20228  */
20229  JSON_NODISCARD
20230  static basic_json diff(const basic_json& source, const basic_json& target,
20231  const std::string& path = "")
20232  {
20233  // the patch
20234  basic_json result(value_t::array);
20235 
20236  // if the values are the same, return empty patch
20237  if (source == target)
20238  {
20239  return result;
20240  }
20241 
20242  if (source.type() != target.type())
20243  {
20244  // different types: replace value
20245  result.push_back(
20246  {
20247  {"op", "replace"}, {"path", path}, {"value", target}
20248  });
20249  }
20250  else
20251  {
20252  switch (source.type())
20253  {
20254  case value_t::array:
20255  {
20256  // first pass: traverse common elements
20257  std::size_t i = 0;
20258  while (i < source.size() and i < target.size())
20259  {
20260  // recursive call to compare array values at index i
20261  auto temp_diff = diff(source[i], target[i], path + "/" + std::to_string(i));
20262  result.insert(result.end(), temp_diff.begin(), temp_diff.end());
20263  ++i;
20264  }
20265 
20266  // i now reached the end of at least one array
20267  // in a second pass, traverse the remaining elements
20268 
20269  // remove my remaining elements
20270  const auto end_index = static_cast<difference_type>(result.size());
20271  while (i < source.size())
20272  {
20273  // add operations in reverse order to avoid invalid
20274  // indices
20275  result.insert(result.begin() + end_index, object(
20276  {
20277  {"op", "remove"},
20278  {"path", path + "/" + std::to_string(i)}
20279  }));
20280  ++i;
20281  }
20282 
20283  // add other remaining elements
20284  while (i < target.size())
20285  {
20286  result.push_back(
20287  {
20288  {"op", "add"},
20289  {"path", path + "/" + std::to_string(i)},
20290  {"value", target[i]}
20291  });
20292  ++i;
20293  }
20294 
20295  break;
20296  }
20297 
20298  case value_t::object:
20299  {
20300  // first pass: traverse this object's elements
20301  for (auto it = source.cbegin(); it != source.cend(); ++it)
20302  {
20303  // escape the key name to be used in a JSON patch
20304  const auto key = json_pointer::escape(it.key());
20305 
20306  if (target.find(it.key()) != target.end())
20307  {
20308  // recursive call to compare object values at key it
20309  auto temp_diff = diff(it.value(), target[it.key()], path + "/" + key);
20310  result.insert(result.end(), temp_diff.begin(), temp_diff.end());
20311  }
20312  else
20313  {
20314  // found a key that is not in o -> remove it
20315  result.push_back(object(
20316  {
20317  {"op", "remove"}, {"path", path + "/" + key}
20318  }));
20319  }
20320  }
20321 
20322  // second pass: traverse other object's elements
20323  for (auto it = target.cbegin(); it != target.cend(); ++it)
20324  {
20325  if (source.find(it.key()) == source.end())
20326  {
20327  // found a key that is not in this -> add it
20328  const auto key = json_pointer::escape(it.key());
20329  result.push_back(
20330  {
20331  {"op", "add"}, {"path", path + "/" + key},
20332  {"value", it.value()}
20333  });
20334  }
20335  }
20336 
20337  break;
20338  }
20339 
20340  default:
20341  {
20342  // both primitive type: replace value
20343  result.push_back(
20344  {
20345  {"op", "replace"}, {"path", path}, {"value", target}
20346  });
20347  break;
20348  }
20349  }
20350  }
20351 
20352  return result;
20353  }
20354 
20355  /// @}
20356 
20357  ////////////////////////////////
20358  // JSON Merge Patch functions //
20359  ////////////////////////////////
20360 
20361  /// @name JSON Merge Patch functions
20362  /// @{
20363 
20364  /*!
20365  @brief applies a JSON Merge Patch
20366 
20367  The merge patch format is primarily intended for use with the HTTP PATCH
20368  method as a means of describing a set of modifications to a target
20369  resource's content. This function applies a merge patch to the current
20370  JSON value.
20371 
20372  The function implements the following algorithm from Section 2 of
20373  [RFC 7396 (JSON Merge Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396):
20374 
20375  ```
20376  define MergePatch(Target, Patch):
20377  if Patch is an Object:
20378  if Target is not an Object:
20379  Target = {} // Ignore the contents and set it to an empty Object
20380  for each Name/Value pair in Patch:
20381  if Value is null:
20382  if Name exists in Target:
20383  remove the Name/Value pair from Target
20384  else:
20385  Target[Name] = MergePatch(Target[Name], Value)
20386  return Target
20387  else:
20388  return Patch
20389  ```
20390 
20391  Thereby, `Target` is the current object; that is, the patch is applied to
20392  the current value.
20393 
20394  @param[in] apply_patch the patch to apply
20395 
20396  @complexity Linear in the lengths of @a patch.
20397 
20398  @liveexample{The following code shows how a JSON Merge Patch is applied to
20399  a JSON document.,merge_patch}
20400 
20401  @sa @ref patch -- apply a JSON patch
20402  @sa [RFC 7396 (JSON Merge Patch)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396)
20403 
20404  @since version 3.0.0
20405  */
20406  void merge_patch(const basic_json& apply_patch)
20407  {
20408  if (apply_patch.is_object())
20409  {
20410  if (not is_object())
20411  {
20412  *this = object();
20413  }
20414  for (auto it = apply_patch.begin(); it != apply_patch.end(); ++it)
20415  {
20416  if (it.value().is_null())
20417  {
20418  erase(it.key());
20419  }
20420  else
20421  {
20422  operator[](it.key()).merge_patch(it.value());
20423  }
20424  }
20425  }
20426  else
20427  {
20428  *this = apply_patch;
20429  }
20430  }
20431 
20432  /// @}
20433 };
20434 } // namespace nlohmann
20435 
20436 ///////////////////////
20437 // nonmember support //
20438 ///////////////////////
20439 
20440 // specialization of std::swap, and std::hash
20441 namespace std
20442 {
20443 
20444 /// hash value for JSON objects
20445 template<>
20446 struct hash<nlohmann::json>
20447 {
20448  /*!
20449  @brief return a hash value for a JSON object
20450 
20451  @since version 1.0.0
20452  */
20453  std::size_t operator()(const nlohmann::json& j) const
20454  {
20455  // a naive hashing via the string representation
20456  const auto& h = hash<nlohmann::json::string_t>();
20457  return h(j.dump());
20458  }
20459 };
20460 
20461 /// specialization for std::less<value_t>
20462 /// @note: do not remove the space after '<',
20463 /// see https://github.com/nlohmann/json/pull/679
20464 template<>
20465 struct less< ::nlohmann::detail::value_t>
20466 {
20467  /*!
20468  @brief compare two value_t enum values
20469  @since version 3.0.0
20470  */
20471  bool operator()(nlohmann::detail::value_t lhs,
20472  nlohmann::detail::value_t rhs) const noexcept
20473  {
20474  return nlohmann::detail::operator<(lhs, rhs);
20475  }
20476 };
20477 
20478 /*!
20479 @brief exchanges the values of two JSON objects
20480 
20481 @since version 1.0.0
20482 */
20483 template<>
20484 inline void swap<nlohmann::json>(nlohmann::json& j1, nlohmann::json& j2) noexcept(
20485  is_nothrow_move_constructible<nlohmann::json>::value and
20486  is_nothrow_move_assignable<nlohmann::json>::value
20487 )
20488 {
20489  j1.swap(j2);
20490 }
20491 
20492 } // namespace std
20493 
20494 /*!
20495 @brief user-defined string literal for JSON values
20496 
20497 This operator implements a user-defined string literal for JSON objects. It
20498 can be used by adding `"_json"` to a string literal and returns a JSON object
20499 if no parse error occurred.
20500 
20501 @param[in] s a string representation of a JSON object
20502 @param[in] n the length of string @a s
20503 @return a JSON object
20504 
20505 @since version 1.0.0
20506 */
20507 inline nlohmann::json operator "" _json(const char* s, std::size_t n)
20508 {
20509  return nlohmann::json::parse(s, s + n);
20510 }
20511 
20512 /*!
20513 @brief user-defined string literal for JSON pointer
20514 
20515 This operator implements a user-defined string literal for JSON Pointers. It
20516 can be used by adding `"_json_pointer"` to a string literal and returns a JSON pointer
20517 object if no parse error occurred.
20518 
20519 @param[in] s a string representation of a JSON Pointer
20520 @param[in] n the length of string @a s
20521 @return a JSON pointer object
20522 
20523 @since version 2.0.0
20524 */
20525 inline nlohmann::json::json_pointer operator "" _json_pointer(const char* s, std::size_t n)
20526 {
20527  return nlohmann::json::json_pointer(std::string(s, n));
20528 }
20529 
20530 // #include <nlohmann/detail/macro_unscope.hpp>
20531 
20532 
20533 // restore GCC/clang diagnostic settings
20534 #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
20535  #pragma GCC diagnostic pop
20536 #endif
20537 #if defined(__clang__)
20538  #pragma GCC diagnostic pop
20539 #endif
20540 
20541 // clean up
20542 #undef JSON_INTERNAL_CATCH
20543 #undef JSON_CATCH
20544 #undef JSON_THROW
20545 #undef JSON_TRY
20546 #undef JSON_LIKELY
20547 #undef JSON_UNLIKELY
20548 #undef JSON_DEPRECATED
20549 #undef JSON_NODISCARD
20550 #undef JSON_HAS_CPP_14
20551 #undef JSON_HAS_CPP_17
20552 #undef NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION
20553 #undef NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL
20554

20556 #endif
nlohmann::basic_json::json_value::json_value
json_value(string_t &&value)
constructor for rvalue strings

nlohmann::json_sax::number_float

nlohmann::basic_json::array_t
ArrayType< basic_json, AllocatorType< basic_json > > array_t

Definition: json.hpp:13031
nlohmann::basic_json::json_value::object
object_t * object

nlohmann::detail::binary_writer::oa

Definition: json.hpp:9795
nlohmann::basic_json::operator+=

basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last)
construct a JSON container given an iterator range

nlohmann::basic_json::operator[]
const_reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type &key) const
